Preface
The purpose of this book is to provide core material in nonlinear analysis for mathematicians, physicists,
engineers, and mathematical biologists. The main goal is to provide a working knowledge of manifolds,
dynamical systems, tensors and diï¬€erential forms. Some applications to Hamiltonian mechanics, ï¬‚uid me-
chanics, electromagnetism, plasma dynamics and control theory are given in Chapter 8, using both invariant
and index notation.
Throughout the text supplementary topics are noted that may be downloaded from the internet from
http://www.cds.caltech.edu/~marsden. This device enables the reader to skip various topics without
disturbing the main ï¬‚ow of the text. Some of these provide additional background material intended for
completeness, to minimize the necessity of consulting too many outside references.
Philosophy.
We treat ï¬nite and inï¬nite-dimensional manifolds simultaneously. This is partly for eï¬ƒciency
of exposition. Without advanced applications, using manifolds of mappings (such as applications to ï¬‚uid
dynamics), the study of inï¬nite-dimensional manifolds can be hard to motivate. Chapter 8 gives an intro-
duction to these applications. Some readers may wish to skip the inï¬nite-dimensional case altogether. To
aid in this, we have separated some of the technical points peculiar to the inï¬nite-dimensional case into sup-
plements, either directly in the text or on-line. Our own research interests lean toward physical applications,
and the choice of topics is partly shaped by what has been useful to us over the years.
We have tried to be as sympathetic to our readers as possible by providing ample examples, exercises, and
applications. When a computation in coordinates is easiest, we give it and do not hide things behind com-
plicated invariant notation. On the other hand, index-free notation sometimes provides valuable geometric
and computational insight so we have tried to simultaneously convey this ï¬‚avor.
Prerequisites and Links.
The prerequisites required are solid undergraduate courses in linear algebra
and advanced calculus along with the usual mathematical maturity. At various points in the text contacts are
made with other subjects. This provides a good way for students to link this material with other courses. For
example, Chapter 1 links with point-set topology, parts of Chapters 2 and 7 are connected with functional
analysis, Section 4.3 relates to ordinary diï¬€erential equations and dynamical systems, Chapter 3 and Section
7.5 are linked to diï¬€erential topology and algebraic topology, and Chapter 8 on applications is connected
with applied mathematics, physics, and engineering.
Use in Courses.
This book is intended to be used in courses as well as for reference. The sections are,
as far as possible, lesson sized, if the supplementary material is omitted. For some sections, like 2.5, 4.2, or

iv
Preface
7.5, two lecture hours are required if they are to be taught in detail. A standard course for mathematics
graduate students could omit Chapter 1 and the supplements entirely and do Chapters 2 through 7 in one
semester with the possible exception of Section 7.4. The instructor could then assign certain supplements
for reading and choose among the applications of Chapter 8 according to taste.
A shorter course, or a course for advanced undergraduates, probably should omit all supplements, spend
about two lectures on Chapter 1 for reviewing background point set topology, and cover Chapters 2 through
7 with the exception of Sections 4.4, 7.4, 7.5 and all the material relevant to volume elements induced by
metrics, the Hodge star, and codiï¬€erential operators in Sections 6.2, 6.4, 6.5, and 7.2.
A more applications oriented course could skim Chapter 1, review without proofs the material of Chapter
2 and cover Chapters 3 to 8 omitting the supplementary material and Sections 7.4 and 7.5. For such a
course the instructor should keep in mind that while Sections 8.1 and 8.2 use only elementary material,
Section 8.3 relies heavily on the Hodge star and codiï¬€erential operators, and Section 8.4 consists primarily
of applications of Frobeniusâ€™ theorem dealt with in Section 4.4.
The notation in the book is as standard as conï¬‚icting usages in the literature allow. We have had to
compromise among utility, clarity, clumsiness, and absolute precision. Some possible notations would have
required too much interpretation on the part of the novice while others, while precise, would have been so
dressed up in symbolic decorations that even an expert in the ï¬eld would not recognize them.
History and Credits.
In a subject as developed and extensive as this one, an accurate history and
crediting of theorems is a monumental task, especially when so many results are folklore and reside in
private notes. We have indicated some of the important credits where we know of them, but we did not
undertake this task systematically. We hope our readers will inform us of these and other shortcomings of
the book so that, if necessary, corrected printings will be possible. The reference list at the back of the book
is conï¬ned to works actually cited in the text. These works are cited by author and year like this: deRham
[1955].

Topology
The purpose of this chapter is to introduce just enough topology for later requirements. It is assumed that
the reader has had a course in advanced calculus and so is acquainted with open, closed, compact, and
connected sets in Euclidean space (see for example Marsden and Hoï¬€man [1993]). If this background is
weak, the reader may ï¬nd the pace of this chapter too fast. If the background is under control, the chapter
should serve to collect, review, and solidify concepts in a more general context. Readers already familiar
with point set topology can safely skip this chapter.
A key concept in manifold theory is that of a diï¬€erentiable map between manifolds. However, manifolds
are also topological spaces and diï¬€erentiable maps are continuous. Topology is the study of continuity
in a general context, so it is appropriate to begin with it. Topology often involves interesting excursions
into pathological spaces and exotic theorems that can consume lifetimes. Such excursions are deliberately
minimized here. The examples will be ones most relevant to later developments, and the main thrust will
be to obtain a working knowledge of continuity, connectedness, and compactness. We shall take for granted
the usual logical structure of analysis, including properties of the real line and Euclidean space
1.1
Topological Spaces
The notion of a topological space is an abstraction of ideas about open sets in Rn that are learned in
advanced calculus.
1.1.1 Deï¬nition.
A topological space is a set S together with a collection O of subsets of S called open
sets such that

the union of any collection of open sets is open.

For the real line with its standard topology, we choose S = R, with

The Trivial and Discrete Topologies.
The trivial topology on a set S consists of O = {âˆ…, S}. The
discrete topology on S is deï¬ned by O = { A | A âŠ‚S }; that is, O consists of all subsets of S.

Closed rectangles in Rn are closed sets, as are closed balls, one-point sets, and spheres. Not every set is
either open or closed. For example, the interval [0, 1[ is neither an open nor a closed set. In the discrete
topology on S, any set A âŠ‚S is both open and closed, whereas in the trivial topology any A Ì¸= âˆ…or S is
neither.
Closed sets can be used to introduce a topology just as well as open ones. Thus, if C is a collection
satisfying C1â€“C3 and O consists of the complements of sets in C, then O satisï¬es T1â€“T3.
Neighborhoods.
The idea of neighborhoods is to localize the topology.
1.1.4 Deï¬nition.
An open neighborhood of a point u in a topological space S is an open set U such
that u âˆˆU. Similarly, for a subset A of S, U is an open neighborhood of A if U is open and A âŠ‚U. A
neighborhood of a point (or a subset) is a set containing some open neighborhood of the point (or subset).
Examples of neighborhoods of x âˆˆR are ]xâˆ’1, x+3], ]xâˆ’Ïµ, x+Ïµ[ for any Ïµ > 0, and R itself; only the last
two are open neighborhoods. The set [x, x + 2[ contains the point x but is not one of its neighborhoods. In
the trivial topology on a set S, there is only one neighborhood of any point, namely S itself. In the discrete
topology any subset containing p is a neighborhood of the point p âˆˆS, since {p} is an open set.

First and Second Countable Spaces.
1.1.5 Deï¬nition.
A topological space is called ï¬rst countable if for each u âˆˆS there is a sequence
{U1, U2, . . . } = {Un} of neighborhoods of u such that for any neighborhood U of u, there is an integer n such
that Un âŠ‚U. A subset B of O is called a basis for the topology, if each open set is a union of elements in
B. The topology is called second countable if it has a countable basis.
Most topological spaces of interest to us will be second countable. For example Rn is second countable
since it has the countable basis formed by rectangles with rational side length and centered at points all of
whose coordinates are rational numbers. Clearly every second-countable space is also ï¬rst countable, but
the converse is false. For example if S is an inï¬nite non-countable set, the discrete topology is not second
countable, but S is ï¬rst countable, since {p} is a neighborhood of p âˆˆS. The trivial topology on S is second
countable (see Exercises 1.1-9 and 1.1-10 for more interesting counter-examples).
1.1.6 Lemma (LindelÂ¨ofâ€™s Lemma).
Every covering of a set A in a second countable space S by a family
of open sets Ua (i.e., âˆªaUa âŠƒA) contains a countable subcollection also covering A.
Proof.
Let B = {Bn} be a countable basis for the topology of S. For each p âˆˆA there are indices n and Î±
such that p âˆˆBn âŠ‚UÎ±. Let Bâ€² = { Bn | there exists an Î± such that Bn âŠ‚UÎ± }. Now let UÎ±(n) be one of the
UÎ± that includes the element Bn of Bâ€². Since Bâ€² is a covering of A, the countable collection {UÎ±(n)} covers
A.

Closure, Interior, and Boundary.
1.1.7 Deï¬nition.
Let S be a topological space and A âŠ‚S. The closure of A, denoted cl(A) is the
intersection of all closed sets containing A. The interior of A, denoted int(A) is the union of all open sets
contained in A. The boundary of A, denoted bd(A) is deï¬ned by
bd(A) = cl(A) âˆ©cl(S\A).
By C3, cl(A) is closed and by T3, int(A) is open. Note that as bd(A) is the intersection of closed sets,
bd(A) is closed, and bd(A) = bd(S\A).
On R, for example,
cl([0, 1[) = [0, 1],
int([0, 1[) = ]0, 1[,
and
bd([0, 1[) = {0, 1}.
The reader is assumed to be familiar with examples of this type from advanced calculus.
1.1.8 Deï¬nition.
A subset A of S is called dense in S if cl(A) = S, and is called nowhere dense if
S\ cl(A) is dense in S. The space S is called separable if it has a countable dense subset. A point u in S
is called an accumulation point of the set A if each neighborhood of u contains a point of A other than
itself. The set of accumulation points of A is called the derived set of A and is denoted by der(A). A point
of A is said to be isolated if it has a neighborhood in A containing no other points of A than itself.
The set A = [0, 1[ âˆª{2} in R has the element 2 as its only isolated point, its interior is int(A) = ]0, 1[,
cl(A) = [0, 1] âˆª{2}, and der(A) = [0, 1]. In the discrete topology on a set S, int{p} = cl{p} = {p}, for any
p âˆˆS.
Since the set Q of rational numbers is dense in R and is countable, R is separable. Similarly Rn is separable.
A set S with the trivial topology is separable since cl{p} = S for any p âˆˆS. But S = R with the discrete
topology is not separable since cl(A) = A for any A âŠ‚S. Any second-countable space is separable, but the
converse is false; see Exercises 1.1-9 and 1.1-10.

Convergence and Limit Points.
The notion of a convergent sequence carries over from calculus in a
straightforward way.
1.1.11 Deï¬nition.
Let S be a topological space and {un} a sequence of points in S. The sequence is said
to converge if there is a point u âˆˆS such that for every neighborhood U of u, there is an N such that
n â‰¥N implies un âˆˆU. We say that un converges to u, or u is a limit point of {un}.
For example, the sequence {1/n} âˆˆR converges to 0. It is obvious that limit points of sequences un of dis-
tinct points are accumulation points of the set {un}. In a ï¬rst countable topological space any accumulation
point of a set A is a limit of a sequence of elements of A. Indeed, if {Un} denotes the countable collection
of neighborhoods of a âˆˆder(A) given by Deï¬nition 1.1.5, then choosing for each n an element an âˆˆUn âˆ©A
such that an Ì¸= a, we see that {an} converges to a. We have proved the following.
1.1.12 Proposition.
Let S be a ï¬rst-countable space and A âŠ‚S. Then u âˆˆcl(A) iï¬€there is a sequence
of points of A that converges to u (in the topology of S).
Separation Axioms.
It should be noted that a sequence can be divergent and still have accumulation
points. For example {2, 0, 3/2, âˆ’1/2, 4/3, âˆ’2/3, . . . } does not converge but has both 1 and âˆ’1 as accumula-
tion points. In arbitrary topological spaces, limit points of sequences are in general not unique. For example,
in the trivial topology of S any sequence converges to all points of S. In order to avoid such situations
several separation axioms have been introduced, of which the three most important ones will be mentioned.
1.1.13 Deï¬nition.
A topological space S is called Hausdorï¬€if each two distinct points have disjoint
neighborhoods (i.e., with empty intersection). The space S is called regular if it is Hausdorï¬€and if each
closed set and point not in this set have disjoint neighborhoods. Similarly, S is called normal if it is
Hausdorï¬€and if each two disjoint closed sets have disjoint neighborhoods.
Most standard spaces that we meet in geometry and analysis are normal. The discrete topology on any
set is normal, but the trivial topology is not even Hausdorï¬€. It turns out that â€œHausdorï¬€â€ is the necessary
and suï¬ƒcient condition for uniqueness of limit points of sequences in ï¬rst countable spaces (see Exercise
1.1-5). Since in Hausdorï¬€space single points are closed (Exercise 1.1-6), we have the implications: normal
=â‡’regular =â‡’Hausdorï¬€. Counterexamples for each of the converses of these implications are given in
Exercises 1.1-9 and 1.1-10.
1.1.14 Proposition.
A regular second-countable space is normal.
Proof.

open neighborhoods Up of p and UB of B. Hence cl(Up) âˆ©B = âˆ…. Since { Up | p âˆˆA } is an open covering
of A, by the LindelÂ¨of lemma 1.1.6, there is a countable collection { Uk | k = 1, 2, . . . } covering A. Thus

Some Additional Set Theory.
For technical completeness we shall present the axiom of choice and an
equivalent result. These notions will be used occasionally in the text, but can be skipped on a ï¬rst reading.
Axiom of choice.
If S is a collection of nonempty sets, then there is a function
Ï‡ : S â†’

SâˆˆS
S
such
that
Ï‡(S) âˆˆS for every S âˆˆS.
The function Ï‡, called a choice function, chooses one element from each S âˆˆS. Even though this
statement seems self-evident, it has been shown to be equivalent to a number of nontrivial statements, using
other axioms of set theory. To discuss them, we need a few deï¬nitions. An order on a set A is a binary
relation, usually denoted by â€œâ‰¤â€ satisfying the following conditions:
a â‰¤a
(reï¬‚exivity),
a â‰¤b and b â‰¤a implies a = b
(antisymmetry), and
a â‰¤b and b â‰¤c implies a â‰¤c
(transitivity).
An ordered set A is called a chain if for every a, b âˆˆA, a Ì¸= b we have a â‰¤b or b â‰¤a. The set A is said
to be well ordered if it is a chain and every nonempty subset B has a ï¬rst element; i.e., there exists an
element b âˆˆB such that b â‰¤x for all x âˆˆB.
An upper bound u âˆˆA of a chain C âŠ‚A is an element for which c â‰¤u for all c âˆˆC. A maximal
element m of an ordered set A is an element for which there is no other a âˆˆA such that m â‰¤a, a Ì¸= m; in
other words x â‰¤m for all x âˆˆA that are comparable to m.
We state the following without proof.
Theorem.
Given other axioms of set theory, the following statements are equivalent:
(i) The axiom of choice.
(ii) Product Axiom. If {Ai}iâˆˆI is a collection of nonempty sets then the product space

iâˆˆI
Ai = { (xi) | xi âˆˆAi }
is nonempty.
(iii) Zermeloâ€™s Theorem. Any set can be well ordered.
(iv) Zornâ€™s Theorem. If A is an ordered set for which every chain has an upper bound (i.e., A is inductively
ordered), then A has at least one maximal element.

1.2
Metric Spaces
One of the common ways to form a topological space is through the use of a distance function, also called
a (topological) metric. For example, on Rn the standard distance
d(x, y) =

(xi âˆ’yi)2

between x = (x1, . . . , xn) and y = (y1, . . . , yn) can be used to construct the open disks and from them the
topology. The abstraction of this proceeds as follows.
1.2.1 Deï¬nition.
Let M be a set. A metric (also called a topological metric) on M is a function
d : M Ã— M â†’R such that for all m1, m2, m3 âˆˆM,
M1.
d(m1, m2) = 0 iï¬€m1 = m2 (deï¬niteness);
M2.

M3.
d(m1, m3) â‰¤d(m1, m2) + d(m2, m3) (triangle inequality).
A metric space is the pair (M, d); if there is no danger of confusion, just write M for (M, d).
Taking m1 = m3 in M3 shows that d(m1, m2) â‰¥0. It is proved in advanced calculus courses (and is
geometrically clear) that the standard distance on Rn satisï¬es M1â€“M3.

The Topology on a Metric Space.
The topology determined by a metric is deï¬ned as follows.

For Îµ > 0 and m âˆˆM, the open Îµ-ball (or disk) about m is deï¬ned by

The collection of subsets of M that are unions of open disks deï¬nes the metric topology of the metric
space (M, d).
Two metrics on a set are called equivalent if they induce the same metric topology.
1.2.3 Proposition.

(ii) A set U âŠ‚M is open iï¬€for each m âˆˆU there is an Îµ > 0 such that DÎµ(m) âŠ‚U.
Proof.

Notice that every set M can be made into a metric space by the discrete metric deï¬ned by setting
d(m, n) = 1 for all m Ì¸= n. The metric topology of M is the discrete topology.
Pseudometric Spaces.
A pseudometric on a set M is a function d : M Ã— M â†’R that satisï¬es M2,
M3, and
PM1.
d(m, m) = 0 for all m.
Thus the distance between distinct points can be zero for a pseudometric. The pseudometric topology is
deï¬ned exactly as the metric space topology. Any set M can be made into a pseudometric space by the
trivial pseudometric: d(m, n) = 0 for all m, n âˆˆM; the pseudometric topology on M is the trivial
topology. Note that a pseudometric space is Hausdorï¬€iï¬€it is a metric space.
Metric Spaces are Normal.
To show that metric spaces are normal, it will be useful to have the notion
of the distance from a point to a set. If M is a metric space (or pseudometric space) and u âˆˆM, A âŠ‚M,
we deï¬ne

diam(A) = sup { d(u, v) | u, v âˆˆA } .
A set is called bounded if its diameter is ï¬nite.

Proof.

Completeness.
We learn in calculus the importance of the notion of completeness of the real line. The
general notion of a complete metric space is as follows.
1.2.5 Deï¬nition.
Let M be a metric space with metric d and {un} a sequence in M. Then {un} is a
Cauchy sequence if for all real Îµ > 0, there is an integer N such that n, m â‰¥N implies d(un, um) < Îµ.
The space M is called complete if every Cauchy sequence converges.
We claim that a sequence {un} converges to u iï¬€for every Îµ > 0 there is an integer N such that n â‰¥N
implies d(un, u) < Îµ. This follows readily from the Deï¬nitions 1.1.11 and 1.2.2.
We also claim that a convergent sequence {un} is a Cauchy sequence. To see this, let Îµ > 0 be given.
Choose N such that n â‰¥N implies d(un, u) < Îµ/2. Thus, n, m â‰¥N implies
d(un, um) â‰¤d(un, u) + d(u, um) < Îµ
2 + Îµ
2 = Îµ
by the triangle inequality. Completeness requires that, conversely, every Cauchy sequence converges. A basic
fact about Rn is that with the standard metric, it is complete. The proof is found in any textbook on
advanced calculus.
Contraction Maps.
A key to many existence theorems in analysis is the following.
1.2.6 Theorem (Contraction Mapping Theorem).
Let M be a complete metric space and f : M â†’M a
mapping. Assume there is a constant k, where 0 â‰¤k < 1 such that
d(f(m), f(n)) â‰¤k d(m, n),
for all m, n âˆˆM; such an f is called a contraction. Then f has a unique ï¬xed point; that is, there exists
a unique mâˆ—âˆˆM such that f(mâˆ—) = mâˆ—.
Proof.
Let m0 be an arbitrary point of M and deï¬ne recursively mi+1 = f(mi), i = 0, 1, 2, . . . . Induction

1.3
Continuity
Deï¬nition of Continuity.
We learn about continuity in calculus. Its general setting in topological spaces
is as follows.
1.3.1 Deï¬nition.
Let S and T be topological spaces and Ï• : S â†’T be a mapping. We say that Ï• is
continuous at u âˆˆS if for every neighborhood V of Ï•(u) there is a neighborhood U of u such that
Ï•(U) âŠ‚V . If, for every open set V of T, Ï•âˆ’1(V ) = { u âˆˆS | Ï•(u) âˆˆV } is open in S, Ï• is continuous.
(Thus, Ï• is continuous if Ï• is continuous at each u âˆˆS.) If the map Ï• : S â†’T is a bijection (i.e.,
one-to-one and onto), and both Ï• and Ï•âˆ’1 are continuous, Ï• is called a homeomorphism and S and T
are said to be homeomorphic.
For example, notice that any map from a discrete topological space to any topological space is continuous.
Similarly, any map from an arbitrary topological space to the trivial topological space is continuous. Hence
the identity map from the set S topologized with the discrete topology to S with the trivial topology is
bijective and continuous, but its inverse is not continuous, hence it is not a homeomorphism.
Properties of Continuous Maps.
It follows from Deï¬nition 1.3.1, by taking complements and using
the set theoretic identity S\Ï•âˆ’1(A) = Ï•âˆ’1(T\A), that Ï• : S â†’T is continuous iï¬€the inverse image of every
closed set is closed. Here are additional properties of continuous maps.
1.3.2 Proposition.
Let S, T be topological spaces and Ï• : S â†’T. The following are equivalent:
(i) Ï• is continuous;
(ii) Ï•(cl(A)) âŠ‚cl(Ï•(A)) for every A âŠ‚S;
(iii) Ï•âˆ’1(int(B)) âŠ‚int(Ï•âˆ’1(B)) for every B âŠ‚T.
Proof.
If Ï• is continuous, then Ï•âˆ’1(cl(Ï•(A))) is closed. But
A âŠ‚Ï•âˆ’1(cl(Ï•(A))),
and hence
cl(A) âŠ‚Ï•âˆ’1(cl(Ï•(A))),
that is, Ï•(cl(A)) âŠ‚cl(Ï•(A)). Conversely, let B âŠ‚T be closed and A = Ï•âˆ’1(B). Then
cl(A) âŠ‚Ï•âˆ’1(B) = A,
so A is closed. A similar argument shows that (ii) and (iii) are equivalent.

Open and Closed Maps.
Continuity is deï¬ned by requiring that inverse images of open (closed) sets
are open (closed). In many situations it is important to ask whether the image of an open (closed) set is
open (closed).
1.3.7 Deï¬nition.
A map Ï• : S â†’T, where S and T are topological spaces, is called open (resp., closed)
if the image of every open (resp., closed) set in S is open (resp., closed) in T.
Thus, a homeomorphism is a bijective continuous open (closed) map.
An example of an open map that is not closed is
Ï• : ]0, 1[ â†’R,
x â†’x,
the inclusion map. An example of a closed map that is not open is
Ï• : R â†’R,
deï¬ned by x â†’x2
which maps ]âˆ’1, 1[ to [0, 1[. An example of a map that is neither open nor closed is the map
Ï• : ]âˆ’1, 1[â†’R,
deï¬ned by x â†’x2.
Finally, note that the identity map of a set S topologized with the trivial and discrete topologies on the
domain and range, respectively, is not continuous but is both open and closed.

Uniform Continuity and Convergence.
In a metric space we also have the notions of uniform conti-
nuity and uniform convergence.
1.3.9 Deï¬nition.
(i) Let (M1, d1) and (M2, d2) be metric spaces and Ï• : M1 â†’M2. We say Ï•
is uniformly continuous if for every Îµ > 0 there is a Î´ > 0 such that d1(u, v) < Î´ implies
d2(Ï•(u), Ï•(v)) < Îµ.
(ii) Let S be a set, M a metric space, Ï•n : S â†’M, n = 1, 2, . . . , and Ï• : S â†’M be given mappings. We
say Ï•n â†’Ï• uniformly if for every Îµ > 0 there is an N such that d(Ï•n(u), Ï•(u)) < Îµ for all n â‰¥N
and all u âˆˆS.
For example, a map satisfying d(Ï•(u), Ï•(v)) â‰¤Kd(u, v) for a constant K is uniformly continuous. Uniform
continuity and uniform convergence ideas come up in the construction of a metric on the space of continuous
maps. This is considered next.
1.3.10 Proposition.
Let M be a topological space and (N, d) a complete metric space. Then the collection

1.4
Subspaces, Products, and Quotients
This section concerns the construction of new topological spaces from old ones.
Subset Topology.
The ï¬rst basic operation of this type we consider is the formation of subset topologies.
1.4.1 Deï¬nition.
If A is a subset of a topological space S with topology O, the relative topology on A
is deï¬ned by OA = {U âˆ©A | U âˆˆO} .
In other words, the open subsets in A are declared to be those subsets that are intersections of open sets
in S with A. The following identities show that OA is indeed a topology:
(i) âˆ…âˆ©A = âˆ…, S âˆ©A = A;
(ii) (U1 âˆ©A) âˆ©(U2 âˆ©A) = (U1 âˆ©U2) âˆ©A; and
(iii) 

Î± UÎ±) âˆ©A.
Example.
The topology on the n âˆ’1-dimensional sphere Snâˆ’1 = { x âˆˆRn | d(x, 0) = 1 } is the relative
topology induced from Rn; that is, a neighborhood of a point x âˆˆSnâˆ’1 is a subset of Snâˆ’1 containing the
set DÎµ(x) âˆ©Snâˆ’1 for some Îµ > 0. Note that an open (closed) set in the relative topology of A is in general
not open (closed) in S. For example, DÎµ(x) âˆ©Snâˆ’1 is open in Snâˆ’1 but it is neither open nor closed in Rn.
However, if A is open (closed) in S, then any open (closed) set in the relative topology is also open (closed)
in S.
If Ï• : S â†’T is a continuous mapping, then the restriction Ï•|A : A â†’T is also continuous in the relative
topology. The converse is false. For example, the mapping Ï• : R â†’R deï¬ned by Ï•(x) = 0 if x âˆˆQ and
Ï•(x) = 1 if x âˆˆR\Q is discontinuous, but Ï•|Q : Q â†’R is a constant mapping and is thus continuous.

The product topology on S Ã— T consists of all subsets that are unions of sets which have the form U Ã— V,
where U is open in S and V is open in T. Thus, these open rectangles form a basis for the topology.

1.5
Compactness
Some basic theorems of calculus, such as â€œevery real valued continuous function on [a, b] attains its maximum
and minimumâ€ implicitly use the fact that [a, b] is compact.
Deï¬nition of Compactness.
The general deï¬nition of compactness is rather unintuitive at the beginning.
In fact, the general formulation of compactness and the realization of it as a useful tool is one of the excellent
achievements of topology. But one has to be patient to see the rewards of formulating the deï¬nition the way
it is done.
1.5.1 Deï¬nition.
Let S be a topological space. Then S is called compact if for every covering of S by
open sets UÎ± (i.e., 
Î± UÎ± = S) there is a ï¬nite subcollection of the UÎ± also covering S. A subset A âŠ‚S is
called compact if A is compact in the relative topology. A subset A is called relatively compact if cl(A)
is compact. A space is called locally compact if it is Hausdorï¬€and each point has a relatively compact
neighborhood.
Properties of Compactness.
We shall soon see the true power of this notion, but lets work up to this
with some simple observations.
1.5.2 Proposition.
(i) If S is compact and A âŠ‚S is closed, then A is compact.
(ii) If Ï• : S â†’T is continuous and S is compact, then Ï•(S) is compact.
Proof.
(i) Let {UÎ±} be an open covering of A. Then {UÎ±, S\A} is an open covering of S and hence
contains a ï¬nite subcollection of this covering also covering S. The elements of this collection, except
S\A, cover A.
(ii) Let {UÎ±} be an open covering of Ï•(S). Then {Ï•âˆ’1(UÎ±)} is an open covering of S and thus by compact-
ness of S a ï¬nite subcollection { Ï•âˆ’1(UÎ±(i)) | i = 1, . . . , n }, covers S. But then {UÎ±(i)}, i = 1, . . . , n
covers Ï•(S) and thus Ï•(S) is compact.
â– 
In a Hausdorï¬€space, compact subsets are closed (exercise). Thus if S is compact, T is Hausdorï¬€and Ï•
is continuous, then Ï• is closed; if Ï• is also bijective, then it is a homeomorphism.
Compactness of Products.
It is a basic fact that the product of compact spaces is compact.

A product space S Ã— T is compact iï¬€both S and T are compact.

open in S and T, respectively. Let {UÎ² Ã— VÎ²} be a covering of S Ã— T by open rectangles. If we show that
there exists a ï¬nite subcollection of UÎ² Ã— VÎ² covering S Ã— T, then clearly also a ï¬nite subcollection of {AÎ±}
will cover S Ã— T.

Total Boundedness.
A property that came up in the preceding proof turns out to be important.
1.5.5 Deï¬nition.
Let S be a metric space. A subset A âŠ‚S is called totally bounded if for any Îµ > 0
there exists a ï¬nite set {p1, . . . , pn} in S such that
A âŠ‚

DÎµ(pi).
1.5.6 Corollary.
A metric space is compact iï¬€it is complete and totally bounded. A subset of a complete
metric space is relatively compact iï¬€it is totally bounded.
Proof.
The previous proof shows that compactness implies total boundedness. As for compactness im-
plying completeness, it is enough to remark that in this context, a Cauchy sequence having a convergent
subsequence is itself convergent. Conversely, if S is complete and totally bounded, let { pn | n = 1, 2, . . . } be
a sequence in S. By total boundedness, this sequence contains a Cauchy subsequence, which by complete-
ness, converges. Thus S is compact by the Bolzanoâ€“Weierstrass theorem. The second statement now readily
follows.

Heineâ€“Borel Theorem.
This result makes it easy to spot compactness in Euclidean spaces.
1.5.9 Theorem (Heineâ€“Borel Theorem).
In Rn a closed and bounded set is compact.
Proof.

1. Topology
1.6
Connectedness
Three types of connectedness treated in this section are arcwise connectedness, connectedness, and simple
connectedness.
Arcwise Connectedness.
We begin with the most intuitive notion of connectedness.
1.6.1 Deï¬nition.
Let S be a topological space and I = [0, 1] âŠ‚R. An arc Ï• in S is a continuous mapping
Ï• : I â†’S. If Ï•(0) = u, Ï•(1) = v, we say Ï• joins u and v; S is called arcwise connected if every two
points in S can be joined by an arc in S. A space S is called locally arcwise connected if for each point
x âˆˆS and each neighborhood U of x, there is a neighborhood V of x such that any pair of points in V can
be joined by an arc in U.
For example, Rn is arcwise and locally arcwise connected: any two points of Rn can be joined by the
straight line segment connecting them. A set A âŠ‚Rn is called convex if this property holds for any two of
its points. Thus, convex sets in Rn are arcwise and locally arcwise connected. A set with the trivial topology
is arcwise and locally arcwise connected, but in the discrete topology it is neither (unless it has only one
point).
Connected Spaces.
Less intuitive is the basic notion of connectedness.
1.6.2 Deï¬nition.
A topological space S is connected if âˆ…and S are the only subsets of S that are both
open and closed. A subset of S is connected if it is connected in the relative topology. A component A of
S is a nonempty connected subset of S such that the only connected subset of S containing A is A itself; S is
called locally connected if each point has a connected neighborhood. The components of a subset T âŠ‚S
are the components of T in the relative topology of T in S.
For example, Rn and any convex subset of Rn are connected and locally connected. The union of two
disjoint open convex sets is disconnected but is locally connected; its components are the two convex sets. The
trivial topology is connected and locally connected, whereas the discrete topology is neither: its components
are all the one-point sets.
Connected spaces are characterized by the following.
1.6.3 Proposition.
The following are equivalent:
(i) S is not connected;
(ii) there is a nonempty proper subset of S that is both open and closed;
(iii) S is the disjoint union of two nonempty open sets; and
(iv) S is the disjoint union of two nonempty closed sets.
The sets in (iii) or (iv) are said to disconnect S.
Proof.
To prove that (i) implies (ii), assume there is a nonempty proper set A that is both open and
closed. Then S = Aâˆª(S\A) with A, S\A open and nonempty. Conversely, if S = AâˆªB with A, B open and
nonempty, then A is also closed, and thus A is a proper nonempty set of S that is both open and closed.
The equivalences of the remaining assertions are similarly checked.
â–

Connectedness is preserved by continuous maps, as is shown next.
1.6.4 Proposition.
If f : S â†’T is a continuous map of topological spaces and S is connected (resp.,
arcwise connected) then so is f(S).

1.6.5 Lemma.
The only connected sets of R are the intervals (ï¬nite, inï¬nite, open, closed, or half-open).

Intermediate Value Theorem.
Connectedness provides a general context for this theorem learned in
calculus.
1.6.8 Theorem (Intermediate Value Theorem).
Let S be a connected space and f : S â†’R be continuous.
Then f assumes every value between any two values f(u) and f(v).
Proof.
Suppose f(u) < a < f(v) and f does not assume the value a. Then the set U = { u0 | f(u0) < a }
is both open and closed.

An alternative proof uses the fact that f(S) is connected in R and therefore is an interval.

Simple Connectivity.
This notion means, intuitively, that loops can be continuously shrunk to points.
1.6.12 Deï¬nition.
Let S be a topological space and c : [0, 1] â†’S a continuous map such that c(0) =
c(1) = p âˆˆS. We call c a loop in S based at p. The loop c is called contractible if there is a continuous
map H : [0, 1] Ã— [0, 1] â†’S such that H(t, 0) = c(t) and H(0, s) = H(1, s) = H(t, 1) = p for all t âˆˆ[0, 1].
(See Figure 1.6.1.)
Figure 1.6.1. The loop c is contractible
We think of cs(t) = H(t, s) as a family of arcs connecting c0 = c to c1, a constant arc; see Figure 1.6.1.
Roughly speaking, a loop is contractible when it can be shrunk continuously to p by loops beginning and
ending at p. The study of loops leads naturally to homotopy theory. In fact, the loops at p can, by successively
traversing them, be made into a group called the fundamental group; see Exercise 1.6-6.

1.6 Connectedness
29
1.6.13 Deï¬nition.
A space S is simply connected if S is connected and every loop in S is contractible.
In the plane R2 there is an alternative approach to simple connectedness, by way of the Jordan curve the-
orem; namely, that every simple (nonintersecting) loop in R2 divides R2 (divides means that its complement
has two components). The bounded component of the complement is called the interior, and a subset A of
R2 is simply connected iï¬€the interior of every loop in A lies in A.
Alexandroï¬€â€™s Theorem.
We close this section with an optional theorem sometimes used in Riemannian
geometry (to show that a Riemannian manifold is second countable) that illustrates the interplay between
various notions introduced in this chapter.
1.6.14 Theorem (Alexandroï¬€â€™s Theorem).
An arcwise connected locally compact metric space is separa-
ble and hence is second countable.
Proof (Pï¬‚uger [1957]).
Since the metric space M is locally compact, each m âˆˆM has compact neighbor-
hoods that are disks. Denote by r(m) the least upper bound of the radii of such disks. If r(m) = âˆ, since
every metric space is ï¬rst countable, M can be written as a countable union of compact disks. But since
each compact metric space is separable (Exercise 1.5-2), these disks and also their union will be separable,
and so the proposition is proved in this case. If r(m0) < âˆ, since r(m) â‰¤r(m0) + d(m, m0), we see that
r(m) < âˆfor all m âˆˆM. By the preceding argument, if we show that M is a countable union of compact
sets, the proposition is proved. Then second countability will follow from Exercise 1.2-3.

2
Banach Spaces and Diï¬€erential Calculus
Manifolds have enough structure to allow diï¬€erentiation of maps between them. To set the stage for these
concepts requires a development of diï¬€erential calculus in linear spaces from a geometric point of view. The
goal of this chapter is to provide this perspective.
Perhaps the most important theorem for later use is the Implicit Function Theorem. A fairly detailed
exposition of this topic will be given with examples appropriate for use in manifold theory. The basic
language of tangents, the derivative as a linear map, and the chain rule, while elementary, are important for
developing geometric and analytic skills needed in manifold theory.
The main goal is to develop the theory of ï¬nite-dimensional manifolds. However, it is instructive and eï¬ƒ-
cient to do the inï¬nite-dimensional theory simultaneously. To avoid being sidetracked by inï¬nite-dimensional
technicalities at this stage, some functional analysis background and other topics special to the inï¬nite-
dimensional case are presented in supplements. With this arrangement readers who wish to concentrate on
the ï¬nite-dimensional theory can do so with a minimum of distraction.
2.1
Banach Spaces
It is assumed the reader is familiar with the concept of a real or complex vector space. Banach spaces are
vector spaces with the additional structure of a norm that deï¬nes a complete metric space. While most of
this book is concerned with ï¬nite-dimensional spaces, much of the theory is really no harder in the general
case, and the inï¬nite-dimensional case is needed for certain applications. Thus, it makes sense to work in the
setting of Banach spaces. In addition, although the primary concern is with real Banach spaces, the basic
concepts needed for complex Banach spaces are introduced with little extra eï¬€ort.
Normed Spaces.
We begin with the notion of a normed space; that is, a space in which one has a length
measure for vectors.

Normed Spaces are Metric Spaces.
We have seen that inner product spaces are normed spaces. Now
we show that normed spaces are metric spaces.
2.1.6 Proposition.
Let (E, âˆ¥Â·âˆ¥) be a normed (resp. a seminormed) space and deï¬ne d(e1, e2) = âˆ¥e1âˆ’e2âˆ¥.

Proof.
The only non-obvious veriï¬cation is the triangle inequality for the metric. By N3, we have
d(e1, e3) = âˆ¥e1 âˆ’e3âˆ¥= âˆ¥(e1 âˆ’e2) + (e2 âˆ’e3)âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥e1 âˆ’e2âˆ¥+ âˆ¥e2 âˆ’e3âˆ¥
= d(e1, e2) + d(e2, e3).

Banach and Hilbert Spaces.
Now we are ready to add the crucial assumption of completeness.
2.1.7 Deï¬nition.
Let (E, âˆ¥Â· âˆ¥) be a normed space. If the corresponding metric d is complete, we say
(E, âˆ¥Â·âˆ¥) is a Banach space. If (E, âŸ¨Â·, Â·âŸ©) is an inner product space whose corresponding metric is complete,
we say (E, âŸ¨Â·, Â·âŸ©) is a Hilbert space.

2.1.14 Deï¬nition.
The closed subspace F of the Banach space E is said to be split, or complemented,
if there is a closed subspace G âŠ‚E such that E = F âŠ•G.
The relation between split subspaces and quotients is simple: the projection map of E to G induces, in
a natural way, a Banach space isomorphism of E/F with G. We leave this as a veriï¬cation for the reader.
One should note, however, that the quotient E/F is deï¬ned independent of any choice of split subspace and
that, accordingly, the choice of G is not unique.
1This quotient is the same as the quotient in the sense discussed in Chapter 1, with the equivalence relation being u âˆ¼v iï¬€
u âˆ’v âˆˆF, so that the equivalence class of u is the set u + F.

Supplement 2.1B
Split Subspaces
Deï¬nition 2.1.14 implicitly asks that the topology of E coincide with the product topology of F âŠ•G. We
shall show in Supplement 2.2C that this topological condition can be dropped; that is, F is split iï¬€E is the
algebraic direct sum of F and the closed subspace G.
As we noted above, if E = F âŠ•G then G is isomorphic to E/F. However, F need not split for E/F to
be a Banach space, as we proved in Proposition 2.1.13. In ï¬nite-dimensional spaces, any subspace is closed
and splits; however, in inï¬nite dimensions this is false. For example, let E = Lp(S1) and let
F = { f âˆˆE | f(n) = 0 for n < 0 },
where
f(n) = 1
2Ï€

Riesz (Theorem 17.26 of Rudin [1966]) but does not split in E for p = 1 (Example 5.19 of Rudin [1973]).
The same result holds if E = C0(S1, C) and F has the same deï¬nition.
Another example worth mentioning is E = â„“âˆ, the Banach space of all bounded sequences, and F = c0, the
subspace of â„“âˆconsisting of all sequences convergent to zero. The subspace F = c0 is closed in E = â„“âˆ, but
does not split. However, c0 splits in any separable Banach space which contains it isomorphically as a closed
subspace by a theorem of Sobczyk; see Veech [1971]. If every subspace of a Banach space is complemented, the
space must be isomorphic to a Hilbert space by a result of Lindenstrauss and Tzafriri [1971]. Supplement
2.2B gives some general criteria useful in nonlinear analysis for a subspace to be split. But the simplest
situation occurs in Hilbert spaces.

2.2
Linear and Multilinear Mappings
This section deals with various aspects of linear and multilinear maps between Banach spaces. We begin
with a study of continuity and go on to study spaces of continuous linear and multilinear maps and some
related fundamental theorems of linear analysis.

2. Banach Spaces and Diï¬€erential Calculus
Continuity and Boundedness.
We begin by showing for a linear map, the equivalence of continuity
and possessing a certain bound.
2.2.1 Proposition.

Dual Spaces
Riesz Representation Theorem.
Recall from elementary linear algebra that the dual space of a ï¬nite
dimensional vector space of dimension n also has dimension n and so the space and its dual are isomorphic.
For general Banach spaces this is no longer true. However, it is true for Hilbert space.

52
2. Banach Spaces and Diï¬€erential Calculus

Permutations.
We shall need a few facts about the permutation group on k elements. The information
we cite is obtainable from virtually any elementary algebra book. The permutation group on k elements,
denoted Sk, consists of all bijections Ïƒ : {1, . . . , k} â†’{1, . . . , k} together with the structure of a group under
composition. Clearly, Sk has order k!, that is, Sk has k! elements.
One of the more subtle but very useful properties of permutations is the notion of the sign of a permutation.
Letting (R, Ã—) denote R\{0} with the multiplicative group structure, the sign is a homomorphism
sign : Sk â†’(R, Ã—).
Being a homomorphism means that for Ïƒ, Ï„ âˆˆSk,
sign(Ïƒ â—¦Ï„) = (sign Ïƒ)(sign Ï„).
The image of â€œsignâ€ is the subgroup {âˆ’1, 1}, while its kernel consists of the subgroup of even permutations.
Thus, a permutation Ïƒ is even when sign Ïƒ = +1 and is odd when sign Ïƒ = âˆ’1.
The sign of a permutation is perhaps easiest to understand in terms of transpositions. A transposition is
a permutation that swaps two elements of {1, . . . , k}, leaving the remainder ï¬xed. An even (odd) permutation
can be written as the product of an even (odd) number of transpositions.
The group Sk acts on the space Lk(E; F); that is, each Ïƒ âˆˆSk deï¬nes a map Ïƒ : Lk(E; F) â†’Lk(E; F)
by
(ÏƒA)(e1, . . . , ek) = A(eÏƒ(1), . . . , eÏƒ(k)).
Note that (Ï„Ïƒ)A = Ï„(ÏƒA) for all Ï„, Ïƒ âˆˆSk. Accordingly, A âˆˆLk(E, F) is called symmetric (antisymmet-
ric) if for any permutation Ïƒ âˆˆSk, ÏƒA = A (resp., ÏƒA = (sign Ïƒ)A.)

The Three Pillars of Linear Analysis
The three fundamental theorems of linear analysis are the Hahnâ€“Banach theorem, the open mapping theorem,
and the uniform boundedness principle. See, for example, Banach [1932] and Riesz and Sz.-Nagy [1952] for
further information. This supplement gives the classical proofs of these three fundamental theorems and
derives some corollaries that will be used later. In ï¬nite dimensions these corollaries are all â€œobvious.â€

An important consequence is the following.
2.2.16 Theorem (Banachâ€™s Isomorphism Theorem).
A continuous linear isomorphism of Banach spaces
is a homeomorphism.
Thus, if F and G are closed subspaces of the Banach space E and E is the algebraic direct sum of F and G,
then the mapping (e, eâ€²) âˆˆF Ã— G â†’e + eâ€² âˆˆE is a continuous isomorphism, and hence a homeomorphism;
that is, E = F âŠ•G; this proves the comment at the beginning of Supplement 2.1B.
Closed Graph Theorem.
This result characterizes continuity by closedness of the graph of a linear map.
2.2.17 Theorem (Closed Graph Theorem).
Suppose that E and F are Banach spaces. A linear map A :
E â†’F is continuous iï¬€its graph
Î“A = { (e, Ae) âˆˆE Ã— F | e âˆˆE }
is a closed subspace of E âŠ•F.
Proof.
It is readily veriï¬ed that Î“A is a linear subspace of E âŠ•F. If A âˆˆL(E, F), then Î“A is closed
(see Exercise 1.4-2). Conversely, if Î“A is closed, then it is a Banach subspace of E âŠ•F, and since the
mapping (e, Ae) âˆˆÎ“A â†’e âˆˆE is a continuous isomorphism, its inverse e âˆˆE â†’(e, Ae) âˆˆÎ“A is also
continuous by Theorem 2.2.16. Since (e, Ae) âˆˆÎ“A â†’Ae âˆˆF is clearly continuous, so is the composition
e â†’(e, Ae) â†’Ae.

continuous for E and F Banach spaces, it suï¬ƒces to show that if en â†’0 and Aen â†’eâ€², then eâ€² = 0.
2.2.18 Corollary.
Let E be a Banach space and F a closed subspace of E. Then F is split iï¬€there exists
P âˆˆL(E, E) such that P â—¦P = P and F = { e âˆˆE | Pe = e }.

2.3.5 Proposition (Linearity of the Derivative).
Let f, g : U âŠ‚E â†’F be r times diï¬€erentiable mappings
and a a real (or complex) constant. Then af and f + g : U âŠ‚E â†’F are r times diï¬€erentiable with
Dr(f + g) = Drf + Drg
and
Dr(af) = aDrf.
Proof.
If u âˆˆU and e âˆˆE, then
f(u + e) = f(u) + Df(u) Â· e + o(e) and
g(u + e) = g(u) + Dg(u) Â· e + o(e),
so that adding these two relations yields
(f + g)(u + e) = (f + g)(u) + (Df(u) + Dg(u)) Â· e + o(e).
The case r > 1 follows by induction. Similarly,
af(u + e) = af(u) + aDf(u) Â· e + ao(e) = af(u) + aDf(u) Â· e + o(e).

The Gradient and Diï¬€erential.
It should be emphasized that Df assigns a linear mapping to each
x âˆˆU and the deï¬nition of Df(x) is independent of the basis used. If we change the basis from the standard

of a linear transformation, it can be seen that the columns of the matrix relative to the new basis will be
the derivative Df(x) applied to the new basis in Rn with this image vector expressed in the new basis in
Rm. Of course, the linear map Df(x) itself does not change from basis to basis. In the case m = 1, Df(x)
is, in the standard basis, a 1 Ã— n matrix. The vector whose components are the same as those of Df(x) is
called the gradient of f, and is denoted grad f or âˆ‡f. Thus for f : U âŠ‚Rn â†’R,

Chain Rule.
Perhaps the most important rule of diï¬€erential calculus is the chain rule. To facilitate its
statement, the notion of the tangent of a map is introduced. The text will begin conceptually distinguishing
points in U from vectors in E. At this point it is not so clear that the distinction is important, but it will
help with the transition to manifolds in Chapter 3.

The Functional Derivative and the Calculus of Variations
Diï¬€erential calculus in inï¬nite dimensions has many applications, one of which is to the calculus of variations.
We give some of the elementary aspects here. We shall begin with some notation and a generalization of the
notion of the dual space.
Duality and Pairings.
Let E and F be Banach spaces. A continuous bilinear functional âŸ¨, âŸ©: EÃ—F â†’R
is called E-non-degenerate if âŸ¨x, yâŸ©= 0 for all y âˆˆF implies x = 0. Similarly, it is F-non-degenerate if
âŸ¨x, yâŸ©= 0 for all x âˆˆE implies y = 0. If it is both, we just say âŸ¨, âŸ©is non-degenerate. Equivalently, the
two linear maps of E to Fâˆ—and F to Eâˆ—deï¬ned by x â†’âŸ¨x, Â·âŸ©and y â†’âŸ¨Â·, yâŸ©, respectively, are one to one.
If they are isomorphisms, âŸ¨, âŸ©is called E- or F-strongly non-degenerate. A non-degenerate bilinear form
âŸ¨, âŸ©thus represents certain linear functionals on F in terms of elements in E. We say E and F are in duality
if there is a non-degenerate bilinear functional âŸ¨, âŸ©: E Ã— F â†’R, also called a pairing of E with F. If the
functional is strongly non-degenerate, we say the duality is strong.

2.4.26 Deï¬nition.
Let f : U âŠ‚E â†’R be a continuous function, U open in E. We say f has a local
minimum (resp., maximum at u0 âˆˆU, if there is a neighborhood V of u0, V âŠ‚U such that f(u0) â‰¤f(u)
(resp., f(u0) â‰¥f(u)) for all u âˆˆV . If the inequality is strict, u0 is called a strict local minimum
(resp., maximum). The point u0 is called a global minimum (resp., maximum) if f(u0) â‰¤f(u) (resp.,
f(u0) â‰¥f(u)) for all u âˆˆU. Local maxima and minima are called local extrema.

2.5
The Inverse and Implicit Function Theorems
The inverse and implicit function theorems are pillars of nonlinear analysis and geometry, so we give them
special attention in this section. Throughout, E, F, . . . , are assumed to be Banach spaces. In the ï¬nite-
dimensional case these theorems have a long and complex history; the inï¬nite-dimensional version is appar-
ently due to Hildebrandt and Graves [1927].

102
2. Banach Spaces and Diï¬€erential Calculus
The Inverse Function Theorem.
This theorem states that if the linearization of the equation f(x) = y
is uniquely invertible, then locally so is f; that is, we can uniquely solve f(x) = y for x as a function of y.
To formulate the theorem, the following terminology is useful.
2.5.1 Deï¬nition.
A map f : U âŠ‚E â†’V âŠ‚F, where U and V are open subsets of E and F respectively,
is a Cr diï¬€eomorphism if f is of class Cr, is a bijection (i.e., f is one-to-one and onto from U to V ),
and f âˆ’1 is also of class Cr.
The example f(x) = x3 shows that a map can be smooth and bijective, but its inverse need not be smooth.
A theorem guaranteeing a smooth inverse is the following.
2.5.2 Theorem (Inverse Mapping Theorem).
Let f : U âŠ‚E â†’F be of class Cr, r â‰¥1, x0 âˆˆU, and
suppose that Df(x0) is a linear isomorphism. Then f is a Cr diï¬€eomorphism of some neighborhood of x0
onto some neighborhood of f(x0) and, moreover, the derivative of the inverse function is given by
Df âˆ’1(y) = [Df(f âˆ’1(y))]âˆ’1
for y in this neighborhood of f(x0).
Although our immediate interest is the ï¬nite-dimensional case, for Banach spaces it is good to keep in
mind the Banach isomorphism theorem: If T : E â†’F is linear, bijective, and continuous, then T âˆ’1 is
continuous. (See Theorem 2.2.19.)
Proof of the Inverse Function Theorem.
To prove the theorem, we assemble a few lemmas. First
recall the contraction mapping principle from Â§1.2.
2.5.3 Lemma.
Let M be a complete metric space with distance function d : M Ã—M â†’R. Let F : M â†’M
and assume there is a constant Î», 0 â‰¤Î» < 1, such that for all x, y âˆˆM,
d(F(x), F(y)) â‰¤Î»d(x, y).
Then F has a unique ï¬xed point x0 âˆˆM; that is, F(x0) = x0.
This result is the basis of many important existence theorems in analysis. The other fundamental ï¬xed
point theorem in analysis is the Schauder ï¬xed point theorem, which states that a continuous map of a
compact convex set (in a Banach space, say) to itself, has a ï¬xed pointâ€”not necessarily unique, however.

2.5.8 Corollary.
Let U âŠ‚E be open and f : U â†’F be Cr, r â‰¥1. Suppose Df(x0) is surjective and
ker Df(x0) is complemented. Then f(U) contains a neighborhood of f(x0).

hypotheses of Theorem 2.5.7 are satisï¬ed and thus f(U) contains W0 provided by that theorem.
â– 
Local Surjectivity Theorem.
Since in ï¬nite-dimensional spaces every subspace splits, the foregoing
corollary implies that if f : U âŠ‚Rn â†’Rm, n â‰¥m, and the Jacobian of f at every point of U has rank m,
then f is an open mapping. This statement generalizes directly to Banach spaces, but it is not a consequence
of the implicit function theorem anymore, since not every subspace is split. This result goes back to Graves
[1950]. The proof given in Supplement 2.5B follows Luenberger [1969].
2.5.9 Theorem (Local Surjectivity Theorem).
If f : U âŠ‚E â†’F is C1 and Df(u0) is onto for some
u0 âˆˆU, then f is locally onto; that is, there exist open neighborhoods U1 of u0 and V1 of f(u0) such that
f|U1 : U1 â†’V1 is onto. In particular, if Df(u) is onto for all u âˆˆU, then f is an open mapping.

The local surjectivity theorem shows that for y near y0 = f(u0), f(x) = y has a solution. If there is a
solution g(y) = x which is C1, then Df(x0) â—¦Dg(y0) = I and so range Dg(y0) is an algebraic complement
to ker Df(x0). It follows that if range Dg(y0) is closed, then ker Df(x0) is split.
In many applications to nonlinear partial diï¬€erential equations, methods of functional analysis and elliptic
operators can be used to show that ker Df(x0) does split, even in Banach spaces. Such a splitting theorem
is called the Fredholm alternative. For illustrations of this idea in geometry and relativity, see Fischer and
Marsden [1975, 1979], and in elasticity, see Chapter 6 of Marsden and Hughes [1983]. For such applications,
Corollary 2.5.8 often suï¬ƒces.

Notice that this proof is done by direct estimates, and not by invoking the inverse or implicit function

To use Theorem 2.5.12 (or Theorem 2.5.13) in ï¬nite dimensions, we must have the rank of Df equal to the
dimension of its domain space (or the range space). However, we can also use the inverse function theorem

Roughly speaking, in ï¬nite dimensions, the rank theorem says that if Df has constant rank k on an open
set in Rm, then m âˆ’k variables are redundant and can be eliminated. As a simple example, if f : R2 â†’R is
deï¬ned by setting f(x, y) = xâˆ’y, then Df has rank 1, and indeed, we can express f using just one variable,
namely, let Ïˆ(x, y) = (x + y, y) so that (f â—¦Ïˆ)(x, y) = x, which depends only on x.

theorem guarantee that a Ck map f between Banach spaces is a global diï¬€eomorphism. To get a feel for
these supplementary conditions, consider a Ck function f : R â†’R, k â‰¥1, satisfying 1/|f â€²(x)| < M for
all x âˆˆR. Then f is a local diï¬€eomorphism at every point of R and thus is an open map. In particular,
f(R) is an open interval ]a, b[. The condition |f â€²(x)| > 1/M implies that f is either strictly increasing or
strictly decreasing. Let us assume that f is strictly increasing. If b < +âˆ, then the line y = b is a horizontal
asymptote of the graph of f and therefore we should have limxâ†’âˆf â€²(x) = 0 contradicting |f â€²(x)| > 1/M.
One similarly shows that a = âˆ’âˆand the same proof works if f â€²(x) < âˆ’1/M. The theorem below generalizes
this result to the case of Banach spaces.
2.5.17 Theorem (The Hadamardâ€“Levy Theorem).
Let f : E â†’F be a Ck map of Banach spaces, k â‰¥1.
If Df(x) is an isomorphism of E with F for every x âˆˆE and if there is a constant M > 0 such that
âˆ¥Df(x)âˆ’1âˆ¥< M for all x âˆˆE, then f is a diï¬€eomorphism.
The key to the proof of the theorem consists of a homotopy lifting argument. If X is a topological space,
a continuous map Ï• : X â†’F is said to lift to E through f, if there is a continuous map Ïˆ : X â†’E
satisfying f â—¦Ïˆ = Ï•.

Proof of Theorem 2.5.17.
Let y0, y âˆˆF and consider the path Î³(t) = (1 âˆ’t)y0 + ty. Regarding Î³ as
deï¬ned on [0, 1] Ã— [0, 1], independent of the second variable, the homotopy lifting lemma guarantees the
existence of a C1 path Î´ : [0, 1] â†’E lifting Î³, that is, f â—¦Î´ = Î³. In particular, f(Î´(1)) = Î³(1) = y and thus
f is surjective.
To show that f is injective, assume x1 Ì¸= x2, f(x1) = f(x2), and consider the path Î´(t) = (1 âˆ’t)x1 + tx2.
Then Î³(t) = f(Î´(t)). By the homotopy lifting lemma, there exists a lift K of H through f. From f â—¦K = H
it follows that the continuous curve s â†’K(0, s) is mapped by f to the point f(x1), thus contradicting the
inverse function theorem.
Therefore f is a bijective map which is a local diï¬€eomorphism around every point, that is, f is a diï¬€eo-
morphism of E with F.

Remarks.
(i)
The uniform bound on âˆ¥Df(x)âˆ’1âˆ¥can be replaced by properness of the map, that is,
if f(xn) â†’y there exists a convergent subsequence {xm}, xm â†’x with f(x) = y (see Exercise
1.5-10). Indeed, the only place where the uniform bound on âˆ¥Df(x)âˆ’1âˆ¥was used is in the homotopy
lifting lemma in the argument that Î± = sup A âˆˆA. If f is proper, this is shown in the following
way. Let {t(n)} be an increasing sequence in A converging to Î±. Then H(t(n), s) â†’H(Î±, s) and from
f â—¦K = H on [0, Î±[ Ã— [0, 1], it follows that f(K(t(m), s)) â†’H(Î±, s) uniformly in s âˆˆ[0, 1]. Thus, by
properness of f, there is a subsequence {t(m)} such that K(t(m), s) is convergent for every s. Put
K(Î±, s) = limt(m)â†‘Î± K(t(n), s) and proceed as before.
(ii)
If E and F are ï¬nite dimensional, properness of f is equivalent to: the inverse image of every compact
set in F is compact in E (see Exercise 1.5-10).
(iii)
Conditions on f like the one in (ii) or in the theorem are necessary as the following counterexample
shows. Let f : R2 â†’R2 be given by (ex, yeâˆ’x) so that f(R2) is the right open half plane and in

Laxâ€“Milgram Theorem.
If E = F = H is a Hilbert space, then the Hadamardâ€“Levy theorem has an
important consequence. We have seen that in the case of f : R â†’R with a uniform bound on 1/|f â€²(x)|, the
strong monotonicity of f played a key role in the proof that f is a diï¬€eomorphism.
2.5.20 Deï¬nition.
Let H be a Hilbert space. A map f : H â†’H is strongly monotone if there exists a > 0
such that

2.5.21 Lemma.

2. Banach Spaces and Diï¬€erential Calculus

3
Manifolds and Vector Bundles
We are now ready to study manifolds and the diï¬€erential calculus of maps between manifolds. Manifolds
are an abstraction of the idea of a smooth surface in Euclidean space. This abstraction has proved useful
because many sets that are smooth in some sense are not presented to us as subsets of Euclidean space. The
abstraction strips away the containing space and makes constructions intrinsic to the manifold itself. This
point of view is well worth the geometric insight it provides.
3.1
Manifolds
Charts and Atlases.
The basic idea of a manifold is to introduce a local object that will support
diï¬€erentiation processes and then to patch these local objects together smoothly. Before giving the formal
deï¬nitions it is good to have an example in mind. In Rn+1 consider the n-sphere Sn; that is, the set of
x âˆˆRn+1 such that âˆ¥xâˆ¥= 1 (âˆ¥Â· âˆ¥denotes the usual Euclidean norm). We can construct bijections from
subsets of Sn to Rn in several ways. One way is to project stereographically from the south pole onto a
hyperplane tangent to the north pole. This is a bijection from Sn, with the south pole removed, onto Rn.
Similarly, we can interchange the roles of the poles to obtain another bijection. (See Figure 3.1.1.)
With the usual relative topology on Sn as a subset of Rn+1, these maps are homeomorphisms from their
domain to Rn. Each map takes the sphere minus the two poles to an open subset of Rn. If we go from Rn
to the sphere by one map, then back to Rn by the other, we get a smooth map from an open subset of Rn
to Rn. Each map assigns a coordinate system to Sn minus a pole. The union of the two domains is Sn, but
no single homeomorphism can be used between Sn and Rn; however, we can cover Sn using two of them.
In this case they are compatible; that is, in the region covered by both coordinate systems, the change of
coordinates is smooth. For some studies of the sphere, and for other manifolds, two coordinate systems will
not suï¬ƒce. We thus allow all other coordinate systems compatible with these. For example, on S2 we want
to allow spherical coordinates (Î¸, Ï•) since they are convenient for many computations.
3.1.1 Deï¬nition.
Let S be a set. A chart on S is a bijection Ï• from a subset U of S to an open subset
of a Banach space. We sometimes denote Ï• by (U, Ï•), to indicate the domain U of Ï•. A Ck atlas on S is
a family of charts A = { (Ui, Ï•i) | i âˆˆI } such that

Deï¬nition of a Manifold.
We are now ready for the formal deï¬nition of a manifold.
3.1.3 Deï¬nition.
Two Ck atlases A1 and A2 are equivalent if A1 âˆªA2 is a Ck atlas. A Ck diï¬€eren-
tiable structure D on S is an equivalence class of atlases on S. The union of the atlases in D,
AD =

{ A | A âˆˆD }
is the maximal atlas of D, and a chart (U, Ï•) âˆˆAD is an admissible local chart. If A is a Ck atlas
on S, the union of all atlases equivalent to A is called the Ck diï¬€erentiable structure generated by A. A
diï¬€erentiable manifold M is a pair (S, D), where S is a set and D is a Ck diï¬€erentiable structure on S.
We shall often identify M with the underlying set S for notational convenience. If a covering by charts takes
their values in a Banach space E, then E is called the model space and we say that M is a Ck Banach
manifold modeled on E.
If we make a choice of a Ck atlas A on S then we obtain a maximal atlas by including all charts whose
overlap maps with those in A are Ck. In practice it is suï¬ƒcient to specify a particular atlas on S to determine
a manifold structure for S.

Topology of a Manifold.
We now deï¬ne the open subsets in a manifold, which will give us a topology.
3.1.5 Deï¬nition.
Let M be a diï¬€erentiable manifold. A subset A âŠ‚M is called open if for each a âˆˆA
there is an admissible local chart (U, Ï•) such that a âˆˆU and U âŠ‚A.
3.1.6 Proposition.
The open sets in M deï¬ne a topology.
Proof.
Take as basis of the topology the family of ï¬nite intersections of chart domains.
â– 
3.1.7 Deï¬nition.
A diï¬€erentiable manifold M is an n-manifold when every chart has values in an n-
dimensional vector space. Thus for every point a âˆˆM there is an admissible local chart (U, Ï•) with a âˆˆU
and Ï•(U) âŠ‚Rn. We write n = dim M. An n-manifold will mean a Hausdorï¬€, diï¬€erentiable n-manifold in
this book. A diï¬€erentiable manifold is called a ï¬nite-dimensional manifold if its connected components

128
3. Manifolds and Vector Bundles
are all n-manifolds (n can vary with the component). A diï¬€erentiable manifold is called a Hilbert manifold
if the model space is a Hilbert space.1
No assumption on the connectedness of a manifold has been made. In fact, in some applications the manifolds
are disconnected (see Exercise 3.1-3). Since manifolds are locally arcwise connected, their components are
both open and closed.
3.1.8 Examples.
A.
Every discrete topological space S is a 0-manifold, the charts being given by the pairs ({s}, Ï•s), where
Ï•s : s â†’0 and s âˆˆS.
B.
Every Banach space is a manifold; its diï¬€erentiable structure is given by the atlas with the single
identity chart.
C.
The n-sphere Sn with a maximal atlas generated by the atlas with two charts described in Examples
3.1.2B or 3.1.4 makes Sn into an n-manifold. The reader can verify that the resulting topology is the same
as that induced on Sn as a subset of Rn+1.
D.
A set can have more than one diï¬€erentiable structure. For example, R has the following incompatible
charts:
(U1, Ï•1) : U1 = R,
Ï•1(r) = r3 âˆˆR;
and
(U2, Ï•2) : U2 = R,
Ï•2(r) = r âˆˆR.

1
is not diï¬€erentiable at the origin. Nevertheless, these two structures
are â€œdiï¬€eomorphicâ€ (Exercise 3.2-8), but structures can be â€œessentially diï¬€erentâ€ on more complicated sets
(e.g., S7). That S7 has two nondiï¬€eomorphic diï¬€erentiable structures is a famous result of Milnor [1956].
Similar phenomena have been found on R4 by Donaldson [1983]; see also Freed and Uhlenbeck [1984].
E.
Essentially the only one-dimensional paracompact connected manifolds are R and S1. This means that
all others are diï¬€eomorphic to R or S1 (diï¬€eomorphic will be precisely deï¬ned later). For example, the circle
with a knot is diï¬€eomorphic to S1. (See Figure 3.1.3.) See Milnor [1965] or Guillemin and Pollack [1974] for
proofs.

3.2
Submanifolds, Products, and Mappings
A submanifold is the nonlinear analogue of a subspace in linear algebra. Likewise, the product of two
manifolds, producing a new manifold, is the analogue of a product vector space. The analogue of linear
transformations are the Cr maps between manifolds, also introduced in this section. We are not yet ready
to diï¬€erentiate these mappings; this will be possible after we introduce the tangent bundle in Â§3.3.
Submanifolds.
If M is a manifold and A âŠ‚M is an open subset of M, the diï¬€erentiable structure of M
naturally induces one on A. We call A an open submanifold of M. For example, Gn(E), Gn(E) are open
submanifolds of G(E) (see Example 3.1.8G). We would also like to say that Sn is a submanifold of Rn+1,
although it is a closed subset. To motivate the general deï¬nition we notice that there are charts in Rn+1 in
which a neighborhood of Sn becomes part of the subspace Rn. Figure 3.2.1 illustrates this for n = 1.
3.2.1 Deï¬nition.
A submanifold of a manifold M is a subset B âŠ‚M with the property that for each
b âˆˆB there is an admissible chart (U, Ï•) in M with b âˆˆU which has the submanifold property, namely,
that Ï• has the form
SM.
Ï• : U â†’E Ã— F,
and
Ï•(U âˆ©B) = Ï•(U) âˆ©(E Ã— {0}).
An open subset V of M is a submanifold in this sense. Here we merely take F = {0}, and for x âˆˆV use
any chart (U, Ï•) of M for which x âˆˆU.

Products of Manifolds.
Now we show how to make the product of two manifolds into a manifold.
3.2.4 Deï¬nition.
Let (S1, D1) and (S2, D2) be two manifolds. The product manifold (S1 Ã—S2, D1 Ã—D2)
consists of the set S1 Ã— S2 together with the diï¬€erentiable structure D1 Ã— D2 generated by the atlas { (U1 Ã—
U2, Ï•1 Ã— Ï•2) | (Ui, Ï•i) is a chart of (Si, Di), i = 1, 2 }.
That the set in this deï¬nition is an atlas follows from the fact that if Ïˆ1 : U1 âŠ‚E1 â†’V1 âŠ‚F1
and Ïˆ2 : U2 âŠ‚E2 â†’V2 âŠ‚F2, then Ïˆ1 Ã— Ïˆ2 is a diï¬€eomorphism iï¬€Ïˆ1 and Ïˆ2 are, and in this case
(Ïˆ1 Ã— Ïˆ2)âˆ’1 = Ïˆâˆ’1
1
Ã— Ïˆâˆ’1
2 . It is clear that the topology on the product manifold is the product topology.
Also, if S1, S2 are ï¬nite dimensional, dim(S1 Ã— S2) = dim S1 + dim S2. Inductively one deï¬nes the product
of a ï¬nite number of manifolds. A simple example of a product manifold is the n-torus Tn = S1 Ã— Â· Â· Â· Ã— S1
(n times).

3.2.6 Proposition.
Let f : M â†’N be a continuous map of manifolds. Then f is Cr iï¬€the local repre-

Proof.

f is Cr now follows from the fact that any chart of M can be obtained from the given collection by change
of diï¬€eomorphism, restrictions, and/or unions of domains, all three operations preserving the Cr character
of f. This argument also demonstrates the converse.

Deï¬ne a map i : U Ã— E â†’T(U) by i(u, e) = [cu,e]u. The preceding lemma says that i is a bijection and
thus we can deï¬ne a manifold structure on TU by means of i.
The tangent space TmM at a point m âˆˆM has an intrinisic vector space structure. This vector space
structure can be deï¬ned directly by showing that addition and scalar multiplication can be deï¬ned by the
corresponding operations in charts and that this deï¬nition is independent of the chart. This idea is very
important in the general study of vector bundles and we shall return to this point below.
Tangents of Mappings.
It will be convenient to deï¬ne the tangent of a mapping before showing that
TM is a manifold. The idea is simply that the derivative of a map can be characterized by its eï¬€ect on
tangents to curves.
3.3.5 Lemma.

C1. Then f â—¦c1 and f â—¦c2 are tangent at f(m) âˆˆN.
Proof.

f â—¦c1 and f â—¦c2 are of class C1. For tangency, let (V, Ïˆ) be a chart on N with f(m) âˆˆV . We must show

3. Manifolds and Vector Bundles
3.4
Vector Bundles
Roughly speaking, a vector bundle is a manifold with a vector space attached to each point. During the
formal deï¬nitions we may keep in mind the example of the tangent bundle to a manifold, such as the n-sphere
Sn. Similarly, the collection of normal lines to Sn form a vector bundle.
Deï¬nition of a Vector Bundle.
The deï¬nitions will follow the pattern of those for a manifold. Namely,
we obtain a vector bundle by smoothly patching together local vector bundles. The following terminology
for vector space products and maps will be useful.
3.4.1 Deï¬nition.
Let E and F be Banach spaces with U an open subset of E. We call the Cartesian
product U Ã—F a local vector bundle. We call U the base space, which can be identiï¬ed with U Ã—{0}, the
zero section. For u âˆˆU, {u} Ã— F is called the ï¬ber of u, which we endow with the vector space structure
of F. The map Ï€ : U Ã— F â†’U given by Ï€(u, f) = u is called the projection of U Ã— F. (Thus, the ï¬ber over
u âˆˆU is Ï€âˆ’1(u). Also note that U Ã— F is an open subset of E Ã— F and so is a local manifold.)
Next, we introduce the idea of a local vector bundle map. The main idea is that such a map must map a
ï¬ber linearly to a ï¬ber.
3.4.2 Deï¬nition.
Let U Ã— F and U â€² Ã— Fâ€² be local vector bundles. A map Ï• : U Ã— F â†’U â€² Ã— Fâ€² is called
a Cr local vector bundle map if it has the form Ï•(u, f) = (Ï•1(u), Ï•2(u) Â· f) where Ï•1 : U â†’U â€² and
Ï•2 : U â†’L(F, Fâ€²) are Cr. A local vector bundle map that has an inverse which is also a local vector bundle
map is called a local vector bundle isomorphism. (See Figure 3.4.1.)

A local vector bundle map Ï• : U Ã— F â†’U â€² Ã— Fâ€² maps the ï¬ber {u} Ã— F into the ï¬ber {Ï•1(u)} Ã— Fâ€² and

Supplement 3.4A
Smoothness of Local Vector Bundle Maps
In some examples, to check whether a map Ï• is a Câˆlocal vector bundle map, one is faced with the rather
unpleasant task of verifying that Ï•2 : U â†’L(F, Fâ€²) is Câˆ. It would be nice to know that the smoothness
of Ï• as a function of two variables suï¬ƒces. This is the context of the next proposition. We state the result
for Câˆ, but the proof contains a Cr result (with an interesting derivative loss) which is discussed in the
ensuing Remark A.

3.4.3 Proposition.
A map Ï• : U Ã— F â†’U â€² Ã— Fâ€² is a Câˆlocal vector bundle map iï¬€Ï• is Câˆand is of
the form Ï•(u, f) = (Ï•1(u), Ï•2(u) Â· f), where Ï•1 : U â†’U â€² and Ï•2 : U â†’L(F, Fâ€²).

The ï¬bers of a vector bundle inherit an intrinsic vector space structure and a topology independent of the
charts, but there is no norm that is chart independent. Putting particular norms on ï¬bers is extra structure
to be considered later in the book. Sometimes the phrase Banachable space is used to indicate that the
topology comes from a complete norm but we are not nailing down a particular one.
The following summarizes the basic properties of a vector bundle.

3.4.7 Theorem.
Let E be a vector bundle. The zero section (or base) B of E is a submanifold of E
and there is a map Ï€ : E â†’B (sometimes denoted Ï€BE : E â†’B) called the projection that is of class
Câˆ, and is surjective (onto). Moreover, for each b âˆˆB, Ï€âˆ’1(b), called the ï¬ber over b, has a Banachable
vector space structure induced by any admissible vector bundle chart, with b the zero element.
Because of these properties we sometimes write â€œthe vector bundle Ï€ : E â†’Bâ€ instead of â€œthe vector
bundle (E, V).â€ Fibers are often denoted by Eb = Ï€âˆ’1(b). If the base B and the map Ï€ are understood, we
just say â€œthe vector bundle E.â€

3.4.11 Deï¬nition.
Let E and Eâ€² be two vector bundles. A map f : E â†’Eâ€² is called a Cr vector bundle
mapping (local isomorphism) when for each v âˆˆE and each admissible local bundle chart (V, Ïˆ) of Eâ€²

This deï¬nition makes sense only for local vector bundle charts and not for all manifold charts. Also,
such a W is not guaranteed by the continuity of f, nor does it imply it. However, if we ï¬rst check that f
is ï¬ber preserving (which it must be) and is continuous, then such an open set W is guaranteed. This

We also note that the composition of two vector bundle mappings is again a vector bundle mapping.
3.4.13 Examples.
A.
Let M and N be Cr+1 manifolds and f : M â†’N a Cr+1 map. Then Tf : TM â†’TN is a Cr vector
bundle map of class Cr. Indeed the local representative of Tf, (Tf)T Ï•,T Ïˆ = T(fÏ•Ïˆ) is a local vector bundle
map, so the result follows from Proposition 3.3.11.
B.
The proof of Proposition 3.3.13 shows that T(M1 Ã— M2) and TM1 Ã— TM2 are isomorphic as vector
bundles over the identity of M1 Ã— M2. They are usually identiï¬ed.
C.
To get an impression of how vector bundle maps work, let us show that the cylinder S1 Ã— R and the
MÂ¨obius band M are not vector bundle isomorphic. If Ï• : M â†’S1 Ã— R were such an isomorphism, then the
image of the curve c : [0, 1] â†’M, c(t) = [t, 1] by Ï• would never cross the zero section in S1 Ã— R, since [s, 1]
is never zero in all ï¬bers of M; that is, the second component of (Ï• â—¦c)(t) Ì¸= 0 for all t âˆˆ[0, 1]. But
c(1) = [1, 1] = [0, âˆ’1] = âˆ’[0, 1] = âˆ’c(0)
so that the second components of Ï• â—¦c at t = 0 and t = 1 are in absolute value equal and of opposite sign,
which, by the intermediate value theorem, implies that the second component of Ï• â—¦c vanishes somewhere.

D.

Sections of Vector Bundles.
A second generalization of a local Cr mapping, f : U âŠ‚E â†’F, globalizes
not f but rather its graph mapping Î»f : U â†’U Ã— F; u â†’(u, f(u)).
3.4.14 Deï¬nition.
Let Ï€ : E â†’B be a vector bundle. A Cr local section of Ï€ is a Cr map Î¾ : U â†’E,
where U is open in B, such that for each b âˆˆU, Ï€(Î¾(b)) = b. If U = B, Î¾ is called a Cr global section, or
simply a Cr section of Ï€. Let Î“r(Ï€) denote the set of all Cr sections of Ï€, together with the obvious real
(inï¬nite-dimensional) vector space structure.
The condition on Î¾ says that Î¾(b) lies in the ï¬ber over b. The Cr sections form a linear function space
suitable for global linear analysis. As will be shown in later chapters, this general construction includes
spaces of vector and tensor ï¬elds on manifolds. The space of sections of a vector bundle diï¬€ers from the
more general class of global Cr maps from one manifold to another, which is a nonlinear function space.
(See, for example, Eells [1958], Palais [1968], Elliasson [1967], or Ebin and Marsden [1970] for further details.)

3.4.29 Examples.
A.
Any manifold is a locally trivial ï¬ber bundle with typical ï¬ber a point.
B.
Any vector bundle Ï€ : E â†’B is a locally trivial ï¬ber bundle whose typical ï¬ber is the model of the
ï¬ber Eb. Indeed, if Ï• : W â†’U â€² Ã— F, where U â€² open in E, is a local vector bundle chart, by Proposition

by Ï‡(e) = (Ï€(e), (p2 â—¦Ï•)(e)), where p2 : U â€² Ã— F â†’F is the projection, is a local trivialization of E. In fact,
any locally trivial ï¬ber bundle Ï€ : E â†’B whose typical ï¬ber F is a Banach space is a vector bundle, iï¬€the
maps Ï‡Î±b : Eb â†’F induced by the local trivializations Ï‡Î± : Ï€âˆ’1(UÎ±) â†’UÎ± Ã— F, are linear and continuous.
Indeed, under these hypotheses, the vector bundle charts are given by (Ï•Î± Ã— idF) â—¦Ï‡Î± : Ï€âˆ’1(UÎ±) â†’UÎ± Ã— F,
where idF is the identity mapping on F.
C.
Many of the topological properties of a vector bundle are determined by its ï¬ber bundle structure. For
example, a vector bundle Ï€ : E â†’B is trivial if and only if it is trivial as a ï¬ber bundle. Clearly, if E is a
trivial vector bundle, then it is also a trivial ï¬ber bundle. The converse is also true, but requires topological
ideas beyond the scope of this book. (See, for instance, Steenrod [1957].)
D.

E.
Consider the smooth map Ï€n : Sn â†’RPn which associates to each point of Sn the line through the

G. The Hopf ï¬bration is nontrivial.
A rigorous proof of this fact is not so elementary and historically
was what led to the introduction of the Hopf invariant, a precursor of characteristic classes (Hopf [1931] and
Hilton and Wylie [1960]). We shall limit ourselves to a geometric description of this bundle which exhibits its
non-triviality. In fact we shall describe how each pair of ï¬bers are linked. Cut S2 along an equator to obtain

the closed northern and southern hemispheres, each of which is diï¬€eomorphic to two closed disks DN and DS.
Their inverse images in S3 are two solid tori S1 Ã— DN and S1 Ã— DS. We think of S3 as the compactiï¬cation
of R3 and as the union of two solid tori glued along their common boundary by a diï¬€eomorphism which
identiï¬es the parallels of one with meridians of the other and vice-versa. The Hopf ï¬bration on S3 is then
obtained in the following way. Cut each of these two solid tori along a meridian, twist them by 2Ï€ and glue
each one back together. The result is still two solid tori but whose embedding in R3 is changed: they have
the same parallels but twisted meridians; each two meridians are now linked (see Figure 3.4.5). Now glue
the two twisted solid tori back together along their common boundary by the diï¬€eomorphism identifying
the twisted meridians of one with the parallels of the other and vice-versa, thereby obtaining the total space
S3 of the Hopf ï¬bration.

3.4.35 Theorem.
Let Ï€ : E â†’B be any C0 ï¬ber bundle over a contractible space B. Then E is trivial.
Proof.

any b âˆˆB, where b0 âˆˆB is a ï¬xed element of B. Then the pull-back bundle hâˆ—E is a ï¬ber bundle over
B Ã— [0, 1] whose restrictions to B Ã— {0} and B Ã— {1} equals the trivial ï¬ber bundle over {b0} and E over
B Ã— {1}, respectively. By Lemma 3.4.34, hâˆ—E is trivial over B Ã— [0, 1] and thus E, which is isomorphic to
E|B Ã— {1}, is also trivial.

3.5
Submersions, Immersions, and Transversality
The notions of submersion, immersion, and transversality are geometric ways of stating various hypotheses
needed for the inverse function theorem, and are central to large portions of calculus on manifolds. One
immediate beneï¬t is easy proofs that various subsets of manifolds are actually submanifolds.
3.5.1 Theorem (Local Diï¬€eomorphisms Theorem).
Suppose that M and N are manifolds, f : M â†’N
is of class Cr, r â‰¥1 and m âˆˆM. Suppose Tf restricted to the ï¬ber over m âˆˆM is an isomorphism. Then
f is a Cr diï¬€eomorphism from some neighborhood of m onto some neighborhood of f(m).

3.5 Submersions, Immersions, and Transversality
173
Proof.
In local charts, the hypothesis reads: (DfÏ•Ïˆ)(u) is an isomorphism, where Ï•(m) = u. Then the
inverse function theorem guarantees that fÏ•Ïˆ restricted to a neighborhood of u is a Cr diï¬€eomorphism.
Composing with chart maps gives the result.
â– 
The local results of Theorems 2.5.9 and 2.5.13 give the following:
3.5.2 Theorem (Local Onto Theorem).
Let M and N be manifolds and f : M â†’N be of class Cr, where
r â‰¥1. Suppose Tf restricted to the ï¬ber TmM is surjective to Tf(m)N. Then
(i)
f is locally onto at m; that is, there are neighborhoods U of m and V of f(m) such that f|U : U â†’V
is onto; in particular, if Tf is surjective on each tangent space, then f is an open mapping;
(ii)
if, in addition, the kernel ker(Tmf) is split in TmM there are charts (U, Ï•) and (V, Ïˆ) with m âˆˆU,
f(U) âŠ‚V , Ï• : U â†’U â€² Ã— V â€², Ï•(m) = (0, 0), Ïˆ : V â†’V â€², and fÏ•Ïˆ : U â€² Ã— V â†’V â€² is the projection onto
the second factor.
Proof.
It suï¬ƒces to prove the results locally, and these follow from Theorems 2.5.9 and 2.5.13.
â– 
Submersions.
The notions of submersion and immersion correspond to the local surjectivity and injec-
tivity theorems from Â§2.5. Let us ï¬rst examine submersions, building on the preceding theorem.
3.5.3 Deï¬nition.
Suppose M and N are manifolds with f : M â†’N of class Cr, r â‰¥1. A point n âˆˆN is
called a regular value of f if for each m âˆˆf âˆ’1({n}), Tmf is surjective with split kernel. Let Rf denote the
set of regular values of f : M â†’N; note N\f(M) âŠ‚Rf âŠ‚N. If, for each m in a set S, Tmf is surjective
with split kernel, we say f is a submersion on S. Thus n âˆˆRf iï¬€f is a submersion on f âˆ’1({n}). If Tmf
is not surjective, m âˆˆM is called a critical point and n = f(m) âˆˆN a critical value of f.
3.5.4 Theorem (Submersion Theorem).
Let f : M â†’N be of class Câˆand n âˆˆRf. Then the level set
