C. Orthogonal Group.
Let O(n) be the set of elements Q of L(Rn, Rn) that are orthogonal, that is,
QQT = Identity. We shall prove that O(n) is a compact submanifold of dimension n(nâˆ’1)/2. This manifold
is called the orthogonal group of Rn; the group operations (composition of linear operators and inversion)
being smooth in L(Rn, Rn) are therefore smooth in O(n), that is, O(n) is an example of a Lie group. To
show that O(n) is a submanifold, let sym(n) denote the vector space of symmetric linear operators S of
Rn, that is, ST = S; its dimension equals n(n + 1)/2. The map f : L(Rn, Rn) â†’sym(n), f(Q) = QQT is
smooth and has derivative
TQf(A) = AQT + QAT = AQâˆ’1 + QAT
at Q âˆˆO(n). This linear map from L(Rn, Rn) to sym(n) is onto since for any S âˆˆsym(n),
TQf(SQ/2) = S.
Therefore, by Theorem 3.5.4, f âˆ’1 (Identity) = O(n) is a closed submanifold of L(Rn, Rn) of dimension equal
to n2 âˆ’n(n + 1)/2 = n(n âˆ’1)/2. Finally, O(n) is compact since it lies on the unit sphere of L(Rn, Rn).

Immersions.
Now we look at maps whose derivatives are one-to-one.
3.5.6 Deï¬nition.
A Cr map f : M â†’N, r â‰¥1, is called an immersion at m if Tmf is injective with
closed split range in Tf(m)N. If f is an immersion at each m, we just say f is an immersion.
3.5.7 Theorem (Immersion Theorem).
For a Cr map f : M â†’N, where r â‰¥1, the following are
equivalent:
(i)
f is an immersion at m;
(ii)
there are charts (U, Ï•) and (V, Ïˆ) with m âˆˆU, f(U) âŠ‚V , Ï• : U â†’U â€², Ïˆ : V â†’U â€² Ã—V â€² and Ï•(m) = 0
such that fÏ•Ïˆ : U â€² â†’U â€² Ã— V â€² is the inclusion u â†’(u, 0);
(iii)
there is a neighborhood U of m such that f(U) is a submanifold in N and f restricted to U is a
diï¬€eomorphism of U onto f(U).
Proof.
The equivalence of (i) and (ii) is guaranteed by the local immersion theorem 2.5.12. Assuming (ii),
choose U and V given by that theorem to conclude that f(U) is a submanifold in V . But V is open in N
and hence f(U) is a submanifold in N proving (iii). The converse is a direct application of the deï¬nition of
a submanifold.

intersects f(S1) in a set with â€œcornersâ€ which is not diï¬€eomorphic to an open interval. In such cases we say

Embeddings.
If f : M â†’N is an injective immersion, f(M) is called an immersed submanifold of
N.
3.5.8 Deï¬nition.
An immersion f : M â†’N that is a homeomorphism onto f(M) with the relative
topology induced from N is called an embedding.
Thus, if f : M â†’N is an embedding, then f(M) is a submanifold of N.
The following is an important situation in which an immersion is guaranteed to be an embedding; the
proof is a straightforward application of the deï¬nition of relative topology.

3.5.9 Theorem (Embedding Theorem).
An injective immersion which is an open or closed map onto its
image is an embedding.
The condition â€œf : M â†’N is closedâ€ is implied by â€œf is proper,â€ that is, each sequence xn âˆˆM with f(xn)
convergent to y N has a convergent subsequence xn(i) in M such that f(xn(i)) converges to y. Indeed, if this
hypothesis holds, and A is a closed subset of M, then f(A) is shown to be closed in N in the following way.
Let xn âˆˆA, and suppose f(xn) = yn converges to y âˆˆN. Then there is a subsequence {zm} of {xn}, such
that zm â†’x. Since A = cl(A), x âˆˆA and by continuity of f, y = f(x) âˆˆf(A); that is, f(A) is closed. If N is
inï¬nite dimensional, this hypothesis is assured by the condition â€œthe inverse image of every compact set in
N is compact in M.â€ This is clear since in the preceding hypothesis one can choose a compact neighborhood
V of the limit of f(xn) in N so that for n large enough, all xn belong to the compact neighborhood f âˆ’1(V )
in M. The reader should note that while both hypotheses in the proposition are necessary, properness of f
is only suï¬ƒcient. An injective nonproper immersion whose image is a submanifold is, for example, the map

Transversality.
This is an important notion that applies to both maps and submanifolds.
3.5.10 Deï¬nition.
A Cr map f : M â†’N, r â‰¥1, is said to be transversal to the submanifold P of N
(denoted f â‹”P) if either f âˆ’1(P) = âˆ…, or if for every m âˆˆf âˆ’1(P),
T1.
(Tmf)(TmM) + Tf(m)P = Tf(m)N and
T2.
the inverse image (Tmf)âˆ’1(Tf(m)P) of Tf(m)P splits in TmM.
The ï¬rst condition T1 is purely algebraic; no splitting assumptions are made on (Tmf)(TmM), nor need
the sum be direct. If M is a Hilbert manifold, or if M is ï¬nite dimensional, then the splitting condition T2
in the deï¬nition is automatically satisï¬ed.
3.5.11 Examples.
A.
If each point of P is a regular value of f, then f â‹”P since, in this case, (Tmf)(TmM) = Tf(m)N.
B.
Assume that M and N are ï¬nite-dimensional manifolds with dim(P)+dim(M) < dim(N). Then f â‹”P
implies f(M) âˆ©P = âˆ…. This is seen by a dimension count: if there were a point m âˆˆf âˆ’1(P) âˆ©M, then
dim(N) = dim((Tmf)(TmM) + Tf(m)P) â‰¤dim(M) + dim(P) < dim(N),
which is absurd.

3.5.18 Theorem (Fibration Theorem).
The following are equivalent for a Câˆmap f : M â†’N:
(i)
the map f is a subimmersion (if M or N are ï¬nite dimensional, this is equivalent to the rank of Tmf
being locally constant);
(ii)
for each m âˆˆM there is a neighborhood U of m, a neighborhood V of f(m), and a submanifold Z of M
with m âˆˆZ such that f(U) is a submanifold of N and f induces a diï¬€eomorphism of f âˆ’1(V ) âˆ©Z âˆ©U
onto f(U) âˆ©V ;
(iii)
ker Tf is a subbundle of TM (called the tangent bundle to the ï¬bers) and for each m âˆˆM, the
image of Tmf is closed and splits in Tf(m)N.
If one of these hold and if f is open (or closed) onto its image, then f(M) is a submanifold of N.
Proof.
To show that (i) implies (ii), choose for U and V the chart domains given by Proposition 3.5.16(i)
and let Z = Ï•âˆ’1(V1 Ã— {0}). Then
Ïˆ(f(U) âˆ©V ) = fÏ•Ïˆ(V1 Ã— U2) = V1 Ã— {0},
that is, f(U) is a submanifold of N. In addition, the local expression of f : f âˆ’1(V ) âˆ©Z âˆ©U â†’f(U) âˆ©V
is (x, 0) â†’(x, 0), thus proving that so restricted, f is a diï¬€eomorphism. Reading this argument backward
shows that (ii) implies (i).
We have
TÏ•(ker Tf âˆ©TU) = V1 Ã— U2 Ã— {0} Ã— E2,
since fÏ•Ïˆ(x, y) = (x, 0), thus showing that (TU, TÏ•) has the subbundle property for ker Tf. The same local
expression shows that (Tmf)(TmM) is closed and splits in Tf(m)M and thus (i) implies (iii). The reverse is
proved along the same lines.
If f is open (closed) onto its image, then f(U) âˆ©V [resp., int(f(cl(U))) âˆ©V ] can serve as a chart domain
for f(M) with the relative topology induced from N. Thus f(M) is a submanifold of N.

The relationship between transversality and subimmersivity is given by the following.

3.5.19 Proposition.
Let f : M â†’N be smooth, P a submanifold of N, and assume that f â‹”P. Then
there is an open neighborhood W of P in N such that f|f âˆ’1(W) : f âˆ’1(W) â†’W is a subimmersion.
Proof.
Let m âˆˆf âˆ’1(P) and write Tm(f âˆ’1(P)) = ker(Tmf) âŠ•Cm so that Tmf : Cm â†’TnP is an
isomorphism, where n = f(m). As in the proof of Theorem 3.5.12, this situation can be locally straightened
out, so we can assume that M âŠ‚E1 Ã—E2, where P is open in E1 and E1 = ker Tmf âŠ•C for a complementary
space C. The map f restricted to C is a local immersion, so projection to C followed by the restriction of
f to C writes f as the composition of a submersion followed by an immersion. We leave it to the reader to
expand the details of this argument.
â– 
In some applications, the closedness of f follows from properness of f; see the discussion following Theorem
3.5.9.
If M or N is ï¬nite dimensional, then f being a subimmersion is equivalent to ker Tf being a subbundle
of TM. Indeed, range(Tmf) = TmM/ ker(Tmf) and thus dim(range(Tmf)) = codim(ker(Tmf)) = constant
and f is hence a subimmersion by Proposition 3.5.16(ii). Proposition 3.5.19 is an inï¬nite dimensional version
of this.
We have already encountered subimmersions in the study of vector bundles. Namely, the condition in
Proposition 3.4.18(i) (which insures that for a vector bundle map f over the identity ker f and range f are
subbundles) is nothing other than f being a subimmersion.
Quotients.
We conclude this section with a study of quotient manifolds.
3.5.20 Deï¬nition.
An equivalence relation R on a manifold M is called regular if the quotient space
M/R carries a manifold structure such that the canonical projection Ï€ : M â†’M/R is a submersion. If R
is a regular equivalence relation, then M/R is called the quotient manifold of M by R.
Since submersions are open mappings, Ï€ and hence the regular equivalence relations R are open.
Quotient manifolds are characterized by their eï¬€ect on mappings.
3.5.21 Proposition.
Let R be a regular equivalent relation on M.
(i)
A map f : M/R â†’N is Cr, r â‰¥1 iï¬€f â—¦Ï€ : M â†’N is Cr.
(ii)

map Ë†g : M/R â†’N such that Ë†g â—¦Ï€ = g.
(iii)
The manifold structure of M/R is unique.
Proof.
(i)
If f is Cr, then so is f â—¦Ï€ by the composite mapping theorem. Conversely, let f â—¦Ï€ be Cr.
Since Ï€ is a submersion it can be locally expressed as a projection and thus there exist charts (U, Ï•) at
m âˆˆM and (V, Ïˆ) at Ï€(m) âˆˆM/R such that

thus fÏˆÏ‡ is Cr.
(ii)

There is, in fact, a bijective correspondence between surjective submersions and quotient manifolds. More
precisely, we have the following.
3.5.23 Proposition.
Let f : M â†’N be a submersion and let R be the equivalence relation deï¬ned by f;
that is, xRy iï¬€f(x) = f(y). Then R is regular, M/R is diï¬€eomorphic to f(M), and f(M) is open in N.
Proof.
As f is a submersion, it is an open mapping, so f(M) is open in N. Moreover, since f is open,
so is the equivalence R and thus f induces a homeomorphism of M/R onto f(M) (see the comments
following Deï¬nition 1.4.9). Put the diï¬€erentiable structure on M/R that makes the homeomorphism into a
diï¬€eomorphism. Then M/R is a manifold and the projection is clearly a submersion, since f is.
â– 
This construction provides a number of examples of quotient manifolds.
3.5.24 Examples.
A. The base space of any vector bundle is a quotient manifold. Take the submersion to be the vector
bundle projection.
B. The circle S1 is a quotient manifold of R deï¬ned by the submersion Î¸ â†’eiÎ¸; we can then write
S1 = R/2Ï€Z, including the diï¬€erentiable structure.
C. The Grassmannian Gk(E) is a quotient manifold in the following way. Deï¬ne the set D by D =
{ (x1, . . . , xk) | xi âˆˆE, x1, . . . , xk are linearly dependent }. Since D is open in the product E Ã— Â· Â· Â· Ã— E
(k times), one can deï¬ne the map Ï€ : D â†’Gk(E) by Ï€(x1, . . . , xk) = span{x1, . . . , xk}. Using the
charts described in Example 3.1.8G, one ï¬nds that Ï€ is a submersion. In particular, the projective
spaces RPn and CPn are quotient manifolds.
D. The MÂ¨obius band as explained in Example 3.4.10C is a quotient manifold.
E. Quotient bundles are quotient manifolds (see Proposition 3.4.17).

The only solutions are Î» = Â±1/2, x = 0, y = 0, z = Â±1, and indeed these correspond to the maximum and
minimum points for f on S2. See an elementary text such as Marsden and Tromba [1996] for additional
examples. For more advanced applications, see Luenberger [1969].
The reader will recall from advanced calculus that maximum and minimum tests for a critical point can be
given in terms of the Hessian, that is, matrix of second derivatives. For constrained problems there is a similar
test involving bordered Hessians. Bordered Hessians are simply the Hessians of h = f âˆ’Î»g + c(Î» âˆ’Î»0)2
in (x, Î»)-space. Then the Hessian test for maxima and minima apply; a maximum or minimum of h clearly
implies the same for f on a level set of g. See Marsden and Tromba [1996] (pp. 224â€“30) for an elementary
treatment and applications.

3.6
The Sard and Smale Theorems
This section is devoted to the classical Sard theorem and its inï¬nite-dimensional generalization due to Smale
[1965]. We ï¬rst develop a few properties of sets of measure zero in Rn.
Sets of Measure Zero.
A subset A âŠ‚Rm is said to have measure zero if, for every Îµ > 0, there is a
countable covering of A by open sets Ui, such that the sum of the volumes of Ui is less than Îµ. Clearly a
countable union of sets of measure zero has measure zero.
3.6.1 Lemma.
Let U âŠ‚Rm be open and A âŠ‚U be of measure zero. If f : U â†’Rm is a C1 map, then
f(A) has measure zero.
Proof.
Let A be contained in a countable union of relatively compact sets Cn. If we show that f(A âˆ©Cn)
has measure zero, then f(A) has measure zero since it will be a countable union of sets of measure zero. But
Cn is relatively compact and thus there exists M > 0 such that âˆ¥Df(x)âˆ¥â‰¤M for all x âˆˆCn. By the mean
value theorem, the image of a cube of edge length d is contained in a cube of edge length dâˆšmM.
â– 

3.6 The Sard and Smale Theorems
193
3.6.2 Lemma (Fubini Lemma).
Let A be a countable union of compact sets in Rn, ï¬x an integer r satis-
fying 1 â‰¤r â‰¤n âˆ’1 and assume that Ac = A âˆ©({c} Ã— Rnâˆ’r) has measure zero in Rnâˆ’r for all c âˆˆRr. Then
A has measure zero.
Proof.
By induction we reduce to the case r = n âˆ’1. It is enough to work with one element of the union,
so we may assume A itself is compact and hence there exists and interval [a, b] such that A âŠ‚[a, b] Ã— Rnâˆ’1.
Since Ac is compact and has measure zero for each c âˆˆ[a, b], there is a ï¬nite number of closed cubes
Kc,1, . . . , Kc,N(c) in Rnâˆ’1 the sum of whose volumes is less than Îµ and such that {c} Ã— Kc,i cover Ac,
i = 1, . . . , N(c). Find a closed interval Ic with c in its interior such that Ic Ã— Kc,i âŠ‚Ac Ã— Rnâˆ’1. Thus the
family
{ Ic Ã— Kc,i | i = 1, . . . , N(c), c âˆˆ[a, b] }
covers A âˆ©([a, b] Ã— Rnâˆ’1) = A. Since { int(Ic) | c âˆˆ[a, b] } covers [a, b], we can choose a ï¬nite subcovering
Ic(1), . . . , Ic(M). Now ï¬nd another covering Jc(1), . . . , Jc(K) such that each Jc(i) is contained in some Ic(j)
and such that the sum of the lengths of all Jc(i) is less than 2(b âˆ’a). Consequently { Jc(j) Ã— Kc(j),i | j =
1, . . . , K, i = 1, . . . , Nc(j) } cover A and the sum of their volumes is less than 2(b âˆ’a)Îµ.
â– 
Sard Theorem.
Let us recall the following notations from Â§3.5. If M and N are C1 manifolds and
f : M â†’N is a C1 map, a point x âˆˆM is a regular point of f if Txf is surjective, otherwise x is a critical
point of f. If C âŠ‚M is the set of critical points of f, then f(C) âŠ‚N is the set of critical values of f
and N\f(C) is the set of regular values of f, which is denoted by Rf or R(f). In addition, for A âŠ‚M
we deï¬ne Rf|A by Rf|A = N\f(A âˆ©C). In particular, if U âŠ‚M is open, Rf|U = R(f|U).
3.6.3 Theorem (Sardâ€™s Theorem in Rn).
Let U âŠ‚Rm be open and f : U â†’Rn be of class Ck, where
k > max(0, m âˆ’n). Then the set of critical values of f has measure zero in Rn.
Note that if m â‰¤n, then f is only required to be at least C1.
Proof.

The smoothness assumption k â‰¥1 + max(0, m âˆ’n) cannot be weakened as the following counterexample

3.6.4 Example (Devilâ€™s Staircase Phenomenon).
The Cantor set C is deï¬ned by the following construc-
tion. Remove the open interval ]âˆ’1/3, 2/3[ from the closed interval [0, 1]. Then remove the middle thirds
]1/9, 2/9[ and ]7/9, 8/9[ from the closed intervals [0, 1/3] and [2/3, 1] respectively and continue this process
of removing the middle third of each remaining closed interval indeï¬nitely. The set C is the remaining set.
Since we have removed a (countable) union of open intervals, C is closed. The total length of the removed
intervals equals (1/3) 
nâ‰¥0(2/3)n = 1 and thus C has measure zero in [0, 1]. On the other hand each point
of C is approached arbitrarily closely by a sequence of endpoints of the intervals removed, that is, each
point of C is an accumulation point of [0, 1]\C. Each open subinterval of [0, 1] has points in common with at
least one of the deleted intervals which means that the union of all these deleted intervals is dense in [0, 1].
Therefore C is nowhere dense. Expand each number x in [0, 1] in a ternary expansion 0.a1a2 . . . that is,
x = 
nâ‰¥0 3âˆ’nan, where an = 0, 1, or 2. Then it is easy to see that C consists of all numbers whose ternary
expansion involves only 0 and 2. (The number 1 equals 0.222 . . . .) Thus C is in bijective correspondence
with all sequences valued in a two-point set, that is, the cardinality of C is that of the continuum; that is,
C is uncountable.
We shall construct a C1 function f : R2 â†’R which is not C2 and which contains [0, 2] among its
critical values. Since the measure of this set equals 2, this contradicts the conclusion of Sardâ€™s theorem.
Note, however, that there is no contradiction with the statement of Sardâ€™s theorem since f is only C1. We
start the construction by noting that the set C + C = { x + y | x, y âˆˆC } equals [0, 2]. The reader can

f(x, y) = g(x)+g(y) is C1, and if c1, c2 âˆˆC, then there are critical points x1, x2 âˆˆ[0, 1] such that g(xi) = ci,

We proceed to the global version of Sardâ€™s theorem on ï¬nite-dimensional manifolds. Recall that a subset of
a topological space is residual if it is the intersection of countably many open dense sets. The Baire category
theorem 1.7.3 asserts that a residual subset of a a locally compact space or of a complete pseudometric
space is dense. A topological space is called LindelÂ¨of if every open covering has a countable subcovering.
In particular, second countable topological spaces are LindelÂ¨of. (See Lemma 1.1.6.)
3.6.5 Theorem (Sardâ€™s Theorem for Manifolds).
Let M and N be ï¬nite-dimensional Ck manifolds, dim(M) =
m, dim(N) = n, and f : M â†’N a Ck mapping, k â‰¥1. Assume M is LindelÂ¨of and k > max(0, m âˆ’n).
Then Rf is residual and hence dense in N.
Proof.
Denote by C the set of critical points of f. We will show that every x âˆˆM has a neighborhood Z
such that Rf| cl(Z) is open and dense. Then, since M is LindelÂ¨of we can ï¬nd a countable cover {Zi} of X
with Rf| cl(Zi) open and dense. Since Rf = 
i Rf| cl(Zi), it will follow that Rf is residual.
Choose x âˆˆM. We want a neighborhood Z of x with Rf| cl(Z) open and dense. By taking local charts
we may assume that M is an open subset of Rm and N = Rn. Choose an open neighborhood Z of x such
that cl(Z) is compact. Then
C = { x âˆˆM | rank Df(x) < n }
is closed, so cl(Z) âˆ©C is compact, and hence f(cl(Z) âˆ©C) is compact. But f(cl(Z) âˆ©C) is a subset of the
set of critical values of f and hence, by Sardâ€™s theorem in Rn, has measure zero. A closed set of measure
zero is nowhere dense; hence Rf| cl(Z) = Rn\f(cl(Z) âˆ©C) is open and dense.

Sardâ€™s theorem holds, however, if enough restrictions are imposed on f. The generalization we consider is
due to Smale [1965]. The class of linear maps allowed are Fredholm operators which have splitting properties
similar to those in the Fredholm alternative theorem.
3.6.10 Deï¬nition.
Let E and F be Banach spaces and A âˆˆL(E, F). Then A is called a Fredholm
operator if :
(i) A is double splitting; that is, both the kernel and the image of A are closed and have closed complement;
(ii) the kernel of A is ï¬nite dimensional;
(iii) the range of A has ï¬nite codimension.
In this case, if n = dim(ker A) and p = codim(range (A)), index (A) := n âˆ’p is the index of A. If M and
N are C1 manifolds and f : M â†’N is a C1 map, we say f is a Fredholm map if for every x âˆˆM, Txf
is a Fredholm operator.
Condition (i) follows from (ii) and (iii); see Exercises 2.2-8 and 2.2-14. A map g between topological spaces
is called locally closed if every point in the domain of deï¬nition of g has an open neighborhood U such
that g| cl (U) is a closed map (i.e., maps closed sets to closed sets).
3.6.11 Lemma.
A Fredholm map is locally closed.
Proof.
By the local representative theorem we may suppose our Fredholm map has the form f(e, x) =
(e, Î·(e, x)), for e âˆˆD1, and x âˆˆD2, where f : D1 Ã— D2 â†’E Ã— Rp and D1 âŠ‚E, D2 âŠ‚Rn are open
unit balls. Let U1 and U2 be open balls with cl(U1) âŠ‚D1 and cl(U2) âŠ‚D2. Let U = U1 Ã— U2 so that
cl(U) = cl(U1) Ã— cl(U2). Then f| cl(U) is closed. To see this, suppose A âŠ‚cl(U) is closed; to show f(A) is
closed, choose a sequence {(ei, yi)} such that (ei, yi) â†’(e, y) as i â†’âˆand (ei, yi) âˆˆf(A), say (ei, yi) =
f(ei, xi), where (ei, xi) âˆˆA. Since xi âˆˆcl(U2) and cl(U2) is compact, we may assume xi â†’x âˆˆcl(U2). Then
(ei, xi) â†’(e, x). Since A is closed, (e, x) âˆˆA, and f(e, x) = (e, y), so (e, y) âˆˆf(A). Thus f(A) is closed.

Sardâ€™s theorem deals with the genericity of the surjectivity of the derivative of a map. We now address

3.6.13 Lemma.

3.6.14 Proposition.
Let f : M â†’N be a C1-map of manifolds. The set
P = { x âˆˆM | f is an immersion at x }
is open in M.
Proof.
It suï¬ƒces to prove the proposition locally. If E and F are the models of M and N respectively and
if f : U â†’E is immersive at x âˆˆU âŠ‚E, then Df(x) âˆˆIL(E, F). By Lemma 3.6.13, (Df)âˆ’1(IL(E, F)) is
open in U since Df : U â†’L(E, F) is continuous.
â– 
The analog of the openness statements in Propositions 3.6.7 and 3.6.14 for subimmersions follows from
Deï¬nition 3.5.15. Indeed, if f : M â†’N is a C1 map which is a subimmersion at x âˆˆM, then there is an
open neighborhood U of x, a manifold P, a submersion s : U â†’P, and an immersion j : P â†’N such that
f|U = j â—¦s. But this says that f is subimmersive at every point of U. Thus we have the following.

3.6.15 Proposition.
Let f : M â†’N be a C1-map of manifolds. Then the set
P = { x âˆˆM | f is a subimmersion at x }
is open in M.
If M or N are ï¬nite dimensional then P = { x âˆˆM | rank Txf is locally constant } by Proposition 3.5.16.
Lower semicontinuity of the rank (i.e., each point x âˆˆM admits an open neighborhood of U such that
rank Tyf â‰¥rank Txf for all y âˆˆU; see Exercise 2.5-9(i)) implies that P is dense. Indeed, if V is any open
subset of M, by lower semicontinuity { x âˆˆV | rank Txf is maximal } is open in V and obviously contained
in P. Thus we have proved the following.
3.6.16 Proposition.
Let f : M â†’N be a C1-map of manifolds where at least one of M or N are ï¬nite
dimensional. Then the set
P = { x âˆˆM | f is a subimmersion at x }
is dense in M.
3.6.17 Corollary.
Let f : M â†’N be a C1 injective map of manifolds and let dim(M) = m. Then the set
P = { x âˆˆM | f is immersive at x } is open and dense in M. In particular, if dim(N) = n, then m â‰¤n.
Proof.
By Propositions 3.6.15 and 3.6.16, it suï¬ƒces to show that if f : M â†’N is a C1-injective map
which is subimmersive at x, then it is immersive at x. Indeed, if f|U = jâ—¦s where U is an open neighborhood
of x on which j is injective, then the submersion s must also be injective. Since submersions are locally onto,
this implies that s is a diï¬€eomorphism in a neighborhood of x, that is, f restricted to a suï¬ƒciently small
neighborhood of x is an immersion.

the existence and uniqueness of integral curves of C1 vector ï¬elds. This material will be treated in Chapter

Given f, Ï• and Î½ the set of possible stationary solutions u is denoted S(f, Ï•, Î½). A theorem of Foias and

We refer the reader to the cited paper for the precise (Sobolev) spaces needed for f, Ï•, u, and rather give

One can also prove a similar generic ï¬niteness result for an open dense set of boundaries âˆ‚â„¦using a

4
Vector Fields and Dynamical Systems
This chapter studies vector ï¬elds and the dynamical systems they determine. The ensuing chapters will
study the related topics of tensors and diï¬€erential forms. A basic operation introduced in this chapter is
the Lie derivative of a function or a vector ï¬eld. It is introduced in two diï¬€erent ways, algebraically as a
type of directional derivative and dynamically as a rate of change along a ï¬‚ow. The Lie derivative formula
asserts the equivalence of these two deï¬nitions. The Lie derivative is a basic operation used extensively in
diï¬€erential geometry, general relativity, Hamiltonian mechanics, and continuum mechanics.
4.1

This section introduces vector ï¬elds and the ï¬‚ows they determine. This topic puts together and globalizes
two basic ideas we learn in undergraduate calculus: the study of vector ï¬elds on the one hand and diï¬€erential
equations on the other.

In Â§4.3 we shall see that singular points, where the vector ï¬eld vanishes, are of great interest in dynamics.
The straightening out theorem does not claim anything about these points. Instead, one needs to appeal to
more sophisticated normal form theorems; see Guckenheimer and Holmes [1983].
Now we turn our attention from local ï¬‚ows to global considerations. These ideas center on considering
the ï¬‚ow of a vector ï¬eld as a whole, extended as far as possible in the t-variable.

inf ) of the times of existence of the integral curves through m; T +(m) (resp., T âˆ’(m)) is called the positive
(resp., negative) lifetime of m.

The support of a vector ï¬eld X deï¬ned on a manifold M is deï¬ned to be the closure of the set { m âˆˆ
M | X(m) Ì¸= 0 }.
4.1.20 Corollary.
A Cr vector ï¬eld with compact support on a manifold M is complete. In particular, a
Cr vector ï¬eld on a compact manifold is complete.
Completeness corresponds to well-deï¬ned dynamics persisting eternally. In some circumstances (shock
waves in ï¬‚uids and solids, singularities in general relativity, etc.) one has to live with incompleteness or

we use the notation X[f] = df Â· X for the derivative of f in the direction X. Here f : E â†’R and df stands

Invariant Sets

4.2
Vector Fields as Diï¬€erential Operators
In the previous section vector ï¬elds were studied from the point of view of dynamics; that is in terms of the
ï¬‚ows they generate. Before continuing the development of dynamics, we shall treat some of the algebraic
aspects of vector ï¬elds. The speciï¬c goal of the section is the development of the Lie derivative of functions
and vector ï¬elds and its relationship with ï¬‚ows. One important feature is the behavior of the constructions
under mappings. The operations should be as natural or covariant as possible when subjected to a mapping.
We begin with a discussion of the action of mappings on functions and vector ï¬elds. First, recall some
notation. Let Cr(M, F) denote the space of Cr maps f : M â†’F, where F is a Banach space, and let Xr(M)

In fact it is obvious that every diï¬€eomorphism induces an algebra automorphism of F(M). The following

functions and measurable automorphisms.)
4.2.36 Theorem.
Let M be a paracompact secondâ€“countable ï¬nite dimensinal manifold. Let Î± : F(M) â†’

unique Câˆdiï¬€eomorphism Ï• : M â†’M such that Î±(f) = f â—¦Ï•.
Remarks.

4.2 Vector Fields as Diï¬€erential Operators
251
A. There is a similar theorem for paracompact secondâ€“countable Banach manifolds; here we assume
that there are invertible linear maps Î±F : Câˆ(M, F) â†’Câˆ(M, F) for each Banach space F such
that for any bilinear continuous map B : F Ã— G â†’H we have Î±H(B(f, g)) = B(Î±F (f), Î±G(g))
for f âˆˆCâˆ(M, F) and g âˆˆCâˆ(M, G). The conclusion is the same: there is a Câˆdiï¬€eomorphism
Ï• : M â†’M such that Î±F (f) = f â—¦Ï• for all F and all f âˆˆCâˆ(M, G). Alternative to assuming this for
all F, one can take F = R and assume that M is modelled on a Banach space that has a norm that

4.2.37 Lemma.
Let M be a (ï¬nite-dimensional) paracompact second countable manifold and Î² : F(M) â†’
R be a nonzero algebra homomorphism. Then there is a unique point m âˆˆM such that Î²(f) = f(m).
Proof.
(Following suggestions of H. Bercovici.) Uniqueness is clear, as before, since for m1 Ì¸= m2 there
exists a bump function f âˆˆF(M) satisfying f(m1) = 0, f(m2) = 1.
To show existence, note ï¬rst that Î²(1) = 1. Indeed Î²(1) = Î²(12) = Î²(1)Î²(1) so that either Î²(1) = 0 or
Î²(1) = 1. But Î²(1) = 0 would imply Î² is identically zero since Î²(f) = Î²(1 Â· f) = Î²(1) Â· Î²(f), contrary to our
hypotheses. Therefore we must have Î²(1) = 1 and thus Î²(c) = c for c âˆˆR. For m âˆˆM, let
Ann(m) = { f âˆˆF(M) | f(m) = 0 }.
Second, we claim that it is enough to show that there is an m âˆˆM such that ker Î² = { f âˆˆF(M) | Î²(f) =
0 } = Ann(m). Clearly, if Î²(f) = f(m) for some m, then ker Î² = Ann(m). Conversely, if this holds for
some m âˆˆM and f Ì¸âˆˆker Î², let c = Î²(f) and note that f âˆ’c âˆˆker Î² = Ann(m), so f(m) = c and thus
Î²(f) = f(m) for all f âˆˆF(M).
To prove that ker Î² = Ann(m) for some m âˆˆM, note that both are ideals in F(M); that is, if f âˆˆker Î²,
(resp., Ann(m)), and g âˆˆF(M), then fg âˆˆker Î² (resp., Ann(m)). Moreover, both of them are maximal
ideals; that is, if I is another ideal of F(M), with I Ì¸= F(M), and ker Î² âŠ‚I, (resp., Ann(m) âŠ‚I) then
necessarily ker Î² = I (resp. Ann(m) = I). For ker Î² this is seen in the following way: since R is a ï¬eld, it has
no ideals except 0 and itself; but Î²(I) is an ideal in R, so Î²(I) = 0, that is, I = ker Î², or Î²(I) = R = Î²(F(M)).

This supplement investigates to what extent vector ï¬elds and tangent vectors are characterized by their
derivation properties on functions, if the underlying manifold is ï¬nite dimensional and of a ï¬nite diï¬€er-
entiability class. We start by studying vector ï¬elds. Recall from Proposition 4.2.9 that a derivation Î¸ is
an R-linear map from Fk+1(M) to Fk(M) satisfying the Leibniz rule, that is, Î¸(fg) = fÎ¸(g) + gÎ¸(f) for
f, g âˆˆFk+1(M), if the diï¬€erentiability class of M is at least k + 1.
4.2.38 Theorem (A. Blass).
Let M be a Ck+2 ï¬nite-dimensional manifold, where k â‰¥0. The collection
of all derivations Î¸ from Fk+1(M) to Fk(M) is isomorphic to Xk(M) as a real vector space.
Proof.
By the remark following Theorem 4.2.16, there is a unique Ck vector ï¬eld X with the property
that Î¸|Fk+2(M) = Â£X|Fk+2(M). Thus, all we have to do is show that Î¸ and Â£X agree on Ck+1 functions.
Replacing Î¸ with Î¸ âˆ’Â£X, we can assume that Î¸ annihilates all Ck+2 functions and we want to show that it
also annihilates all Ck+1 functions. As in the proof of Theorem 4.2.16, it suï¬ƒces to work in a chart, so we
can assume without loss of generality that M = Rn.
Let f be a Ck+1 function and ï¬x p âˆˆRn. We need to prove that (Î¸f)(p) = 0. For simplicity, we will
show this for p = 0, the proof for general p following by centering the following arguments at p instead
of 0. Replacing f by the diï¬€erence between f and its Taylor polynomial of order k + 1 about 0, we can
assume f(0) = 0, and the ï¬rst k + 1 derivatives vanish at 0, since Î¸ evaluated at the origin annihilates any
polynomial. We shall prove that f = g + h, where g and h are two Ck+1 functions, satisfying g|U = 0 and
h|V = 0, where U, V are open sets such that 0 âˆˆcl(U)  cl(V ). Then, since Î¸ is a local operator, Î¸g|U = 0
and Î¸h|V = 0, whence by continuity Î¸g|cl(U) = 0 and Î¸h|cl(V ) = 0. Hence (Î¸f)(0) = (Î¸g)(0) + (Î¸h)(0) = 0
and the theorem will be proved.

We do not know of an example of a derivation not given by a vector ï¬eld on a C1-manifold.
In inï¬nite dimensions, the proof would require the norm of the model space to be Câˆaway from the origin
and the function Ïˆ in the lemma bounded with all derivatives bounded on the unit sphere. Unfortunately,
this does not seem feasible under realistic hypotheses.
The foregoing proof is related to the method of â€œblowing-upâ€ a singularity; see for example Takens
[1974] and Buchner, Marsden, and Schecter [1983a]. There are also diï¬ƒculties with this method in inï¬nite
dimensions in other problems, such as the Morse lemma (see Golubitsky and Marsden [1983] and Buchner,
Marsden, and Schecter [1983b]).

4.3
An Introduction to Dynamical Systems
We have seen quite a bit of theoretical development concerning the interplay between the two aspects of
vector ï¬elds, namely as diï¬€erential operators and as ordinary diï¬€erential equations. It is appropriate now
to look a little more closely at geometric aspects of ï¬‚ows.
Much of the work in this section holds for inï¬nite-dimensional as well as ï¬nite-dimensional manifolds.
The reader who knows or is willing to learn some spectral theory from functional analysis can make the
generalization.
This section is intended to link up the theory of this book with courses in ordinary diï¬€erential equations
that the reader may have taken. The section will be most beneï¬cial if it is read with such a course in mind.
We begin by introducing some of the most basic terminology regarding the stability of ï¬xed points.

4.3.1 Deï¬nition.
Let X be a C1 vector ï¬eld on an n-manifold M. A point m is called a critical point
(also called a singular point or an equilibirum point) of X if X(m) = 0. The linearization of X at a
critical point m is the linear map

Some remarks will clarify this deï¬nition. Ft leaves m ï¬xed: Ft(m) = m, since c(t) â‰¡m is the unique
integral curve through m. Conversely, it is obvious that if Ft(m) = m for all t, then m is a critical point.
Thus TmFt is a linear map of TmM to itself and so its t-derivative at 0, producing another linear map of
TmM to itself, makes sense.

4.3.10 Deï¬nition.
Let X âˆˆXr(M), r â‰¥1, and let m be an equilibrium solution for X, that is, X(m) = 0.
A Liapunov function for X at m is a continuous function L : U â†’R deï¬ned on a neighborhood U of m,
diï¬€erentiable on U\{m}, and satisfying the following conditions:
(i)

The Liapunov function L is said to be strict, if (ii) is replaced by (ii)â€² X[L] < 0 in U\{m}.
Conditions (i) and (iii) are called the potential well hypothesis. In ï¬nite dimensions, (iii) follows
automatically from compactness of the sphere of radius Îµâ€² and (i). By the Lie derivative formula, condition
(ii) is equivalent to the statement: L is decreasing along integral curves of X.

Next we turn to cases where the equilibirum need not be stable.
A critical point is called hyperbolic or elementary if none of its characteristic exponents has zero real
part. A generalization of Liapunovâ€™s theorem called the Hartmanâ€“Grobman theorem shows that near
a hyperbolic critical point the ï¬‚ow looks like that of its linearization. (See Hartman [1973, Chapter 9]
and Nelson [1969, Chapter 3], for proofs and discussions.) In the plane, the possible hyperbolic ï¬‚ows near
a critical point are summarized in the table below and shown in Figure 4.3.2. (Remember that for real
systems, the characteristic exponents occur in conjugate pairs.)

Now we discuss the generic nonlinear case; that is, let m be a hyperbolic equilibrium of the vector ï¬eld
X and let Ft be its ï¬‚ow. Deï¬ne the inset of m by
In(m) = { mâ€² âˆˆM | Ft(mâ€²) â†’m as t â†’+âˆ}
and similarly, the outset is deï¬ned by
Out(m) = { mâ€² âˆˆM | Ft(mâ€²) â†’m as t â†’âˆ’âˆ}.
In the case of a linear system, Ë™x = Ax, where A has no eigenvalue on the imaginary axis (so the origin is
a hyperbolic critical point), In(0) is the generalized eigenspace of the eigenvalues with negative real parts,
while Out(0) is the generalized eigenspace corresponding to the eigenvalues with positive real parts. Clearly,
these are complementary subspaces. The dimension of the linear subspace In(0) is called the stability index
of the critical point. The Hartmanâ€“Grobman linearization theorem states that the phase portrait of
X near m is topologically conjugate to the phase portrait of the linear system Ë™x = Ax, near the origin,
where A = Xâ€²(m), the linearized vector ï¬eld at m. This means there is a homeomorphism of the two
domains, preserving the oriented trajectories of the respective ï¬‚ows. Thus in this nonlinear hyperbolic case,
the inset and outset are C0 submanifolds. Another important theorem of dynamical systems theory, the

266
4. Vector Fields and Dynamical Systems
In(m0)
Out(m0)
Figure 4.3.3. Insets and outsets
stable manifold theorem (Smale [1967]) says that in addition, these are smooth, injectively immersed
submanifolds, intersecting transversally at the critical point m. See Figure 4.3.3 for an illustration showing
part of the inset and outset near the critical point.
It follows from these important results that there are (up to topological conjugacy) only a few essentially
diï¬€erent phase portraits, near hyperbolic critical points. These are classiï¬ed by the dimension of their insets,
called the stability index, which is denoted by S(X, m) for m an equilibrium, as in the linear case.
The word index comes up in this context with another meaning. If M is ï¬nite dimensional and m is a
critical point of a vector ï¬eld X, the topological index of m is +1 if the number of eigenvalues (counting
multiplicities) with negative real part is even and is âˆ’1 if it is odd. Let this index be denoted I(X, m), so
that I(X, m) = (âˆ’1)S(X,m). The PoincarÂ´eâ€“Hopf index theorem states that if M is compact and X
only has (isolated) hyperbolic critical points, then

where Ï‡(M) is the Eulerâ€“PoincarÂ´e characteristic of M. For isolated nonhyperbolic critical points the index

or Guillemin and Pollack [1974, p. 133].

Another basic ingredient in the qualitative theory is the notion of a closed orbit, also called a limit
cycle.
4.3.18 Deï¬nition.
An orbit Î³(t) for a vector ï¬eld X is called closed when Î³(t) is not a ï¬xed point and
there is a Ï„ > 0 such that Î³(t + Ï„) = Î³(t) for all t. The inset of Î³, In(Î³), is the set of points m âˆˆM such
that Ft(m) â†’Î³ as t â†’+âˆ(i.e., the distance between Ft(m) and the (compact) set { Î³(t) | 0 â‰¤t â‰¤Ï„ }
tends to zero as t â†’âˆ). Likewise, the outset, Out(Î³), is the set of points tending to Î³ as t â†’âˆ’âˆ.
4.3.19 Example.
One of the earliest occurrences of an attractive closed orbit in an important application
is found in Baron Rayleighâ€™s model for the violin string (see Rayleigh [1887, Volume 1, Section 68a]),
Â¨u + k1 Ë™u + k3 Ë™u3 + Ï‰2u = 0,
k1 < 0 < k3,
or equivalently,
Ë™u = v,
Ë™v = âˆ’k1v âˆ’k3v3 âˆ’Ï‰2u,
with the phase portrait shown in Figure 4.3.7.
This phase portrait has an unstable focus at the origin, with an attractive closed orbit around it. That is,
the closed orbit Î³ is a limiting set for every point in its basin (or inset) In(Î³), which is an open set of the
domain. In fact the entire plane (excepting the origin) comprises the basin of this closed orbit. Thus every
trajectory tends asymptotically to the limit cycle Î³ and winds around closer and closer to it. Meanwhile this
closed orbit is a periodic function of time, in the sense of Deï¬nition 4.3.18. Thus the eventual (asymptotic)
behavior of every trajectory (other than the unstable constant trajectory at the origin) is periodic; it is an
oscillation.
This picture thus models the sustained oscillation of the violin string, under the inï¬‚uence of the moving
bow. Related systems occur in electrical engineering under the name van der Pol equation. (See Hirsch and
Smale [1974, Chapter 10] for a discussion.)

4.3.29 Deï¬nition.

trajectory Ft(s) winds towards Î³, and this is equivalent to saying that Î˜k(s) tends to m as k â†’+âˆ.
The inset and outset of m âˆˆS are classiï¬ed by linear algebra, as there is an analogue of the linearization
theorem for maps at hyperbolic critical points. The linearization theorem for maps says that there is a
C0 coordinate chart on S, in which the local representative of Î˜ is a linear map. Recall that in the hyperbolic
case, the spectrum of this linear isomorphism avoids the unit circle. The eigenvalues inside the unit circle
determine the generalized eigenspace of contraction that is, the inset of m âˆˆS under the iterates of Î˜. The
eigenvalues outside the unit circle similarly determine the outset of m âˆˆS. Although this argument provides
only local C0 submanifolds, the global stable manifold theorem improves this: the inset and outset of a
ï¬xed point of a diï¬€eomorphism are smooth, injectively immersed submanifolds meeting transversally at m.
Returning to closed orbits, the inset and outset of Î³ âŠ‚M may be visualized by choosing a section Sm at
every point m âˆˆÎ³. The inset and outset of Î³ in M intersect each section Sm in submanifolds of Sm, meeting
transversally at m âˆˆÎ³. In fact, In(Î³) is a cylinder over Î³, that is, a bundle of injectively immersed disks. So,
likewise, is Out(Î³). And these two cylinders intersect transversally in Î³, as shown in Figure 4.3.11. These
bundles need not be trivial.
Figure 4.3.11. Insets and outsets for periodic orbits
Another argument is sometimes used to study the inset and outset of a closed orbit, in place of the
PoincarÂ´e section technique described before, and is originally due to Smale [1967]. The ï¬‚ow Ft leaves the
closed orbit invariant. A special coordinate chart may be found in a neighborhood of Î³. The neighborhood

274
4. Vector Fields and Dynamical Systems
is a disk bundle over Î³, and the ï¬‚ow Ft, is a bundle map. On each ï¬ber, Ft is a linear map of the form
ZteRt, where Zt is a constant, and R is a linear map. Thus, if s = (m, x) is a point in the chart, the local
representative of Ft is given by the expression
Ft(m, x) = (mt, ZteRt Â· x)
called the Floquet normal form. This is the linearization theorem for closed orbits. A related result,
the Floquet theorem, eliminates the dependence of Zt on t, by making a further (time-dependent) change
of coordinates (see Hartman [1973, Chapter 4, Section 6], or Abraham and Robbin [1967]). Finally, linear
algebra applied to the linear map R in the exponent of the Floquet normal form, establishes the C0 structure
of the inset and outset of Î³.
To get an overall picture of a dynamical system in which all critical elements (critical points and closed
orbits) are hyperbolic, we try to draw or visualize the insets and outsets of each. Those with open insets are
attractors, and their open insets are their basins. The domain is divided into basins by the separatrices,
which includes the insets of all the nonattractive (saddle-type) critical elements (and possible other, more
complicated limit sets, called chaotic attractors, not described here.)
We conclude with an example of suï¬ƒcient complexity, which has been at the center of dynamical system
theory for over a century.
4.3.30 Example.
The simple pendulum equation may be â€œsimpliï¬edâ€ by approximating sin x by two
terms of its MacLaurin expansion. The resulting system is a model for a nonlinear spring with linear
damping,
Ë™x = v,
Ë™v = âˆ’cv âˆ’kx + k
3x3.
Adding a periodic forcing term, we have
Ë™x = v,
Ë™v = âˆ’cv âˆ’kx + k
3x4 + F cos Ï‰t.
This time-dependent system in the plane is transformed into an autonomous system in a solid ring by adding
an angular variable proportional to the time, Î¸ = Ï‰t. Thus,
Ë™x = v,
Ë™x = âˆ’cv âˆ’kx + k
3x3 + F cos Î¸,
Ë™Î¸ = Ï‰
Although this was introduced by Baron Rayleigh to study the resonance of tuning forks, piano strings, and
so on, in his classic 1877 book, Theory of Sound , this system is generally named the Duï¬ƒng equation
after Duï¬ƒng who obtained the ï¬rst important results in 1908 (see Stoker [1950] for additional information).
â™¦
Depending on the values of the three parameters (c, k, F) various phase portraits are obtained. One of
these is shown in Figure 4.3.12, adapted from the experiments of Hayashi [1964]. There are three closed
orbits: two attracting, one of saddle type. The inset of the saddle is a cylinder topologically, but the whole
cylinder revolves around the saddle-type closed orbit. This cylinder is the separatrix between the two basins.
For other parameter values the dynamics can be chaotic (see for example, Holmes [1979a, 1979b] and Ueda
[1980]).
For further information on dynamical systems, see, for example, Guckenheimer and Holmes [1983].

(ii)

integral manifold of E at m containing m, whose tangent bundle is exactly E restricted to N.

4.4.3 Theorem (The Local Frobenius Theorem).
A subbundle E of TM is involutive if and only if it is
integrable.
Proof.

through m âˆˆM. At points of N, X and Y are tangent to N, so deï¬ne restricted vector ï¬elds X|N, Y |N on

[X|N, Y |N] = [X, Y ]|N.
Since N is a manifold, [X|N, Y |N] is a vector ï¬eld on N, so [X, Y ] is tangent to N and hence in E.

The method of using the time-one map of a time-dependent ï¬‚ow to provide the appropriate coordinate
change is useful in a number of situations and is called the method of Lie transforms. An abstract version
of this method is given later in Example 5.4.7; we shall use this method again in Chapter 6 to prove the
PoincarÂ´e lemma and in Chapter 8 to prove the Darboux theorem.
Note: The method of Lie transforms is also used in singularity theory and bifurcation theory (see Golubit-

is based on Palais [1969] and Golubitsky and Marsden [1983]. For a proof of the Frobenius theorem from
the implicit function theorem using manifolds of maps in the spirit of Supplement 4.1C, see Penot [1970].
See Exercise 4.4-6 for another proof of the Frobenius theorem in ï¬nite dimensions.

4.4.5 Examples.
A.
The trivial foliation of a connected manifold M has only one leaf, M itself. It has codimension zero.
If M is ï¬nite dimensional, both M and the leaf have the same dimension. Conversely, on a ï¬nite-dimensional
connected manifold M, a foliation of dimension equal to dim(M) is the trivial foliation.
B.
The discrete foliation of a manifold M is the only zero-dimensional foliation; its leaves are all points
of M. If M is ï¬nite dimensional, the dimension of M is the codimension of this foliation.
C.
A vector ï¬eld X that never vanishes on M determines a foliation; its leaves are the maximal integral
curves of the vector ï¬eld X. The fact that this is a foliation is the straightening out theorem (see Â§4.1).
D.
Let f : M â†’N be a submersion. It deï¬nes a foliation on M (of codimension equal to dim(N) if
dim(N) is ï¬nite) by the collection of all connected components of f âˆ’1(n) when n varies throughout N. The
fact that this is a foliation is given by Theorem 3.5.4. In particular, we see that E âŠ•F is foliated by the
family {E Ã— {f}}fâˆˆF .

(The Reeb Foliation on the Solid Torus and the Klein Bottle; Reeb [1952]). We claim that in the

G.
(The Reeb Foliation on S3; Reeb [1952]). Two orientable Reeb foliations on the solid torus determine
a foliation on S3 in the following way. The sphere S3 is the union of two solid tori which are identiï¬ed

the other and vice-versa. This foliation is called the Reeb foliation of
S3; it has one leaf diï¬€eomorphic
to the torus T2 and all its other leaves are diï¬€eomorphic to R2 and accumulate on the torus. Below we
describe, pictorially, the decomposition of S3 in two solid tori. Remove the north pole, (1, 0, 0, 0), of S3 and
stereographically project the rest of S3 onto R3. In the plane (x2, x4) draw two equal circles centered on
the x2-axis at the points a and b, where âˆ’a = b. Rotating about the x4-axis yields the solid torus in R3.
Now draw all of the circles in the (x2, x4) plane minus the two discs, centered on the x4-axis and passing
through a and b. Each such circle yields two connected arcs joining the two discs. In addition, consider
the two portions of the x2-axis: the line joining the two discs and the two rays going oï¬€from each disk
separately. (See Figure 4.4.4.) Now rotate this ï¬gure about the x4-axis. All arcs joining the disks generate
smooth surfaces diï¬€eomorphic to R2 and each such surface meets the solid torus along a parallel. Only the
two rays emanating from the disks generate a surface diï¬€eomorphic to the cylinder. Now add the north

(i)

Proof.

There is an important global topological condition that integrable subbundles must satisfy that was
discovered by Bott [1970]. The result, called the Bott Vanishing Theorem, can be found, along with
related results, by readers with background in algebraic topology, in Lawson [1977].
The leaves of a foliation are characterized by the following property.
4.4.8 Proposition.
Let Î¦ be a foliation on M. Then x and y are in the same leaf if and only if x and y
lie on the same integral curve of a vector ï¬eld X deï¬ned on an open set in M and which is tangent to the
foliation Î¦.

vector ï¬eld on Â£ and thus any integral curve of X starting in Â£ stays in Â£. Since y is on such an integral
curve, it follows that y âˆˆÂ£.
Conversely, let x, y âˆˆÂ£ and let c(t) be a smooth non-intersecting curve in Â£ such that c(0) = x, c(1) = y,
câ€²(t) Ì¸= 0. (This can always be done on a connected manifold by showing that the set of points that can be

Remark.
Novikov [1965] has shown that the Reeb foliation is in some sense typical. A foliation Î¦ on M
is said to be transversally orientable if TM = T(M, Î¦) âŠ•E, where E is an orientable subbundle of TM
(see Exercise 6.5-14 for the deï¬nition). A foliation on a three dimensional manifold M is said to have a
Reeb component if it has a compact leaf diï¬€eomorphic to T2 or K and if the foliation within this torus
or Klein bottle is diï¬€eomorphic to the orientable or non-orientable Reeb foliation in the solid torus or the

288
4. Vector Fields and Dynamical Systems
solid Klein bottle. Novikov has proved the following remarkable result. Let Î¦ be a transversally orientable
C2 codimension one foliation of a compact three dimensional manifold M. If Ï€1(M) is ï¬nite, then Î¦ has a
Reeb component, which may or may not be orientable. If Ï€2(M) Ì¸= 0 (with no hypotheses on Ï€1(M)) and Î¦
has no Reeb components, then all the leaves of Î¦ are compact with ï¬nite fundamental group. We refer the
reader to Camacho and Neto [1985] for a proof of this result and to this reference and Lawson [1977] for a
study of foliations in general.
â™¦
Even though foliations encompass â€œniceâ€ partitions of a manifold into submanifolds, there are important
situations when foliations are inappropriate because they are not regular or the leaves jump in dimension
from point to point. Consider, for example, R2 as a union of concentric circles centered at the origin. As
this example suggests, one would like to relax the condition that M/R be a manifold, provided that M/R
turns out to be a union of manifolds that ï¬t â€œnicelyâ€ together. Stratiï¬cations, another concept allowing us
to â€œstackâ€ manifolds, turn out to be the natural tool to describe the topology of orbit spaces of compact
Lie group actions or non-compact Lie group actions admitting a slice (see, for instance, Bredon [1972],
Burghelea, Albu, and Ratiu [1975], Fischer [1970], and Bourguigon [1975]). We shall limit ourselves to the
deï¬nition in the ï¬nite-dimensional case and some simple remarks.

Tensors
In the previous chapter we studied vector ï¬elds and functions on manifolds. In this chapter these objects are
generalized to tensor ï¬elds, which are sections of vector bundles built out of the tangent bundle. This study
is continued in the next chapter when we discuss diï¬€erential forms, which are tensors with special symmetry
properties. One of the objectives of this chapter is to extend the pull-back and Lie derivative operations
from functions and vector ï¬elds to tensor ï¬elds.

Metric Tensors.
A basic example of a symmetric covariant tensor ï¬eld is the following.
5.2.12 Deï¬nition.
A weak pseudo-Riemannian metric on a manifold M is deï¬ned to be a tensor ï¬eld
g âˆˆT 0
2 (M) that is symmetric and weakly nondegenerate, that is, such that at each m âˆˆM, g(m)(vm, wm) = 0
for all wm âˆˆTmM implies vm = 0. A strong pseudo-Riemannian metric is a 2-tensor ï¬eld that, in
addition is strongly nondegenerate for all m âˆˆM; that is, the map vm â†’g(m)(vm, Â·) is an isomorphism
of TmM onto T âˆ—
mM. A weak (resp., strong) pseudo-Riemannian metric is called weak (resp., strong)
Riemannian if in addition g(m)(vm, vm) > 0 for all vm âˆˆTmM, vm Ì¸= 0.
It is not hard to show that strong Riemannian manifold is necessarily modeled on a Hilbertizable space;
that is, the model space has an equivalent norm arising from an inner product. For ï¬nite-dimensional
manifolds weak and strong metrics coincide: indeed TmM and T âˆ—
mM have the same dimension and so a
one-to-one map of TmM to T âˆ—
mM is an isomorphism. It is possible to have weak metrics on a Banach or
Hilbert manifold that are not strong. For example, the L2 inner product on M = C0([0, 1], R) is a weak
metric that is not strong. For a similar Hilbert space example, see Exercise 5.2-3.
Any Hilbert space is a Riemannian manifold with a constant metric equal to the inner product. A sym-
metric bilinear (weakly) nondegenerate two-form on any Banach space provides an example of a (weak)
pseudo-Riemannian constant metric. A pseudo-Riemannian manifold used in the theory of special relativity
is R4 with the Minkowski pseudo-Riemannian metric
g(x)(v, w) = v1w1 + v2w2 + v3w3 âˆ’v4w4,
where x, v, w âˆˆR4.

We close this section with an important technique based on the dynamic approach to the Lie derivative,
called the Lie transform method. It has been used already in the proof of the Frobenius theorem (Â§4.4)
and we shall see it again in Chapters 6 and 9. The method is also used in the theory of normal forms (cf.
Takens [1974], Guckenheimer and Holmes [1983], and Golubitsky and Schaeï¬€er [1985]).

5.5
Partitions of Unity
A partition of unity is a technical device that is often used to piece smooth local tensor ï¬elds together to
form a smooth global tensor ï¬eld. Partitions of unity will be useful for studying integration; in this section
they are used to study when a manifold admits a Riemannian metric.
5.5.1 Deï¬nition.
If t is a tensor ï¬eld on a manifold M, the carrier of t is the set of m âˆˆM for which
t(m) Ì¸= 0, and is denoted carr(t). The support of t, denoted supp(t), is the closure of carr(t). We say t has
compact support if supp(t) is compact in M. An open set U âŠ‚M is called a Cr carrier if there exists
an f âˆˆFr(M), such that f â‰¥0 and U = carr(f). A collection of subsets {CÎ±} of a manifold M (or, more
generally, a topological space) is called locally ï¬nite if for each m âˆˆM, there is a neighborhood U of m
such that U âˆ©CÎ± = âˆ…except for ï¬nitely many indices Î±.
5.5.2 Deï¬nition.
A partition of unity on a manifold M is a collection {(Ui, gi)}, where
(i)
{Ui} is a locally ï¬nite open covering of M;
(ii)
gi âˆˆF(M), gi(m) â‰¥0 for all m âˆˆM, and supp(gi) âŠ‚Ui for all i;
(iii)
for each m âˆˆM, Î£igi(m) = 1. (By (i), this is a ï¬nite sum.)
If A = {(VÎ±, Ï•Î±)} is an atlas on M, a partition of unity subordinate to A is a partition of unity
{(Ui, gi)} such that each open set Ui is a subset of a chart domain VÎ±(i). If any atlas A has a subordinate
partition of unity, we say M admits partitions of unity.
Occasionally one works with Ck partitions of unity. They are deï¬ned in the same way except gi are only
required to be Ck rather than Câˆ.

To discuss the existence of partitions of unity and consequences thereof, we need some topological pre-
liminaries.
5.5.4 Deï¬nition.
Let S be a topological space. A covering {UÎ±} of S is called a reï¬nement of a covering

open covering of S has a locally ï¬nite reï¬nement of open sets, and S is Hausdorï¬€.

The case of C0-partitions of unity diï¬€ers drastically from the smooth case. Since we are primarily interested
in this latter case, we summarize the topological situation, without giving the proofs.
1.
If S is a Hausdorï¬€space, the following are equivalent:
(i)
S is normal.
(ii)
(Urysohnâ€™s lemma.) For any two closed nonempty disjoint sets A, B there is a continuous function
f : S â†’[0, 1] such that f(A) = 0 and f(B) = 1.
(iii)

there is a continuous extension G : S â†’[a, b] of g.
2.
A Hausdorï¬€space is paracompact iï¬€it admits a C0 partition of unity subordinate to any open covering.
It is clear that if {(Ui, gi)} is a continuous partition of unity subordinate to the given open covering
{VÎ±}, then by deï¬nition {Ui} is an open locally ï¬nite reï¬nement. The converseâ€”the existence of partitions
of unityâ€”is the hard part; the proof of this and of the equivalences of (i), (ii), and (iii) can be found for
instance in Kelley [1975] and Choquet [1969, Section 6]. These results are important for the rich supply of
continuous functions they provide. We shall not use these topological theorems in the rest of the book, but
we do want their smooth versions on manifolds.
Note that if M is a manifold admitting partitions of unity subordinate to any open covering, then M is
paracompact, and thus normal by Proposition 5.5.6. This already enables us to generalize (ii) and (iii) to
the smooth (or Ck) situation.

Notice that the preceding proposition holds in inï¬nite dimensions.
5.5.11 Proposition.
A connected Hausdorï¬€n-manifold admits a Riemannian metric if and only if it is
second countable. Hence for Hausdorï¬€n-manifolds (not necessarily connected) paracompactness and metriz-
ability are equivalent.
Proof.
If M is second countable, it admits partitions of unity by Theorem 5.5.7. Then the patching
construction (Theorem 5.5.3) gives a Riemannian metric on M by choosing in every chart the standard
inner product in Rn.
Conversely, assume M is Riemannian. By Proposition 5.5.10 it is a metric space, which is locally compact
and ï¬rst countable, being locally homeomorphic to Rn. By Theorem 1.6.14, it is second countable.
â– 
The main theorem on the existence of partitions of unity in the general case is as follows.
5.5.12 Theorem.
Any second-countable or paracompact manifold modeled on a separable Banach space
with a Ck norm away from the origin admits Ck partitions of unity. In particular paracompact (or second
countable) manifolds modeled on separable Hilbert spaces admit Câˆpartitions of unity.
5.5.13 Corollary.
Paracompact (or second countable) Hausdorï¬€manifolds modeled on separable real
Hilbert spaces admit Riemannian metrics.

Theorem 5.5.12 will be proved in Supplements 5.5A and 5.5B.
There are Hausdorï¬€nonparacompact n-manifolds. These manifolds are necessarily nonmetrizable and
do not admit partitions of unity. The standard example of a one-dimensional nonparacompact Hausdorï¬€
manifold is the â€œlong line.â€ In dimensions 2 and 3 such manifolds are constructed from the PrÂ¨ufer manifolds.
Since nonparacompact manifolds occur rarely in applications, we refer the reader to Spivak [1979, Volume

of S, it can be reï¬ned to a locally ï¬nite covering {WÎ²}. The ï¬rst lemma below will show that we can shrink

Theorem 5.5.12 now follows from Propositions 5.5.20, 5.5.19, and 5.5.17.
The situation with regard to Banach subspaces and submanifolds is clariï¬ed in the following proposition,
whose proof is an immediate consequence of Propositions 5.5.19 and 5.5.17.
5.5.21 Proposition.
(i)
If E is a Banach space admitting Ck partitions of unity then so does any closed subspace,
(ii)
If a manifold admits Ck partitions of unity subordinate to any open covering, then so does any sub-
manifold.
We shall not develop this discussion of partitions of unity on Banach manifolds any further, but we shall
end by quoting a few theorems that show how intimately connected partitions of unity are with the topology
of the model space. By Propositions 5.5.19 and 5.5.20, for separable Banach spaces one is interested whether
the norm is Ck away from the origin. Restrepo [1964] has shown that a separable Banach space has a C1
norm away from the origin if and only if its dual is separable. Bonic and Reis [1966] and Sundaresan [1967]
have shown that if the norms on E and Eâˆ—are diï¬€erentiable on E\{0} and Eâˆ—\{0}, respectively, then E is
reï¬‚exive, for E a real Banach space (not necessarily separable). Moreover, E is a Hilbert space if and only if
the norms on E and Eâˆ—are twice diï¬€erentiable away from the origin. This result has been strengthened by
Leonard and Sunderesan [1973], who show that a real Banach space is isometric to a Hilbert space if and
only if the norm is C2 away from the origin and the second derivative of e â†’âˆ¥eâˆ¥2/2 is bounded by 1 on
the unit sphere; see Rao [1972] for a related result. Palais [1965b] has shown that any paracompact Banach
manifold admits Lipschitz partitions of unity.
Because of the importance of the diï¬€erentiability class of the norm in Banach spaces there has been
considerable work in the direction of determining the exact diï¬€erentiability class of concrete function spaces.
Thus Bonic and Frampton [1966] have shown that the canonical norms on the spaces Lp(R), â„“p(R), p â‰¥1,
p < âˆare Câˆaway from the origin if p is even, Cpâˆ’1 with D(âˆ¥Â· âˆ¥pâˆ’1) Lipschitz, if p is odd, and C[p]
with D[p](âˆ¥Â· âˆ¥p) HÂ¨older continuous of order p âˆ’[p], if p is not an integer. The space c0 of sequences of real
numbers convergent to zero has an equivalent norm that is Câˆaway from the origin, a result due to Kuiper.
Using this result, Frampton and Tromba [1972] show that the Î›-spaces (closures of Câˆin the HÂ¨older norm)
admit a Câˆnorm away from the origin. The standard norm on the Banach space of continuous real valued
functions on [0, 1] is nowhere diï¬€erentiable. Moreover, since C0([0, 1], R) is separable with nonseparable dual,
it is impossible to ï¬nd an equivalent norm that is diï¬€erentiable away from the origin. To our knowledge it
is still an open problem whether C0([0, 1], R) admits Câˆpartitions of unity for k â‰¥1.
Finally, the only results known to us for nonseparable Hilbert spaces are those of Wells [1971, 1973], who
has proved that nonseparable Hilbert space admits C2 partitions of unity. The techniques used in the proof,
however, do not seem to indicate a general way to approach this problem.
Supplement 5.5C
Simple Connectivity of Fiber Bundles
The goal of this supplement is to discuss the homotopy lifting property for locally trivial continuous ï¬ber
bundles over a paracompact base. This theorem is shown to imply an important criterion on the simple
connectedness of the total space of ï¬ber bundles with paracompact base.
5.5.22 Theorem (Homotopy Lifting Theorem).
Let Ï€ : E â†’B be a locally trivial C0 ï¬ber bundle and
let M be a paracompact topological space. If h : [0, 1] Ã— M â†’B is a continuous homotopy and f : M â†’E
is any continuous map satisfying Ï€ â—¦f = h(0, Â·), there exists a continuous homotopy H : [0, 1] Ã— M â†’E

5.5 Partitions of Unity
333
satisfying Ï€ â—¦H = h and H(0, Â·) = f. If in addition, h ï¬xes some point m âˆˆM, that is h(t, m) is constant
for t in a segment âˆ†of [0, 1], then H(t, m) is also constant for t âˆˆâˆ†.
Remark.
The property in the statement of the theorem is called the homotopy lifting property. A
Hurewicz ï¬bration is a continuous surjective map Ï€ : E â†’B satisfying the homotopy lifting property
relative to any topological space M. Thus the theorem above says that a locally trivial C0 ï¬ber bundle is a
Hurewicz ï¬bration relative to paracompact spaces.
â™¦
See Steenrod [1957] and Huebsch [1955] for the proof.
5.5.23 Corollary.

simply connected, then E is simply connected.
Proof.

6
Diï¬€erential Forms
Diï¬€erential k-forms are tensor ï¬elds of type (0, k) that are completely antisymmetric. Such tensor ï¬elds arise
in many applications in physics, engineering, and mathematics. A hint at why this is so is the fact that the
classical operations of grad, div, and curl and the theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes can all be expressed
concisely in terms of diï¬€erential forms and an operator on diï¬€erential forms to be studied in this chapter,
the exterior derivative d. However, identities like âˆ‡Ã— (âˆ‡f) = 0 and âˆ‡Â· (âˆ‡Ã— X) = 0 are elegantly phrased
as the single identity d2 = 0. However, the examples of Hamiltonian mechanics and Maxwellâ€™s equations
(see Chapter 8) show that their applicability goes well beyond this.
The goal of the chapter is to develop the calculus of diï¬€erential forms, due largely to Cartan [1945]. The
exterior derivative operator d plays a central role; its properties and the expression of the Lie derivative in
terms of it will be developed.
6.1
Exterior Algebra
We begin with the exterior algebra of a vector space and extend this ï¬berwise to a vector bundle. As with
tensor ï¬elds, the most important case is the tangent bundle of a manifold, which is considered in the next
section.
We ï¬rst recall a few facts about the permutation group on k elements; some of these facts have already been
discussed in Â§2.2. Proofs of the results that we cite are obtainable from virtually any elementary algebra book.
The permutation group on k elements, denoted Sk, consists of all bijections Ïƒ : {1, . . . , k} â†’{1, . . . , k}

6.1.7 Deï¬nition.
The direct sum of the spaces k(E) (i = 0, 1, 2, . . . ) together with its structure of real
vector space and multiplication induced by âˆ§, is called the exterior algebra of E, or the Grassmann
algebra of E. It is denoted by (E).
Thus (E) is a graded associative algebra, that is, an algebra in which every element has a degree (a
k-form has degree k), and the degree map is additive on products (by Proposition 6.1.2 and Deï¬nition 6.1.3).
Elements of (E) may be written as ï¬nite sums of increasing degree exactly as one writes a polynomial as
a sum of monomials. Thus if a, b, c âˆˆR, Î± âˆˆ1(E) and Î² âˆˆ2(E) then a + bÎ± + cÎ² makes sense in (E).
The one-form Î± can be understood as an element of 1(E) and also of (E), where Î± is identiï¬ed with
0 + Î± + 0 + 0 + Â· Â· Â· .

In Chapter 2 we saw that the set of isomorphisms of E to F form an open subset of L(E, F). Using the

6.2.5 Proposition.
Suppose that E and F are ï¬nite-dimensional and let GL(E, F) denote those Ï• âˆˆ
L(E, F) that are isomorphisms. Then GL(E, F) is an open subset of L(E, F).
Proof.
If GL(E, F) = âˆ…, the conclusion is true. Otherwise, there is an isomorphism Ïˆ âˆˆGL(E, F). A map
Ï• in L(E, F) is an isomorphism if and only if Ïˆâˆ’1 â—¦Ï• is also. This happens precisely when det(Ïˆâˆ’1 â—¦Ï•) Ì¸= 0.
Therefore, GL(E, F) is the inverse image of R\{0} under the map taking Ï• to det (Ïˆâˆ’1 â—¦Ï•). Since this is
continuous and R\{0} is open, GL(E, F) is also open.

Orientation.
The basis elements of n (E) enable us to deï¬ne orientation or â€œhandednessâ€ of a vector
space.
6.2.6 Deï¬nition.
The nonzero elements of the one-dimensional space n(E) are called volume ele-
ments. If Ï‰1 and Ï‰2 are volume elements, we say Ï‰1 and Ï‰2 are equivalent iï¬€there is a c > 0 such
that Ï‰1 = cÏ‰2. An equivalence class [Ï‰] of volume elements on E is called an orientation on E. An ori-
ented vector space (E, [Ï‰]) is a vector space E together with an orientation [Ï‰] on E; [âˆ’Ï‰] is called the
reverse orientation. A basis {e1, . . . , en} of the oriented vector space (E, [Ï‰]) is called positively (resp.,
negatively) oriented, if Ï‰(e1, . . . , en) > 0 (resp., < 0).
The last statement is independent of the representative of the orientation [Ï‰], for if Ï‰â€² âˆˆ[Ï‰], then Ï‰â€² = cÏ‰
for some c > 0, and thus Ï‰â€²(e1, . . . , en) and Ï‰(e1, . . . , en) have the same sign. Also note that a vector
space E has exactly two orientations: one given by selecting an arbitrary dual basis {e1, . . . , en} and taking
[e1 âˆ§Â· Â· Â· âˆ§en]; the other is its reverse orientation.
This deï¬nition of orientation is related to the concept of orientation from calculus as follows. In R3, a
right-handed coordinate system like the one in Figure 6.2.1 is by convention positively oriented, as are all
other right-handed systems. On the other hand, any left-handed coordinate system, obtained for example
from the one in Figure 6.2.1 by interchanging x1 and x2, is by convention negatively oriented. Thus one would
call a positive orientation in R3 the set of all right-handed coordinate systems. The key to the abstraction of
this construction for any vector space lies in the observation that the determinant of the change of ordered
basis of two right-handed systems in R3 is always strictly positive. Thus, if E is an n-dimensional vector
space, deï¬ne an equivalence relation on the set of ordered bases in the following way: two bases {e1, . . . , en}
and {eâ€²
1, . . . , eâ€²
n} are equivalent iï¬€det Ï• > 0, where Ï• âˆˆGL(E) is given by Ï•(ei) = eâ€²
i, i = 1, . . . , n. We
can relate n-forms to the bases by associating to a basis {e1, . . . , en} and its dual basis {e1, . . . , en} the
n-form Ï‰ = e1 âˆ§Â· Â· Â· âˆ§en. The following proposition shows that this association gives an identiï¬cation of the
corresponding equivalence classes.
6.2.7 Proposition.
An orientation in a vector space is uniquely determined by an equivalence class of
ordered bases.

Volume Elements in Inner Product Spaces.
An important point is that to get a particular volume
element on E requires additional structure, although the determinant does not. The idea is based on the fact
that in R3 the volume of the parallelepiped P = P(x1, x2, x3) spanned by three positively oriented vectors
x1, x2, and x3 can be expressed independent of any basis as
Vol(P) = (det[âŸ¨xi, xjâŸ©])1/2,
where [âŸ¨xi, xjâŸ©] denotes the symmetric 3Ã—3 matrix whose entries are âŸ¨xi, xjâŸ©. If x1, x2, and x3 are negatively
oriented, det[âŸ¨xi, xjâŸ©] < 0 and so the formula has to be modiï¬ed to
Vol(P) = (| det[âŸ¨xi, xjâŸ©]|)1/2.

The Exterior Derivative, Interior Product, and Lie

The purpose of this section is to extend the diï¬€erential of functions to a map
d : â„¦k(M) â†’â„¦k+1(M)

The Exterior derivative on Inï¬nite-dimensional Manifolds
Now we discus the exterior derivative on inï¬nite-dimensional manifolds. Theorem 6.4.1 is rather awkward,
primarily because we cannot, without a lot of technicalities, pass from, for example, one-forms to two-forms
by linear combinations of decomposable two-forms, that is, two-forms of the type Î± âˆ§Î². However, there is
a simpler alternative available.
1. Adopt the formula in Proposition 6.4.11(ii) as the deï¬nition of d on any open subset of M. Note that
at ï¬rst it is deï¬ned as a multilinear function on vector ï¬elds and note that Â£X is already deï¬ned.

computation shows that d : â„¦k(M) â†’â„¦k+1(M) is well deï¬ned, depending only on the point values of
the vector ï¬elds.
3. One checks the basic properties of d. This can be done in two ways: directly, using the local formula,
or using the deï¬nition and the following lemma, easily deducible from the Hahnâ€“Banach theorem: if
a k-form Ï‰ is zero on any set of k vector ï¬elds X1, . . . , Xk âˆˆX(U) for all open sets U in M, then

Cohomology.
It is not true that closed forms are always exact (for example, on R2\{(0, 0)} or on a
sphereâ€”see Exercise 6.4-4). In fact, the quotient groups of closed forms by exact forms (called the deRham
cohomology groups of M) are important algebraic objects attached to a manifold; they are discussed
further in Â§7.6. Below we shall prove that on smoothly contractible manifolds, closed forms are always exact.
6.4.15 Deï¬nition.
Let t â‰¥1. Two Cr maps f, g : M â†’N are said to be (properly) Cr-homotopic, if

F(1, m) = g(m) for all m âˆˆM. The manifold M is called Cr-contractible if there exists a point m0 âˆˆM
and Cr-homotopy F of the constant map m â†’m0 with the identity map of M; F is called a Cr-contraction
of M to m0

the same standard volume form Âµ = dx âˆ§dy âˆ§dz.

6.5.3 Deï¬nition.
Let M be an orientable manifold. Two volume forms Âµ1 and Âµ2 on M are called equiv-
alent if there is an f âˆˆF(M) with f(m) > 0 for all m âˆˆM such that Âµ1 = fÂµ2. (This is clearly an
equivalence relation.) An orientation of M is an equivalence class [Âµ] of volume forms on M. An ori-
ented manifold (M, [Âµ]), is an orientable manifold M together with an orientation [Âµ] on M.
If [Âµ] is an orientation of M, then [âˆ’Âµ], (which is clearly another orientation) is called the reverse
orientation.
The next proposition tells us when [Âµ] and [âˆ’Âµ] are the only two orientations.

Orientation Preserving Maps.
The notion of orientation preserving maps between oriented manifolds
can now be deï¬ned.
6.5.10 Deï¬nition.
Let M and N be two orientable n-manifolds with volume forms ÂµM and ÂµN, re-
spectively. Then we call a Câˆmap f : M â†’N volume preserving (with respect to ÂµM and ÂµN) if
f âˆ—ÂµN = ÂµM, orientation preserving if f âˆ—(ÂµN) âˆˆ[ÂµM], and orientation reversing if f âˆ—(ÂµN) âˆˆ[âˆ’ÂµM].
An orientable manifold admitting (respectively, not admitting) an orientation reversing diï¬€eomorphism is
called reversible (respectively, non-reversible).
From Proposition 6.5.5, [f âˆ—ÂµN] depends only on [ÂµN]. Thus the ï¬rst part of the deï¬nition explicitly
depends on ÂµM and ÂµN, while the last four parts depend only on the orientations [ÂµM] and [ÂµN]. Furthermore,
we see from Proposition 6.5.5 that if f is volume preserving with respect to ÂµM and ÂµN, then f is volume
preserving with respect to hÂµM and gÂµN iï¬€h = g â—¦f. It is also clear that if f is volume preserving with
respect to ÂµM and ÂµN, then f is orientation preserving with respect to [ÂµM] and [ÂµN].
6.5.11 Proposition.
Let M and N be n-manifolds with volume forms ÂµM and ÂµN, respectively. Suppose
f : M â†’N is of class Câˆ. Then f âˆ—(ÂµN) is a volume form iï¬€f is a local diï¬€eomorphism; that is, for each
m âˆˆM, there is a neighborhood V of m such that f|V : V â†’f(V ) is a diï¬€eomorphism. If M is connected,
then f is a local diï¬€eomorphism iï¬€f is orientation preserving or orientation reversing.
Proof.
If f is a local diï¬€eomorphism, then clearly F âˆ—(ÂµN)(m) Ì¸= 0, by Proposition 6.2.3(ii). Conversely,
if f âˆ—(ÂµM) is a volume form, then the determinant of the derivative of the local representative is not zero,
and hence the derivative is an isomorphism. The result then follows by the inverse function theorem. The
second statement follows at once from the ï¬rst and Proposition 6.5.4.

Integration on Manifolds
The integral of an n-form on an n-manifold is deï¬ned by piecing together integrals over sets in Rn using
a partition of unity subordinate to an atlas. The change of variables theorem guarantees that the integral
is well deï¬ned, independent of the choice of atlas and partition of unity. Two basic theorems of integral
calculus, the change of variables theorem and Stokesâ€™ theorem, are discussed in detail along with some
applications.

of its basic properties. We begin with a summary of the basic results in Rn.

Stokesâ€™ Theorem
Stokesâ€™ theorem states that if Î± is an (n âˆ’1)-form on an orientable n-manifold M, then the integral of
dÎ± over M equals the integral of Î± over âˆ‚M, the boundary of M. As we shall see in the next section, the
classical theorems of Gauss, Green, and Stokes are special cases of this result. Before stating Stokesâ€™ theorem
formally, we need to discuss manifolds with boundary and their orientations.
7.2.1 Deï¬nition.
Let E be a Banach space and Î» âˆˆEâˆ—. Let
EÎ» = { x âˆˆE | Î»(x) â‰¥0 },
called a half-space of E, and let U âŠ‚EÎ» be an open set (in the topology induced on EÎ» from E). Call
Int U = U âˆ©{ x âˆˆE | Î»(x) > 0 } the interior of U and âˆ‚U = U âˆ©ker Î» the boundary of U. If E = Rn and
Î» is the projection on the jth factor, then EÎ» is denoted by Rn
j and is called positive jth half-space. Rn
n

7. Integration on Manifolds
Next, we turn to the problem of orientation. As for manifolds without boundary a volume form on an

maps D(Ï•j â—¦Ï•âˆ’1

Supplement 7.2B
Stokesâ€™ Theorem on Manifolds with Piecewise Smooth Boundary
The statement of Stokesâ€™ theorem we have given does not apply when M is, say a cube or a cone, since
these sets do not have a smooth boundary. If the singular portion of the boundary (the four vertices and
12 edges in case of the cube, the vertex and the base circle in case of the cone), is of Lebesgue measure
zero (within the boundary) it should not contribue to the boundary integral and we can hope that Stokesâ€™
theorem still holds. This supplement discusses such a version of Stokesâ€™ theorem inspired by Holmann and
Rummler [1972]. (See Lang [1972] for an alternative approach.)
First we shall give the deï¬nition of a manifold with piecewise smooth boundary. A glance at the deï¬nition
of a manifold with boundary makes it clear that one could deï¬ne a manifold with corners, by choosing
charts that make regions near the boundary diï¬€eomorphic to open subsets of a ï¬nite intersection of positive
closed half-spaces. Unfortunately, singular points on the boundaryâ€”such as the vertex of a coneâ€”need not
be of this type. Thus, instead of trying to classify the singular points up to diï¬€eomorphism and then make a
formal intrinsic deï¬nition, it is simpler to consider manifolds already embedded in a bigger manifold. Then
we can impose a condition on the boundary to insure the validity of Stokesâ€™ theorem.

7.2 Stokesâ€™ Theorem
427
In analysis it can be useful to have hypotheses on the smoothness of Ï‰ as well as on the boundary that
are as weak as possible. Our proofs show that Ï‰ need only be C1. An eï¬€ective strategy for sharper results is
to approximate Ï‰ by smooth forms Ï‰k so that both sides of Stokesâ€™ theorem converge as k â†’âˆ. A useful
class of forms for which this works are those in Sobolev spaces, function spaces encountered in the study of
partial diï¬€erential equations. The HÂ¨older nature of the boundary of N in Stokesâ€™ theorem is exactly what is
needed to make this approximation process work. The key ingredients are approximation properties in M
(which are obtained from those in Rn) and the CalderÂ´on extension theorem to reduce approximations in
N to those in Rn. (Proofs of these facts may be found in Stein [1970], Marsden [1973], and Adams [1975].)
Supplement 7.2C

7.4
Induced Flows on Function Spaces and Ergodicity
This section requires some results from functional analysis. Speciï¬cally we shall require a knowledge of
Stoneâ€™s theorem and self-adjoint operators. The required results may be found in Supplements 7.4A and
7.4B at the end of this section.
Flows on manifolds induce ï¬‚ows on tangent bundles, tensor bundles, and spaces of tensor ï¬elds by means
of push-forward. In this section we shall be concerned mainly with the induced ï¬‚ow on the space of functions.
This induced ï¬‚ow is sometimes called the Liouville ï¬‚ow.
Let M be a manifold and Âµ a volume element on M; that is, (M, Âµ) is a volume manifold. If Ft is a
(volume-preserving) ï¬‚ow on M, then Ft induces a linear one-parameter group (of isometries) on the Hilbert
space H = L2(MÂµ) by
Ut(f) = f â—¦Fâˆ’t.
The association of Ut with Ft replaces a nonlinear ï¬nite-dimensional problem with a linear inï¬nite-dimensional
one.
There have been several theorems that relate properties of Ft and Ut. The best known of these is the
result of Koopman [1931], which shows that Ut has one as a simple eigenvalue for all t if and only if Ft is
ergodic. (If there are no other eigenvalues, then Ft is called weakly mixing.) A few basic results on ergodic
theory are given below. We refer the reader to the excellent texts of Halmos [1956], Arnolâ€™d and Avez [1967],
and Bowen [1975] for more information.
We shall ï¬rst present a result of Povzner [1966], which relates the completeness of the ï¬‚ow of a divergence-
free vector ï¬eld X to the skew-adjointness of X as an operator. (The hypothesis of divergence free is removed
in Exercises 7.4-1â€“7.4-3.) We begin with a lemma due to Ed Nelson.
