Methods of functional analysis applied to L2(M, Âµ) can, as we have seen, be used to obtain theorems
relevant to ï¬‚ows on M. Related to this is a measure-theoretic analogue of the fact that any automorphism of
the algebra F(M) is induced by a diï¬€eomorphism of M (see Supplement 4.2C). This result, due to Mackey
[1962], states that if Ut is a linear isometry on L2(M, Âµ), which is multiplicative (i.e., Ut(fg) = (Utf)(Utg),
where deï¬ned), then Ut is induced by some measure preserving ï¬‚ow Ft on M. This may be used to give
another proof of Theorem 7.4.3.
An important notion for statistical mechanics is that of ergodicity; this is intended to capture the idea
that a ï¬‚ow may be random or chaotic. In dealing with the motion of molecules, the founders of statistical
mechanics, particularly Boltzmann and Gibbs, made such hypotheses at the outset. One of the earliest
precise deï¬nitions of randomness of a dynamical system was minimality: the orbit of almost every point is
dense. In order to prove useful theorems, von Neumann and Birkhoï¬€in the early 1930s required the strong
assumption of ergodicity, deï¬ned as follows.

7.4 Induced Flows on Function Spaces and Ergodicity
445
7.4.4 Deï¬nition.
Let S be a measure space and Ft a (measurable) ï¬‚ow on S. We call Ft ergodic if the
only invariant measurable sets are âˆ…and all of S.
Here, invariant means Ft(A) = A for all t âˆˆR and we agree to write A = B if A and B diï¬€er by a set
of measure zero. (It is not diï¬ƒcult to see that ergodicity implies minimality if we are on a second countable
Borel space.)
A function f : S â†’R will be called a constant of the motion if f â—¦Ft = f a.e. (almost everywhere)
for each t âˆˆR.
7.4.5 Proposition.
A ï¬‚ow Ft on S is ergodic iï¬€the only constants of the motion are constant a.e.
Proof.
If Ft is ergodic and f is a constant of the motion, the two sets
{ x âˆˆS | f(x) â‰¥a }
and { x âˆˆS | f(x) â‰¤a } are invariant, so f must be constant a.e. The converse follows by taking f to be a
characteristic function.
â– 
The ï¬rst major step in ergodic theory was taken by von Neumann [1932], who proved the mean ergodic
theorem which remains as one of the most important basic theorems. The setting is in Hilbert space, but
we shall see how it applies to ï¬‚ows of vector ï¬elds in Corollary 7.4.7.

Modern work in dynamical systems, following the ideas in Â§4.3, has shown that for many interesting ï¬‚ows
arising in the physical sciences, the motion can be â€œchaoticâ€ on large regions of phase space without being
ergodic. Much current research is focused on trying to prove analogues of the ergodic theorems for such cases.
(See, for instance, Guckenheimer and Holmes [1983], Eckmann and Ruelle [1985], and references therein.)
A particularly important example of an ergodic ï¬‚ow is the irrational ï¬‚ow on the torus.
7.4.8 Deï¬nition.

7.4.11 Corollary.
Every trajectory of a quasiperiodic ï¬‚ow Ft on Tn is dense if and only if the ï¬‚ow is

If A is everywhere deï¬ned and bounded, it follows from the Riesz representation theorem (Supplement
2.2A) that Aâˆ—is everywhere deï¬ned; moreover it is not hard to see that, in this case, âˆ¥Aâˆ—âˆ¥= âˆ¥Aâˆ¥.
An operator A is symmetric (Hermitian in the complex case) if Aâˆ—âŠƒA; that is, âŸ¨Ax, yâŸ©= âŸ¨x, AyâŸ©
for all x, y âˆˆDA. If Aâˆ—= A (this includes the condition DAâˆ—= DA), then A is called self-adjoint. An
everywhere deï¬ned symmetric operator is bounded (from the closed graph theorem) and so is self-adjoint.
It is also easy to see that a self-adjoint operator is closed.
One must be aware that, for technical reasons, it is the notion of self-adjoint rather than symmetric,
which is important in applications. Correspondingly, verifying self-adjointness is often diï¬ƒcult while verifying
symmetry is usually trivial.
Sometimes it is useful to have another concept at hand, that of essential self-adjointness. First, it is easy
to check that any symmetric operator A is closable. The closure A is easily seen to be symmetric. One says
that A is essentially self-adjoint when its closure A is self-adjoint.
Let A be a self-adjoint operator. A dense subspace C âŠ‚H is said to be a core of A if C âŠ‚DA and the
closure of A restricted to C is again A. Thus if C is a core of A one can recover A just be knowing A on C.
We now give a number of propositions concerning the foregoing concepts, which are useful in applications.
Most of this is classical work of von Neumann. We begin with the following.

A convenient test for establishing the equality of the deï¬ciency indices is to show that T commutes with
a conjugation U; that is, an antilinear isometry U : H â†’H satisfying U 2 = I; antilinear means that
U(Î±x) = Â¯Î±Ux
for complex scalars Î± and
U(x + y) = Ux + Uy
for x, y âˆˆH. It is easy to see that U is the isometry required from D+ to Dâˆ’(use D+ = range(A + iI)âŠ¥).
As a corollary, we obtain an important classical result of von Neumann: Let H be L2 of a measure space and
let A be a (closed) symmetric operator that is real in the sense that it commutes with complex conjugation.
Then A admits self-adjoint extensions. (Another suï¬ƒcient condition of a diï¬€erent nature, due to Friedrichs,
is given below.) This result applies to many quantum mechanical operators. However, one is also interested
in essential self-adjointness, so that the self-adjoint extension will be unique. Methods for proving this for
speciï¬c operators in quantum mechanics are given in Kato [1951, 1976] and Reed and Simon [1974]. For
corresponding questions in elasticity, see Marsden and Hughes [1983]. We now give some additional results
that illustrate methods for handling self-adjoint operators.
7.4.19 Proposition.
Let A be a self-adjoint and B a bounded self-adjoint operator. Then A + B (with
domain DA) is self-adjoint. If A is essentially self-adjoint on DA then so is A + B.

âŸ¨Ax, yâŸ©+ âŸ¨Bx, yâŸ©= âŸ¨Ax, yâŸ©+ âŸ¨x, ByâŸ©
since B is everywhere deï¬ned. Thus
âŸ¨Ax, yâŸ©= âŸ¨x, (A + B)âˆ—y âˆ’ByâŸ©.
Hence y âˆˆDAâˆ—= DA and

Hence y âˆˆDA+B = DA.
Let A be the closure of A. For the second part, it suï¬ƒces to show that the closure of A+B equals A+B.

In general, the sum of two self-adjoint operators need not be self-adjoint. (See Nelson [1959] and Chernoï¬€
[1974] for this and related examples.)
7.4.20 Proposition.
Let A be a symmetric operator. If the range of A is all of H then A is self-adjoint.
Proof.
We ï¬rst observe that A is one-to-one. Indeed let Ax = 0. Then for any y âˆˆDA,
0 = âŸ¨Ax, yâŸ©= âŸ¨x, AyâŸ©.
But A is onto and so x = 0. Thus A admits an everywhere deï¬ned inverse Aâˆ’1, which is therefore self-adjoint.
Hence A is self-adjoint (we proved earlier than the inverse of a self-adjoint operator is self-adjoint).

Note that an operator A has dense range iï¬€Aâˆ—is one-to-one; that is, Aâˆ—w = 0 implies w = 0.
For a given symmetric operator A, we considered the general problem of self-adjoint extensions of A
and classiï¬ed these in terms of the defect spaces. Now, under diï¬€erent hypotheses, we construct a special
self-adjoint extension (even though A need not be essentially self-adjoint). This result is useful in many
applications, including quantum mechanics.
A symmetric operator A on H is called lower semi-bounded if there is a constant c âˆˆR such that
âŸ¨Ax, xâŸ©â‰¥câˆ¥xâˆ¥2 for all x âˆˆDA. Upper semi-bounded is deï¬ned similarly. If A is either upper or lower
semi-bounded then A is called semi-bounded. Observe that if A is positive or negative then A is semi-
bounded.
As an example, let A = âˆ’âˆ‡2+V where âˆ‡2 is the Laplacian and let V be a real valued continuous function
and bounded below, say V (x) â‰¥Î±. Let H = L2(Rn, C) and DA the Câˆfunctions with compact support.
Then âˆ’âˆ‡2 is positive, so
âŸ¨Af, fâŸ©= âŸ¨âˆ’âˆ‡2f, fâŸ©+ âŸ¨V f, fâŸ©â‰¥Î±âŸ¨f, fâŸ©,
and thus A is semi-bounded.
We already know that this operator is real so has self-adjoint extensions by von Neumannâ€™s theorem.
However, the self-adjoint extension constructed below (called the Friedrichs extension) is â€œnatural.â€
Thus the actual construction is as important as the statement.

Here we give a self-contained proof of Stoneâ€™s theorem for unbounded self-adjoint operators A on a complex

7.4.24 Theorem (Stoneâ€™s Theorem).
Let Ut be a continuous one-parameter unitary group. Then the gen-
erator A of Ut is self-adjoint. (In particular, by Supplement 7.4A, it is closed and densely deï¬ned.) Con-
versely, let A be a given self-adjoint operator. Then there exists a unique one-parameter unitary group Ut
whose generator is A.

In closing, we mention that many of the results proved have generalizations to continuous one-parameter
groups or semi-groups of linear operators in Banach spaces (or on locally convex spaces). The central result,
due to Hille and Yosida, characterizes generators of semi-groups. Our proof of Stoneâ€™s theorem is based on
methods that can be used in the more general context. Expositions of this more general context are found
in, for example, Kato [1976] and Marsden and Hughes [1983, Chapter 6].

Recall that a k-form Î± is called closed if dÎ± = 0 and exact if Î± = dÎ² for some k âˆ’1 form Î². Since d2 = 0,

(with real coeï¬ƒcients) deï¬ned in algebraic topology; the isomorphism is given by integration. For proofs,

of the deRham theorem is proved in Supplement 7.5B.
The scope of this section is to informally discuss the Hodge decomposition theory based on diï¬€erential
operators and to explain how it is related to the deRham cohomology groups. In addition, some topological

is deï¬ned. In the sequel, M will denote a compact oriented Riemannian manifold, and Î´ the codiï¬€erential

The complete proof of the Hodge theorem requires elliptic estimates and may be found in Morrey [1966].

The Hodge theorem plays a fundamental role in incompressible hydrodynamics, as we shall see in Â§8.2.
It allows the introduction of the pressure for a given ï¬‚uid state. It has applications to many other areas
of mathematical physics and engineering as well; see for example, Fischer and Marsden [1979] and Wyatt,
Chua, and Oster [1978].
Below we shall state a generalization of the Hodge theorem for some decomposition theorems for general
elliptic operators (rather than the special case of the Laplacian). However, we ï¬rst pause to discuss what
happens if a boundary is present. This theory was worked out by Kodaira [1949], Duï¬€and Spencer [1952],
and Morrey [1966, Chapter 7]. Diï¬€erentiability across the boundary is very delicate, but important. Some
of the best results in this regard are due to Morrey.

7.5.8 Deï¬nition.
Two smooth mappings f, g : M â†’N, are called Cr-homotopic if there is a Cr-map
F : [0, 1] Ã— M â†’N such that
F(0, m) = f(m)
and
F(1, m) = g(m),
for all m âˆˆM. The homotopy F is called proper if F is a proper map; in this case f and g are said to be
properly Cr-homotopic maps.

7.5.11 Corollary.

7.5.12 Corollary.
Let M, N be orientable n-manifolds, N connected, M boundaryless, and let f, g : M â†’
N be smooth properly homotopic maps. Then deg (f) = deg(g).
This corollary is useful in three important applications. The ï¬rst concerns vector ï¬elds on spheres.
7.5.13 Theorem (Hairy Ball Theorem).
Every vector ï¬eld on an even dimensional sphere has a critical
point.
Proof.

7.5.17 Proposition.
Let U be an open subset of Rn and f : U â†’Rn be a C1 proper map. Assume there
is a closed subset K âŠ‚U such that for all x âˆˆU\K, the Jacobian J(f)(x) does not change sign and is not
identically equal to zero. Then f is surjective.
Proof.
The map f cannot be constant since the Jacobian J(f)(x) is not identically zero for all x âˆˆU\K.
For the same reason, f has a regular value y âˆˆf(U\K), for if all values in f(U\K) are singular, J(f) will
vanish on U\K. If y âˆˆf(U\K) is a regular value of f then sign(Txf) does not change for all x âˆˆf âˆ’1(y) so
by the degree theorem 7.5.10, deg(f) Ì¸= 0, which then implies that f is onto.

7.5.18 Proposition.

Degree theory can be extended to inï¬nite dimensions as well and has important applications to partial
diï¬€erential equations and bifurcations. This theory is similar in spirit to the above and was developed by

[1970b] for modern accounts.

8
Applications
This chapter presents some applications of manifold theory and tensor analysis to physics and engineering.
Our selection is a of limited scope and depth, with the intention of providing an introduction to the tech-
niques. There are many other applications of the ideas of this book as well. We list below a few selected
references for further reading in the same spirit.
1. Arnolâ€™d [1982], Abraham and Marsden [1978], Chernoï¬€and Marsden [1974], Weinstein [1977], Marsden
[1981], Marsden [1992], and Marsden and Ratiu [1999] for Hamiltonian mechanics.
2. Marsden and Hughes [1983] for elasticity theory.
3. Flanders [1963], von Westenholz [1981], and Bloch, Ballieul, Crouch and Marsden [2001] for applications
to control theory.
4. Hermann [1980], Knowles [1981], and Schutz [1980] for diverse applications.
5. Bleecker [1981] for Yangâ€“Mills theory.
6. Misner, Thorne, and Wheeler [1973] and Hawking and Ellis [1973] for general relativity.

to geometrize the symplectic matrix J. In inï¬nite dimensions a few technical points need attention before
proceeding.
Weak and Strong Metrics and Symplectic Forms.
Let E be a Banach space and B : E Ã— E â†’R
a continuous bilinear mapping. Then B induces a continuous map Bâ™­: E â†’Eâˆ—, e â†’Bâ™­(e) deï¬ned by

If E is ï¬nite dimensional there is no diï¬€erence between strong and weak nondegeneracy. However, if inï¬nite
dimensions the distinction is important to bear in mind, and the issue does come up in basic examples, as
we shall see in Supplement 8.1A.
Let M be a Banach manifold. By a weak Riemannian structure we mean a smooth assignment
g : x â†’âŸ¨, âŸ©x = g(x) of a weakly nondegenerate inner product (not necessarily complete) to each tangent

smooth means g is smooth as a section of the vector bundle L2(TM, TM; R) whose ï¬ber at x âˆˆM is
L2(TxM, TxM; R). By a Riemannian manifold we mean a weak Riemannian manifold in which âŸ¨, âŸ©x is
nondegenerate. Equivalently, the topology of âŸ¨, âŸ©x is complete on TxM, so that the model space E must be
isomorphic to a Hilbert space.

Symplectic Maps.
Naturally, since we have the notion of a symplectic manifold, we should consider the
mappings that preserve this structure.
8.1.5 Deï¬nition.
Let (P, Ï‰) be a symplectic manifold. A (smooth) map f : P â†’P is called canonical
or symplectic when f âˆ—Ï‰ = Ï‰.

the phase volume, and so is necessarily a local diï¬€eomorphism. A map f : P1 â†’P2 between symplectic
manifolds (P1, Ï‰1) and (P2, Ï‰2) is called symplectic if f âˆ—Ï‰2 = Ï‰1. As above, if P1 and P2 have the same
dimension, then f is a local diï¬€eomorphism and preserves the phase volume.

One writes Ë™f = {f, H} to stand for the equation in (ii). This equation is called the equation of motion
in Poisson bracket formulation.
Two functions f, g : P â†’R are said to be in involution or to Poisson commute if {f, g} = 0. Any
function Poisson commuting with the Hamiltonian of a mechanical system is, by Corollary 8.1.11, necessarily
constant along on the ï¬‚ow of the Hamiltonian vector ï¬eld. This is why such functions are called constants
of the motion. A classical theorem of Liouville states that in a mechanical system with a 2n-dimensional
phase space admitting k constants of the motion in involution and independent almost everywhere (i.e.,
the diï¬€erentials are independent on an open dense set) one can reduce the dimension of the phase space
to 2(n âˆ’k). In particular, if k = n, the equations of motion can be â€œexplicitlyâ€ integrated. In fact, under
certain additional hypotheses, the trajectories of the mechanical system are straight lines on high-dimensional
cylinders or tori. If the motion takes place on tori, the explicit integration of the equations of motion goes
under the name of ï¬nding action-angle variables. See Arnolâ€™d [1982], and Abraham and Marsden [1978,
pp. 392â€“400] for details and Exercise 8.1-4 for an example. In inï¬nite-dimensional systems the situation is
considerably more complicated. A famous example is the Kortewegâ€“deVries (KdV) equation; for this example
we also refer to Abraham and Marsden [1978, pp. 462â€“72] and references therein. The following supplement
gives some elementary but still interesting examples of inï¬nite-dimensional Hamiltonian systems.

There is feedback between Hamiltonian systems and Riemannian geometry. For example, conservation of
energy for geodesics is a direct consequence of their Hamiltonian character but can also be checked directly.
Moreover, the fact that the ï¬‚ow of the geodesic spray on TM consists of canonical transformations is also
useful in geometry, for example, in the study of closed geodesics (cf. Klingenberg [1978]). On the other hand,
Riemannian geometry provides tools and concepts (such as parallel transport and curvature) that are useful
in studying Hamiltonian systems.

8.2
Fluid Mechanics
We present a few of the basic ideas concerning the motion of an ideal ï¬‚uid from the point of view of manifolds
and diï¬€erential forms. This is usually done in the context of Euclidean space using vector calculus. For the
latter approach and additional details, the reader should consult one of the standard texts on the subject
such as Batchelor [1967], Chorin and Marsden [1993], or Gurtin [1981]. The use of manifolds and diï¬€erential
forms can give additional geometric insight.
The present section is for expository reasons somewhat superï¬cial and is intended only to indicate how to
use diï¬€erential forms and Lie derivatives in ï¬‚uid mechanics. Once the basics are understood, more sophisti-
cated questions can be asked, such as: in what sense is ï¬‚uid mechanics an inï¬nite-dimensional Hamiltonian
system? For the answer, see Arnolâ€™d [1982], Abraham and Marsden [1978], Marsden and Weinstein [1983],
and ?. For analogous topics in elasticity, see Marsden and Hughes [1983], and for plasmas, see Â§8.4 and
Marsden and Weinstein [1982].
Let M be a compact, oriented ï¬nite-dimensional Riemannian n-manifold, possibly with boundary. Let the
Riemannian volume form be denoted Âµ âˆˆâ„¦n(M), and the corresponding volume element dÂµ. Usually M
is a bounded region with smooth boundary in two- or three-dimensional Euclidean space, oriented by the
standard basis, and with the standard Euclidean volume form and inner product.
Imagine M to be ï¬lled with ï¬‚uid and the ï¬‚uid to be in motion. Our object is to describe this motion. Let
x âˆˆM be a point in M and consider the particle of ï¬‚uid moving through x at time t = 0. For example, we
can imagine a particle of dust suspended in the ï¬‚uid; this particle traverses a trajectory which we denote
Ï•t(x) = Ï•(x, t). Let u(x, t) denote the velocity of the particle of ï¬‚uid moving through x at time t. Thus, for
each ï¬xed time, u is a vector ï¬eld on M. See Figure 8.2.1. We call u the velocity ï¬eld of the ï¬‚uid. Thus
the relationship between u and Ï•t is

that is, u is a time-dependent vector ï¬eld with evolution operator Ï•t in the same sense as was used in Â§4.1.

2. Balance of momentum.
Newtonâ€™s second law asserts that the rate of change of momentum of a
portion of the ï¬‚uid equals the total force applied to it. To see how to apply this principle on a general
manifold, let us discuss the situation M âŠ‚R3 ï¬rst. Here we follow the standard vector calculus conventions
and write the velocity ï¬elds in boldface type. The momentum of a portion of the ï¬‚uid at time t that at time
t = 0 occupied the region W is

Ï•t(W )
Ïu dÂµ.
Here and in what follows the integral is R3-valued, so we apply all theorems on integration componentwise.
For any continuum, forces acting on a piece of material are of two types. First there are forces of stress,
whereby the piece of material is acted on by forces across its surface by the rest of the continuum. Second,
there are external, or body forces, such as gravity or a magnetic ï¬eld, which exert a force per unit volume
on the continuum. The clear formulation of surface stress forces in a continuum is usually attributed to
Cauchy. We shall assume that the body forces are given by a given force density b, that is, the total body
forces acting on W are

W Ïb dÂµ. In continuum mechanics the forces of stress are assumed to be of the form

3. Conservation of energy.
A basic problem of ideal ï¬‚uid dynamics is to solve the initial-boundary-
value problem. The unknowns are u, Ï, and p, that is, n + 2 scalar unknowns. We have, however, only n + 1
equations. Thus one might suspect that to specify the ï¬‚uid motion, one more equation is needed. This is in
fact true and the law of conservation of energy will supply the necessary extra equation in ï¬‚uid mechanics.
(The situation is similar for general continua; see Marsden and Hughes [1983].)
For a ï¬‚uid moving in M with velocity ï¬eld u, the kinetic energy of the ï¬‚uid is

where Einternal is the energy that relates to energy we cannot â€œseeâ€ on a macroscopic scale and derives from
sources such as intermolecular potentials and molecular vibrations. If energy is pumped into the ï¬‚uid or if
we allow the ï¬‚uid to do work, Etotal will change. We describe two particular examples of energy equations
that are useful.

8.4
The Lieâ€“Poisson Bracket in Continuum Mechanics and
Plasma Physics
This section studies the equations of motion for some Hamiltonian systems in Poisson bracket formation. As
opposed to Â§8.1, the emphasis is placed here on the Poisson bracket rather than on the underlying symplectic
structure. This naturally leads to a generalization of Hamiltonian mechanics to systems whose phase space
is a â€œPoisson manifold.â€ We do not intend to develop here the theory of Poisson manifolds but only to
illustrate it with the most important example, the Lieâ€“Poisson bracket. See Marsden and Ratiu [1999] for
further details.
If (P, Ï‰) is a (weak) symplectic manifold, H : P â†’R a smooth Hamiltonian with Hamiltonian vector ï¬eld
XH âˆˆX(P) whose ï¬‚ow is denoted by Ï•t, recall from Corollary 8.1.11 that
dÏ•t
dt (p) = XH(Ï•t(p))
(8.4.1)
is equivalent to
d
dt(F â—¦Ï•t) = {F â—¦Ï•t, H â—¦Ï•t}
(8.4.2)
for any smooth locally deï¬ned function f : U â†’R, where U is open in P. In (8.4.2), { , } denotes the Poisson
bracket deï¬ned by Ï‰, that is,
{F, G} = Ï‰(XF , XG) = XG[F] = âˆ’XF [G].
(8.4.3)
Finally, recall that the Poisson bracket is an antisymmetric bilinear operation on F(P) which satisï¬es the
Jacobi identity
{{F, G}, H} + {{G, H}, F} + {{H, F}, G} = 0,
(8.4.4)
that is, (F(P), { , }) is a Lie algebra. In addition, the multiplicative ring structure and the Lie algebra
structure of F(P) are connected by the Leibniz rule
{FG, H} = F{G, H} + G{F, H},
(8.4.5)
that is, { , } is a derivation in each argument. These observations naturally lead to the following generalization
of the concept of symplectic manifolds.
8.4.1 Deï¬nition.
A smooth manifold P is called a Poisson manifold if F(P), the ring of functions on
P, admits a Lie algebra structure which is a derivation in each argument. The bracket operation on F(P)
is called a Poisson bracket and is usually denoted by { , }.
From the remarks above, we see that any (weak) symplectic manifold is a Poisson manifold. One of the
purposes of this section is to show that there are physically important Poisson manifolds which are not
symplectic. But even in the symplectic context it is sometimes easier to compute the Poisson bracket than
the symplectic form, as the following example shows.

8.5
Constraints and Control
The applications in this ï¬nal section all involve the Frobenius theorem. Each example is necessarily treated
brieï¬‚y, but hopefully in enough detail so the interested reader can pursue the subject further by utilizing
the given references.
Constaints.
We start with the subject of holonomic constraints in Hamiltonian systems. A Hamiltonian
system as discussed in Â§8.1 can have a condition imposed that limits the available points in phase space. Such
a condition is a constraint. For example, a ball tethered to a string of unit length in R3 may be considered
to be constrained only to move on the unit sphere S2 (or possibly interior to the sphere if the string is
collapsible). If the phase space is T âˆ—Q and the constraints are all derivable from constraints imposed only on
the conï¬guration space (the qâ€™s), the constraints are called holonomic. For example, if there is one constraint
f(q) = 0 for f : Q â†’R, the constraints on T âˆ—Q can be simply obtained by diï¬€erentiation: df = 0 on T âˆ—Q. If
the phase space is TQ, then the constraints are holonomic iï¬€the constraints on the velocities are saying that
the velocities are tangent to some constraint manifold of the positions. A constraint then can be thought of
in terms of velocities as a subset E âŠ‚TM. If it is a subbundle, this constraint is thus holonomic iï¬€it is
integrable in the sense of Frobeniusâ€™ theorem.
Constraints that are not holonomic, are naturally called nonholonomic constraints. Holonomic constraints
can be dealt with in the sense that one understands how to modify the equations of motion when the
constraints are imposed, by adding forces of constraint, such as centrifugal force. See, for example Goldstein
[1980, Chapter 1], and Abraham and Marsden [1978, Section 3.7]. We shall limit ourselves to the discussion
of two examples of nonholonomic constraints. See for an extensive discussion and background.
A classical example of a nonholonomic system is a disk rolling without slipping on a plane. The disk of
radius a is constrained to move without slipping on the (x, y)-plane. Let us ï¬x a point P on the disk and
call Î¸ the angle between the radius at P and the contact point Q of the disk with the plane, as in Figure
8.5.1. Let (x, y, a) denote the coordinates of the center of the disk. Finally, if Î¸ denotes the angle between

that there is no slipping at Q means that the velocity at Q is zero; that is,

A second example of constraints is due to Nelson [1967]. Consider the motion of a car and denote by (x, y)

of â€œsteerâ€, â€œdriveâ€ and â€œwriggleâ€ is holonomic. Moreover, since the Lie algebra generated by these three
vector ï¬elds is abelian, the motion of the car with these constraints can be described by applying these three
vector ï¬elds in any order.

Control.
Next we turn our attention to some elementary aspects of control theory. We shall restrict our
attention to a simple version of a local controllability theorem. For extensions and many additional results,
we recommend consulting the book of and a few of the important papers and notes such as ? [?, ?], Sussmann
[1977], Hermann and Krener [1977], Russell [1979], Hermann [1980], and Ball, Marsden, and Slemrod [1982]
and references therein.
Consider a system of diï¬€erential equations of the form
Ë™w(t) = X(w(t)) + p(t)Y (w(t))

and Y are smooth vector ï¬elds on M and p : [0, T] â†’R is a prescribed function called a control.
The existence theory for diï¬€erential equations guarantees that equation (8.5.1) has a ï¬‚ow that depends
smoothly on w0 and on p lying in a suitable Banach space Z of maps of [0, T] to R, such as the space of C1
maps. Let the ï¬‚ow of (8.5.1) be denoted
Ft(w0, p) = w(t, p, w0).
(8.5.2)

is locally controllable (at time T) if there is a neighborhood U of w0(T) such that for any point h âˆˆU,
there is a p âˆˆZ such that w(T; p, w0) = h. In other words, we can alter the endpoint of w0(t) in a locally

8.5.1 Proposition.
If the linear map LT : Z â†’E given by equation (8.5.6) is surjective, then equation
(8.5.1) is locally controllable (at time T).
Proof.
This follows from the â€œlocal ontoâ€ form of the implicit function theorem (see Theorem 2.5.9)
applied to the map P. Solutions exist for time T for small p since they do for p = 0; see Corollary 4.1.25.
â– 
8.5.2 Corollary.
Suppose E = Rn and Y is linear as well. If
dim span {Y (w0), [X, Y ](w0), [X, [X, Y ]](w0), . . . } = n,
then equation (8.5.1) is locally controllable.
Proof.
We have the Bakerâ€“Campbellâ€“Hausdorï¬€formula
eâˆ’sXY esX = Y + s[X, Y ] + s2
2 [X, [X, Y ]] + Â· Â· Â· ,
obtained by expanding esX = I + sX + (s2/2)X2 + Â· Â· Â· and gathering terms. Substitution into equation
(8.5.6) shows that LT is surjective.
â– 
For the case of nonlinear vector ï¬elds and the system equation (8.5.1) on ï¬nite-dimensional manifolds,
controllability hinges on the dimension of the space obtained by replacing the foregoing commutator brackets
by Lie brackets of vector ï¬elds, n being the dimension of M. This is related to what are usually called Chowâ€™s
theorem in control theory (see Chow [1947]).
To see that some condition involving brackets is necessary, suppose that the span of X and Y forms an
involutive distribution of TM. Then by the Frobenius theorem, w0 lies in a unique maximal two-dimensional
leaf Â£(w0) of the corresponding foliation. But then the solution of equation (8.5.1) can never leave Â£(w0), no
matter how p is chosen. Hence in such a situation, equation (8.5.1) would not be locally controllable; rather,
one would only be able to move in a two-dimensional subspace. If repeated bracketing with X increases the
dimension of vectors obtained then the attainable states increase in dimension accordingly.

An Introduction to Lie Groups
To prepare for the next chapters, we present some basic facts about Lie
groups. Alternative expositions and additional details can be obtained from
Abraham and Marsden [1978], Olver [1986], and Sattinger and Weaver
[1986]. In particular, in this book we shall require only elementary facts
about the general theory and a knowledge of a few of the more basic groups,
such as the rotation and Euclidean groups.
Here are how some of the basic groups occur in mechanics:
Linear and Angular Momentum.
These arise as conserved quantities
associated with the groups of translations and rotations in space.
Rigid Body.
Consider a free rigid body rotating about its center of mass,
taken to be the origin. â€œFreeâ€ means that there are no external forces, and
â€œrigidâ€ means that the distance between any two points of the body is
unchanged during the motion. Consider a point X of the body at time
t = 0, and denote its position at time t by f(X, t). Rigidity of the body
and the assumption of a smooth motion imply that f(X, t) = A(t)X, where
A(t) is a proper rotation, that is, A(t) âˆˆSO(3), the proper rotation group
of R3, the 3 Ã— 3 orthogonal matrices with determinant 1. The set SO(3)
will be shown to be a three-dimensional Lie group, and since it describes
any possible position of the body, it serves as the conï¬guration space. The
group SO(3) also plays a dual role of a symmetry group, since the same
physical motion is described if we rotate our coordinate axes. Used as a
symmetry group, SO(3) leads to conservation of angular momentum.

Heavy Top.
Consider a rigid body moving with a ï¬xed point but un-
der the inï¬‚uence of gravity. This problem still has a conï¬guration space
SO(3), but the symmetry group is only the circle group S1, consisting of
rotations about the direction of gravity. One says that gravity has broken
the symmetry from SO(3) to S1. This time, â€œeliminatingâ€ the S1 symme-
try â€œmysteriouslyâ€ leads one to the larger Euclidean group SE(3) of rigid
motion of R3. This is a manifestation of the general theory of semidirect
products (see the Introduction, where we showed that the heavy top equa-
tions are Lieâ€“Poisson for SE(3), and Marsden, Ratiu, and Weinstein [1984a,
1984b]).
Incompressible Fluids.
Let â„¦be a region in R3 that is ï¬lled with
a moving incompressible
ï¬‚uid and is free of external forces. Denote by
Î·(X, t) the trajectory of a ï¬‚uid particle that at time t = 0 is at X âˆˆâ„¦.
For ï¬xed t the map Î·t deï¬ned by Î·t(X) = Î·(X, t) is a diï¬€eomorphism of
â„¦. In fact, since the ï¬‚uid is incompressible, we have Î·t âˆˆDiffvol(â„¦), the
group of volume-preserving diï¬€eomorphisms of â„¦. Thus, the conï¬guration
space for the problem is the inï¬nite-dimensional Lie group Diffvol(â„¦). Using
Diffvol(â„¦) as a symmetry group leads to Kelvinâ€™s circulation theorem as a
conservation law. See Marsden and Weinstein [1983].
Compressible Fluids.
In this case the conï¬guration space is the whole
diï¬€eomorphism group Diff(â„¦). The symmetry group consists of density-
preserving diï¬€eomorphisms DiffÏ(â„¦). The density plays a role similar to
that of gravity in the heavy top and again leads to semidirect products, as
does the next example.
Magnetohydrodynamics (MHD).
This example is that of a com-
pressible ï¬‚uid consisting of charged particles with the dominant electro-
magnetic force being the magnetic ï¬eld produced by the particles them-
selves (possibly together with an external ï¬eld). The conï¬guration space
remains Diff(â„¦), but the ï¬‚uid motion is coupled with the magnetic ï¬eld
(regarded as a two-form on â„¦).
Maxwellâ€“Vlasov Equations.
Let f(x, v, t) denote the density function
of a collisionless plasma. The function f evolves in time by means of a
time-dependent canonical transformation on R6, that is, (x, v)-space. In
other words, the evolution of f can be described by ft = Î·âˆ—
t f0, where
f0 is the initial value of f, ft its value at time t, and Î·t is a canonical
transformation. Thus, Diffcan(R6), the group of canonical transformations,
plays an important role.
Maxwellâ€™s Equations
Maxwellâ€™s equations for electrodynamics are in-
variant under gauge transformations that transform the magnetic (or 4)
potential by A â†’A + âˆ‡Ï•. This gauge group is an inï¬nite-dimensional Lie
group. The conserved quantity associated with the gauge symmetry in this
case is the charge.

(b)
The group of linear isomorphisms of Rn to Rn is a Lie group of
dimension n2, called the general linear group and denoted by GL(n, R).
It is a smooth manifold, since it is an open subset of the vector space
L(Rn, Rn) of all linear maps of Rn to Rn. Indeed, GL(n, R) is the inverse
image of R\{0} under the continuous map A â†’det A of L(Rn, Rn) to R.

The group identity element e is the identity map on Rn. If we choose a

formulas for the product and inverse of matrices are smooth (rational)
functions of the matrix components.

Corollary 9.1.7.
Assume that f1, f2 : G â†’H are homomorphisms of
Lie groups and that G is connected. If Tef1 = Tef2, then f1 = f2.
This follows from Proposition 9.1.6, since a connected Lie group G is
generated by a neighborhood of the identity element. This latter fact may
be proved following these steps:
1. Show that any open subgroup of a Lie group is closed (since its com-
plement is a union of sets homeomorphic to it).
2. Show that a subgroup of a Lie group is open if and only if it contains
a neighborhood of the identity element.
3. Conclude that a Lie group is connected if and only if it is generated
by arbitrarily small neighborhoods of the identity element.
From Proposition 9.1.6 and the fact that the inner automorphisms are
group homomorphisms, we get the following corollary.
Corollary 9.1.8.
(i) exp(Adg Î¾) = g(exp Î¾)gâˆ’1, for every Î¾ âˆˆg and g âˆˆG; and
(ii) Adg[Î¾, Î·] = [Adg Î¾, Adg Î·].

9. An Introduction to Lie Groups
More Automatic Smoothness Results.
There are some interesting
results related in spirit to Proposition 9.1.4 and the preceding discussions.
A striking example of this is the following:
Theorem 9.1.9.
Any continuous homomorphism of ï¬nite-dimensional
Lie groups is smooth.
There is a remarkable consequence of this theorem. If G is a topological
group (that is, the multiplication and inversion maps are continuous), one
could, in principle, have more than one diï¬€erentiable manifold structure
making G into two nonisomorphic Lie groups (i.e., the manifold structures
are not diï¬€eomorphic) but both inducing the same topological structure.
This phenomenon of â€œexotic structuresâ€ occurs for general manifolds. How-
ever, in view of the theorem above, this cannot happen in the case of Lie
groups. Indeed, since the identity map is a homeomorphism, it must be
a diï¬€eomorphism. Thus, a topological group that is locally Euclidean (i.e.,
there is an open neighborhood of the identity homeomorphic to an open ball
in Rn) admits at most one smooth manifold structure relative to which it
is a Lie group.
The existence part of this statement is Hilbertâ€™s famous ï¬fth problem:
Show that a locally Euclidean topological group admits a smooth (actually
analytic) structure making it into a Lie group. The solution of this problem
was achieved by Gleason and, independently, by Montgomery and Zippin
in 1952; see Kaplansky [1971] for an excellent account of this proof.
Abelian Lie Groups.
Since any two elements of an Abelian Lie group
G commute, it follows that all adjoint operators Adg, g âˆˆG, equal the
identity. Therefore, by equation (9.1.5), the Lie algebra g is Abelian; that
is, [Î¾, Î·] = 0 for all Î¾, Î· âˆˆg.
Examples
(a)
Any ï¬nite-dimensional vector space, thought of as an Abelian group
under addition, is an Abelian Lie group. The same is true in inï¬nite di-
mensions for any Banach space. The exponential map is the identity.
â™¦
(b)
The unit circle in the complex plane S1 = { z âˆˆC | |z| = 1 } is
an Abelian Lie group under multiplication. The tangent space TeS1 is the
imaginary axis, and we identify R with TeS1 by t â†’2Ï€it. With this iden-
tiï¬cation, the exponential map exp : R â†’S1 is given by exp(t) = e2Ï€it.
Note that expâˆ’1(1) = Z.
â™¦
(c)
The n-dimensional torus Tn = S1 Ã— Â· Â· Â· Ã— S1 (n times) is an Abelian
Lie group. The exponential map exp : Rn â†’Tn is given by
exp(t1, . . . , tn) = (e2Ï€it1, . . . , e2Ï€itn).

If G is a connected Lie group whose Lie algebra g is Abelian, the Lie
group homomorphism g âˆˆG â†’Adg âˆˆGL(g) has induced Lie algebra
homomorphism Î¾ âˆˆg â†’adÎ¾ âˆˆgl(g) the constant map equal to zero.
Therefore, by Corollary 9.1.7, Adg = identity on G, for any g âˆˆG. Apply
Corollary 9.1.7 again, this time to the conjugation by g on G (whose induced
Lie algebra homomorphism is Adg), to conclude that it equals the identity
map on G. Thus, g commutes with all elements of G; since g was arbitrary,
we conclude that G is Abelian. We summarize these observations in the
following proposition.
Proposition 9.1.10.
If G is an Abelian Lie group, its Lie algebra g is
also Abelian. Conversely, if G is connected and g is Abelian, then G is
Abelian.
The main structure theorem for Abelian Lie groups is the following,
whose proof can be found in Varadarajan [1974] or Knapp [1996].
Theorem 9.1.11.
Every connected Abelian n-dimensional Lie group G
is isomorphic to a cylinder, that is, to Tk Ã— Rnâˆ’k for some k = 1, . . . , n.
Lie Subgroups.
It is natural to synthesize the subgroup and submani-
fold concepts.
Deï¬nition 9.1.12.
A Lie subgroup H of a Lie group G is a subgroup
of G that is also an injectively immersed submanifold of G. If H is a sub-
manifold of G, then H is called a regular Lie subgroup.
For example, the one-parameter subgroups of the torus T2 that wind
densely on the torus are Lie subgroups that are not regular.
The Lie algebras g and h of G and a Lie subgroup H, respectively, are
related in the following way:
Proposition 9.1.13.
Let H be a Lie subgroup of G. Then h is a Lie
subalgebra of g. Moreover,

9. An Introduction to Lie Groups
The following is a powerful theorem often used to ï¬nd Lie subgroups.
Theorem 9.1.14.
If H is a closed subgroup of a Lie group G, then H
is a regular Lie subgroup. Conversely, if H is a regular Lie subgroup of G,
then H is closed.
The proof of this theorem may be found in Abraham and Marsden [1978],
Adams [1969], Varadarajan [1974], or Knapp [1996].
We remind the reader that the Lie algebras appropriate to ï¬‚uid dynamics
and plasma physics are inï¬nite-dimensional. Nevertheless, there is still,
with the appropriate technical conditions, a correspondence between Lie
groups and Lie algebras analogous to the preceding theorems. The reader
should be warned, however, that these theorems do not naively generalize
to the inï¬nite-dimensional situation, and to prove them for special cases,
specialized analytical theorems may be required.
The next result is sometimes called â€œLieâ€™s third fundamental theorem.â€
Theorem 9.1.15.
Let G be a Lie group with Lie algebra g, and let h be
a Lie subalgebra of g. Then there exists a unique connected Lie subgroup H
of G whose Lie algebra is h.
The proof may be found in Knapp [1996] or Varadarajan [1974].
Quotients.
If H is a closed subgroup of G, we denote by G/H, the set
of left cosets, that is, the collection { gH | g âˆˆG }. Let Ï€ : G â†’G/H be
the projection g â†’gH.
Theorem 9.1.16.
There is a unique manifold structure on G/H such
that the projection Ï€ : G â†’G/H is a smooth surjective submersion. (Recall
from Chapter 4 that a smooth map is called a submersion when its derivative
is surjective.)
Again the proof may be found in Abraham and Marsden [1978], Knapp
[1996], or Varadarajan [1974].

Haar measure.
One can characterize Lebesgue measure up to a multi-
plicative constant on Rn by its invariance under translations. Similarly, on
a locally compact group there is a unique (up to a nonzero multiplicative
constant) left-invariant measure, called Haar measure. For Lie groups
the existence of such measures is especially simple.
Proposition 9.1.18.
Let G be a Lie group. Then there is a volume form
Âµ, unique up to nonzero multiplicative constants, that is left invariant. If
G is compact, Âµ is right invariant as well.
Proof.
Pick any n-form Âµe on TeG that is nonzero and deï¬ne an n-form
on TgG by
Âµg(v1, . . . , vn) = Âµe Â· (TLgâˆ’1v1, . . . , TLgâˆ’1 Â· vn).
Then Âµg is left invariant and smooth. For n = dim G, Âµe is unique up to a
scalar factor, so Âµg is as well.
Fix g0 âˆˆG and consider Râˆ—
g0Âµ = cÂµ for a constant c. If G is compact,
this relationship may be integrated, and by the change of variables formula
we deduce that c = 1. Hence, Âµ is also right invariant.

The Real General Linear Group GL(n, R).
In the previous section we
showed that GL(n, R) is a Lie group, that it is an open subset of the vector
space of all linear maps of Rn into itself, and that its Lie algebra is gl(n, R)
with the commutator bracket. Since it is open in L(Rn, Rn) = gl(n, R), the
group GL(n, R) is not compact. The determinant function det : GL(n, R) â†’
R is smooth and maps GL(n, R) onto the two components of R\{0}. Thus,
GL(n, R) is not connected.

something that is in reality straightforward. To see this, note that it follows
from Lemma 9.2.3 that det : GL(n, R) â†’R is a submersion, so SL(n, R) =
detâˆ’1(1) is a smooth closed submanifold and hence a closed Lie subgroup.
The tangent space to SL(n, R) at A âˆˆSL(n, R) therefore consists of all
matrices B such that trace(Aâˆ’1B) = 0. In particular, the tangent space at
the identity consists of the matrices with trace zero. We have seen that the
Lie algebra of GL(n, R) is L(Rn, Rn) = gl(n, R) with the Lie bracket given
by [A, B] = AB âˆ’BA. It follows that the Lie algebra sl(n, R) of SL(n, R)
consists of the set of n Ã— n matrices having trace zero, with the bracket
[A, B] = AB âˆ’BA.
Since trace(B) = 0 imposes one condition on B, it follows that
dim[sl(n, R)] = n2 âˆ’1.

Proposition 9.2.10.

Proof.

x2 + y2 + z2
(and (0, 0, 0) to the identity). This mapping is clearly smooth and surjec-

SO(3) is diï¬€eomorphic with D, with antipodal points on the boundary
identiï¬ed.

The Complex General Linear Group GL(n, C).
Many important Lie
groups involve complex matrices. As in the real case,
GL(n, C) = { n Ã— n invertible complex matrices }

300
9. An Introduction to Lie Groups
is an open set in L(Cn, Cn) = { nÃ—n complex matrices }. Clearly, GL(n, C)
is a group under matrix multiplication. Therefore, GL(n, C) is a Lie group
and has the Lie algebra gl(n, C) = { nÃ—n complex matrices } = L(Cn, Cn).
Hence GL(n, C) has complex dimension n2, that is, real dimension 2n2.
We shall prove below that GL(n, C) is connected (contrast this with
the fact that GL(n, R) has two components). As in the real case, we will
need a polar decomposition theorem to do this. A matrix U âˆˆGL(n, C)
is unitary if UU â€  = U â€ U = I, where U â€  := U
T. A matrix P âˆˆgl(n, C)
is called Hermitian if P â€  = P. A Hermitian matrix P is called positive
deï¬nite, denoted by P > 0, if âŸ¨Pz, zâŸ©> 0 for all z âˆˆCn, z Ì¸= 0, where
âŸ¨, âŸ©denotes the inner product on Cn. Note that P > 0 implies that P is
invertible.
Proposition 9.2.15 (Complex Polar Decomposition).
For any matrix
A âˆˆGL(n, C), there exists a unique unitary matrix U and positive deï¬nite
Hermitian matrices P1, P2 such that
A = UP1 = P2U.
The proof is identical to that of Proposition 9.2.1 with the obvious
changes. The only additional property needed is the fact that the eigenval-
ues of a Hermitian matrix are real. As in the proof of the real case, one
needs to use the connectedness of the space of unitary matrices (proved in
Â§9.3) to conclude the following:
Proposition 9.2.16.
The group GL(n, C) is a complex noncompact con-
nected Lie group of complex dimension n2 and real dimension 2n2. Its Lie
algebra gl(n, C) consists of all nÃ—n complex matrices with the commutator
bracket.
On gl(n, C), the inner product is deï¬ned by

The Complex Special Linear Group.
This group is deï¬ned by

and is treated as in the real case. In the proof of its connectedness one uses

Proposition 9.2.17.
The group SL(n, C) is a complex noncompact Lie
group of complex dimension n2 âˆ’1 and real dimension 2(n2 âˆ’1). Its Lie
algebra sl(n, C) consists of all nÃ—n complex matrices of trace zero with the
commutator bracket.

9.3
Actions of Lie Groups
In this section we develop some basic facts about actions of Lie groups on
manifolds. One of our main applications later will be the description of
Hamiltonian systems with symmetry groups.
Basic Deï¬nitions.
We begin with the deï¬nition of the action of a Lie
group G on a manifold M.
Deï¬nition 9.3.1.
Let M be a manifold and let G be a Lie group. A (left)
action of a Lie group G on M is a smooth mapping Î¦ : GÃ—M â†’M such
that:
(i) Î¦(e, x) = x for all x âˆˆM; and
(ii) Î¦(g, Î¦(h, x)) = Î¦(gh, x) for all g, h âˆˆG and x âˆˆM.
A right action is a map Î¨ : M Ã— G â†’M that satisï¬es Î¨(x, e) = x and
Î¨(Î¨(x, g), h) = Î¨(x, gh). We sometimes use the notation g Â·x = Î¦(g, x) for
left actions, and xÂ·g = Î¨(x, g) for right actions. In the inï¬nite-dimensional
case there are important situations where care with the smoothness is
needed. For the formal development we assume that we are in the Banachâ€“
Lie group context.
For every g âˆˆG let Î¦g : M â†’M be given by x â†’Î¦(g, x). Then (i)
becomes Î¦e = idM, while (ii) becomes Î¦gh = Î¦g â—¦Î¦h. Deï¬nition 9.3.1
can now be rephrased by saying that the map g â†’Î¦g is a homomorphism
of G into Diï¬€(M), the group of diï¬€eomorphisms of M. In the special but
important case where M is a Banach space V and each Î¦g : V â†’V is
a continuous linear transformation, the action Î¦ of G on V is called a
representation of G on V .

An action is said to be:

Equivariance.
A map between two spaces is equivariant when it respects
group actions on these spaces. We state this more precisely:
Deï¬nition 9.3.5.
Let M and N be manifolds and let G be a Lie group
that acts on M by Î¦g : M â†’M, and on N by Î¨g : N â†’N. A smooth
map f : M â†’N is called equivariant with respect to these actions if for
all g âˆˆG,
f â—¦Î¦g = Î¨g â—¦f,

particular, if f is an equivariant diï¬€eomorphism, then f âˆ—Î¾N = Î¾M.
Also note that if M/G and N/G are both smooth manifolds with the

Connectivity of Some Classical Groups.
First we state two facts
about homogeneous spaces:
1. If H is a closed normal subgroup of the Lie group G (that is, if
h âˆˆH and g âˆˆG, then ghgâˆ’1 âˆˆH), then the quotient G/H is
a Lie group and the natural projection Ï€ : G â†’G/H is a smooth
group homomorphism. (This follows from Proposition 9.3.2; see also
Theorem 2.9.6 in Varadarajan [1974, p. 80].) Moreover, if H and
G/H are connected, then G is connected. Similarly, if H and G/H
are simply connected, then G is simply connected.
2. Let G, M be ï¬nite-dimensional and second countable and let Î¦ :
GÃ—M â†’M be a transitive action of G on M, and for x âˆˆM, let Gx
be the isotropy subgroup of x. Then the map gGx â†’Î¦g(x) is a dif-
feomorphism of G/Gx onto M. (This follows from Proposition 9.3.2;
see also Theorem 2.9.4 in Varadarajan [1974, p. 77].)

Proof.

fact 1 above, using induction on n and the representation of the spheres as

supplement). Let G be a subgroup of GL(n, R) (resp. GL(n, C)) deï¬ned

(d) Unitary Group of Hilbert Space.
Another basic example of an
inï¬nite-dimensional group is the unitary group U(H) of a complex Hilbert
space H. If G is a Lie group and Ï : G â†’U(H) is a group homomorphism,
we call Ï a unitary representation. In other words, Ï is an action of G
on H by unitary maps.
As with the diï¬€eomorphism group, questions of smoothness regarding
U(H) need to be dealt with carefully, and in this book we shall give only
a brief indication of what is involved. The reason for care is, for one thing,
that one ultimately is dealing with PDEs rather than ODEs and the hy-
potheses made must be such that PDEs are not excluded. For example,
for a unitary representation one assumes that for each Ïˆ, Ï• âˆˆH, the map
g â†’âŸ¨Ïˆ, Ï(g)Ï•âŸ©of G to C is continuous. In particular, for G = R one has the
notion of a continuous one-parameter group U(t) so that U(0) = identity
and
U(t + s) = U(t) â—¦U(s).
Stoneâ€™s theorem says that in an appropriate sense we can write U(t) =
etA, where A is an (unbounded) skew-adjoint operator deï¬ned on a dense
domain D(A) âŠ‚H. See, for example, Abraham, Marsden, and Ratiu [1988,
Section 7.4B] for the proof. Conversely each skew-adjoint operator deï¬nes
a one-parameter subgroup. Thus, Stoneâ€™s theorem gives precise meaning
to the statement that the Lie algebra u(H) of U(H) consists of the skew-
adjoint operators. The Lie bracket is the commutator, as long as one is
careful with domains.
If Ï is a unitary representation of a ï¬nite-dimensional Lie group G on
H, then Ï(exp(tÎ¾)) is a one-parameter subgroup of U(H), so Stoneâ€™s the-
orem guarantees that there is a map Î¾ â†’A(Î¾) associating a skew-adjoint
operator A(Î¾) to each Î¾ âˆˆg. Formally, we have
[A(Î¾), A(Î·)] = A[Î¾, Î·].
Results like this are aided by a theorem of Nelson [1959] guaranteeing a
dense subspace DG âŠ‚H such that
(i) A(Î¾) is well-deï¬ned on DG,
(ii) A(Î¾) maps DG to DG, and
(iii) for Ïˆ âˆˆDG, [exp tA(Î¾)]Ïˆ is Câˆin t with derivative at t = 0 given by
A(Î¾)Ïˆ.
This space is called an essential G-smooth part of H, and on DG the
above commutator relation and the linearity
A(Î±Î¾ + Î²Î·) = Î±A(Î¾) + Î²A(Î·)
become literally true. Moreover, we lose little by using DG, since A(Î¾) is
uniquely determined by what it is on DG.

We identify U(1) with the unit circle in C, and each such complex number

general problem considered by Bargmann and Wigner of lifting projective

two skew-adjoint operators A and A + Î»i, for Î» real.

Miscellany.
We conclude this section with a variety of remarks.
1. Coadjoint Isotropy.
The ï¬rst remark concerns coadjoint orbit isotro-
py groups. The main result here is the following theorem, due to Duï¬‚o and
Vergne [1969]. We give a proof following Rais [1972] in the Internet sup-
plement.
Theorem 9.3.10 (Duï¬‚o and Vergne).
Letg be a ï¬nite-dimensional Lie
algebra with dual gâˆ—and let r = min { dim gÂµ | Âµ âˆˆgâˆ—}. The set { Âµ âˆˆgâˆ—|
dim gÂµ = r } is open and dense in gâˆ—. If dim gÂµ = r, then gÂµ is Abelian.
A simple example is the rotation group SO(3) in which the coadjoint
isotropy at each nonzero point is the Abelian group S1, whereas at the
origin it is the nonabelian group SO(3).
2. More on Inï¬nite-Dimensional Groups.
We can use a slight rein-
terpretation of the formulae in this section to calculate the Lie algebra
structure of some inï¬nite-dimensional groups. Here we will treat this topic
only formally, that is, we assume that the spaces involved are manifolds and
do not specify the function-space topologies. For the formal calculations,
these structures are not needed, but the reader should be aware that there
is a mathematical gap here. (See Ebin and Marsden [1970] and Adams,
Ratiu, and Schmid [1986a, 1986b] for more information.)
Given a manifold M, let Diï¬€(M) denote the group of all diï¬€eomorphisms
of M. The group operation is composition. The Lie algebra of Diï¬€(M), as
a vector space, consists of vector ï¬elds on M; indeed, the ï¬‚ow of a vector

ï¬eld is a curve in Diï¬€(M), and its tangent vector at t = 0 is the given
vector ï¬eld.
To determine the Lie algebra bracket, we consider the action of an arbi-

a homomorphism Î¦ : G â†’Diï¬€(M). By Proposition 9.1.5, its derivative at
the identity TeÎ¦ should be a Lie algebra homomorphism. From the deï¬ni-

[Î¾M, Î·M]Lie bracket = âˆ’[Î¾M, Î·M].
This suggests that the Lie algebra bracket on X(M) is minus the Jacobiâ€“Lie
bracket.
Another way to arrive at the same conclusion is to use the method of

3. Equivariant Darboux Theorem.
In Chapter 5 we studied the Dar-
boux theorem. It is natural to ask the sense in which this theorem holds in
the presence of a group action. That is, suppose that one has a Lie group
G (say compact) acting symplectically on a symplectic manifold (P, â„¦)
and that, for example, the group action leaves a point x0 âˆˆP ï¬xed (one
can consider the more general case of an invariant manifold). We ask to
what extent one can put the symplectic form into a canonical form in an
equivariant way?
This question is best broken up into two parts. The ï¬rst is whether or not
one can ï¬nd a local equivariant representation in which the symplectic form
is constant. This is true and can be proved by establishing an equivariant
diï¬€eomorphism between the manifold and its tangent space at x0 carrying
the constant symplectic form, which is just â„¦evaluated at Tx0P. This
is done by checking that Moserâ€™s proof given in Chapter 5 can be made
equivariant at each stage (see Exercise 9.3-5).
A more subtle question is that of putting the symplectic form into a
canonical form equivariantly. For this, one needs ï¬rst to understand the
equivariant classiï¬cation of normal forms for symplectic structures. This
was done in Dellnitz and Melbourne [1993]. For the related question of
classifying equivariant normal forms for linear Hamiltonian systems, see
Williamson [1936], Melbourne and Dellnitz [1993], and HÂ¨ormander [1995].
